competencyText.en-us: Science Skills and Practices
Students manipulate and analyze scientific data presented in tables, graphs, and diagrams.

en-us: Recognize trends in data
Translate tabular data into graphs
Interpolate and extrapolate
Reason mathematically

competencyText.en-us: Students locate data in data presentations such as graphs, charts, or tables.

en-us: For example, students identify basic features of a table or select one or more pieces of data from a data presentation.

competencyText.en-us: Select one piece of data from a data presentation
Find information in text that describes a data presentation
Select two or more pieces of data from a data presentation
Identify features of a table, graph, or diagram (e.g., axis labels, units of measure)
Understand common scientific terminology, symbols, and units of measure
Students infer relationships between pieces of data or translate data from one form to another.

en-us: For example, students may determine how the value of one variable changes as the value of a second variable changes, or translate information into a table, graph, or diagram.

competencyText.en-us: Translate information into a table, graph, or diagram
Determine how the value of a variable changes as the value of another variable changes in a data presentation
Compare data from a data presentation (e.g., find the highest/lowest value; order data from a table)

en-us: Find the highest/lowest value
Order data from a table

competencyText.en-us: Combine data from a data presentation (e.g., sum data from a table)

en-us: Sum data from a table

competencyText.en-us: Compare data from two or more data presentations (e.g., compare a value in a table to a value in a graph)

en-us: Compare a value in a table to a value in a graph

competencyText.en-us: Combine data from two or more data presentations (e.g., categorize data from a table using a scale from another table)

en-us: Categorize data from a table using a scale from another table

competencyText.en-us: Determine and/or use a mathematical relationship that exists between data (e.g., averaging data, unit conversions)

en-us: Averaging data
Unit conversions

competencyText.en-us: Students make predictions based on the trends in the data.

en-us: For example, students may make interpolations or extrapolations based on the data.

competencyText.en-us: Perform an interpolation using data in a table or graph
Perform an extrapolation using data in a table or graph
Analyze presented data when given new information (e.g., reinterpret a graph when new findings are provided)

en-us: Reinterpret a graph when new findings are provided

competencyText.en-us: Students understand experimental tools, procedures, and design and compare, extend, and modify experiments.

en-us: Identify variables and controls
Predict the results of additional trials

competencyText.en-us: Students locate and compare information about one or more scientific investigations or experiments. For example, students identify similarities and differences between experiments.
Find information in text that describes an experiment
Identify similarities and differences between experiments
Determine which experiments utilize a given tool, method, or aspect of design
Students understand and evaluate aspects of experimental design.

en-us: For example, students could determine the hypothesis of an experiment or identify a flaw in the design.

competencyText.en-us: Understand the methods, tools, and functions of tools used in an experiment
Understand an experimental design
Determine the scientific question that is the basis for an experiment (e.g., the hypothesis)

en-us: Determine the hypothesis

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate the design or methods of an experiment (e.g., possible flaws or inconsistencies; precision and accuracy issues)

en-us: Possible flaws or inconsistencies
Precision and accuracy issues

competencyText.en-us: Students make predictions about future experiments or experimental conditions or designs.

en-us: For example, students may predict the results of an additional trial or determine how additional trials could enhance the conclusions based on the experiments.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the results of an additional trial or measurement in an experiment
Determine the experimental conditions that would produce specified results
Determine an alternate method for testing a hypothesis
Predict the effects of modifying the design or methods of an experiment
Determine which additional trial or experiment could be performed to enhance or evaluate experimental results

competencyLabel.en-us: Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results

competencyText.en-us: Students judge the validity of scientific information and formulate conclusions and predictions based on that information.

en-us: Determine which explanation for a scientific phenomenon is supported by new findings

competencyLabel.en-us: Inferences and Results: Evaluating and Extending

competencyText.en-us: Students evaluate and formulate hypotheses, predictions, and conclusions based on experimental results and other scientific data.

en-us: For example, students determine which hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is or is not consistent with two or more data presentations and/or pieces of information in text.

competencyText.en-us: Determine which hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is or is not consistent with a data presentation or piece of information in text
Determine which experimental results support or contradict a hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion
Determine which hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is or is not consistent with two or more data presentations and/or pieces of information in text
Make a prediction and explain why it is consistent with a data presentation or piece of information in text
Explain why presented information or new information supports or contradicts a hypothesis or conclusion
Make a prediction and explain why it is consistent with two or more data presentations and/or pieces of information in text
Students locate and compare information within a theoretical model or across competing models.

en-us: For example, students identify assumptions of a model or identify differences between two models.

competencyText.en-us: Find information in a theoretical model (a viewpoint proposed to explain scientific observations)
Identify implications and assumptions in a theoretical model
Determine which theoretical models present or imply certain information
Identify similarities and differences between theoretical models
Students evaluate and formulate predictions and hypotheses based on the examination of competing theoretical models.

en-us: For example, students determine if new information strengthens or weakens a model and why, or use new information to make a prediction based on a model.

competencyText.en-us: Determine which hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is or is not consistent with a theoretical model
Determine which hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is or is not consistent with two or more theoretical models
Identify the strengths and weaknesses of theoretical models
Determine which theoretical models are supported or weakened by new information
Determine which theoretical models support or contradict a hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion
Use new information to make a prediction based on a theoretical model
Explain why presented information or new information supports or weakens a theoretical model
Make a prediction and explain why it is consistent with a theoretical model
Make a prediction and explain why it is consistent with two or more theoretical models
Science practices related to engineering and engineering design

competencyLabel.en-us: Science Skills and Practices Learning Progressions

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to the processes and practices scientists and engineers use to understand, explain, and make predictions related to scientific questions or engineering problems
Learning progressions on the practices of making observations during experiments and using that information for analysis and communication
Learning progression on using graphs, charts, tables, and diagrams to communicate, understand, and interpret scientific information or experimental data
Determining what data to collect
Understand that observations and measurements gathered in an investigation are data
Understand that some data involve verbal or pictorial observations
Understand that some data involve numerical measurements
Make and record observations using the five senses

en-us: Look at a flower and record its temperature, number of leaves, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Draw pictures to represent observations, processes, or results of an investigation

en-us: Draw a picture of a flower
Sketch how the seeds were planted

competencyText.en-us: Record data as instructed by teacher, worksheet, etc.
Differentiate between qualitative and quantitative data
Determine what data needs to be collected

en-us: This could be scaffolded using table or column headings. As competence in designing experiments grows, this could become more learner-directed.

competencyText.en-us: Deciding what instrument and measurement units are needed to collect the data
Understand that different science tools are used to measure different characteristics or events
Use a science tool to collect data as instructed by teacher, worksheet, etc.

en-us: Thermometer, ruler, computer probe

competencyText.en-us: Record data using the measurement units as instructed by teacher, worksheet, etc.

en-us: The worksheet would say Use a thermometer to record the temperature.""

competencyText.en-us: Determine what instrument or tool is needed to make the measurements or observations described in instructions by a teacher, worksheet, etc.

en-us: If the teacher says Record the temperature

competencyText.en-us: Determine what instrument or tool is necessary to gather data about a claim, model, or explanation

en-us: If the goal is to determine the effect of temperature on the volume of a gas, the student would determine that a thermometer or temperature probe would be necessary to measure the temperature.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that different science tools may measure the same quantity to different levels of precision and accuracy

en-us: A beaker and a graduated cylinder can both measure volume. However, the lines on a graduated cylinder are designed to give measurements that are both more accurate and precise.

competencyText.en-us: Select a science tool that meets the requirements for measurement in an investigation
Deciding how to record data
Understand that data can be presented in a variety of ways
Understand how to use a simple data table that is provided to record data from an investigation
Create a simple data table to record data from an investigation
Understand that there is variability in data, so one sample is not sufficient
Record data to the precision given in the instructions

en-us: If the directions state to record to the nearest gram, all measurements are made to the units digit.

competencyText.en-us: Determine how many decimal places should be recorded for data

en-us: The student sees temperature data on a digital probe with two decimal places and decides to round to the nearest tenth of a degree.

competencyText.en-us: Use digital or computer-based probes to collect and record data (in real time)
Organizing data as it is collected
Record data accurately for the independent variable, time sample, location sample, etc.

en-us: In an investigation on biodiversity, regions could be grouped by 0-5, 6-10, 11-15, or 16+ organisms in the sampling zone.

competencyText.en-us: Group data into equivalent sections as directed by teachers, worksheets, etc.
Use a computer to organize and manipulate data

en-us: Lehrer's group has shown that simply manipulating data in a computer program can facilitate growth in reasoning and modeling.

competencyText.en-us: Communicating data in tables, graphs, etc.
Find data in simple diagrams or graphs

en-us: Food chain, bar graph, histogram, pie graph

competencyText.en-us: Find data in complex diagrams or graphs

en-us: Stacked bar graph, multivariable axes

competencyText.en-us: Create a simple data table to communicate results using table headings, units, etc.
Batch data into meaningful groups to make it easier to understand

en-us: Equipartitions, quartiles, critical points (phase shifts, etc.)

competencyText.en-us: Create a simple graph to communicate results

en-us: Bar graph, histogram, scatter plot, line graph

competencyText.en-us: Find and report the mean of a data set
Find and report the median of a data set

en-us: Use the counting technique
This can be done at early elementary grades

competencyText.en-us: Find and report the mode of a data set
Find and report the range of a data set
Create a stacked bar graph to communicate data from an investigation

en-us: This could be done via computer or by hand.

competencyText.en-us: Create a pie graph to communicate percentages

en-us: This could be done via computer or by hand.

competencyText.en-us: Communicate using both qualitative and quantitative information
Explain the relationships, in verbal or written form, that are illustrated by a graph, chart, or table

en-us: Explicitly stating the claim and reasoning that can be made based on the data

competencyText.en-us: Understand that data becomes evidence when it is linked to a claim by reasoning
Explain how the data from an investigation is evidence for a claim
Deciding which presentation form is best to communicate the results
Understand that different presentation forms do a better job of communicating different types or trends in data or information

en-us: Pie graphs are best for showing percentages
Scatter plots can show lines of best fit and regression.

competencyText.en-us: Select a visual form (graph, chart, etc.) that is best able to communicate the trends in the data
Create a presentation including both verbal and graphic information that can be used to argue claims, evidence, and reasoning using print media based on an investigation

Create a presentation including both verbal and graphic information that can be used to argue claims, evidence, and reasoning using digital media such as PowerPoint, Prezi, etc. based on an investigation
Deliver a presentation using either a print media (poster or other written format) or digital media to convey claims, evidence, and reasoning from an investigation
Learning progression on using trend analysis and mathematics to interpret data collected from investigations
Did the experiment give good results (engineering model")?"
Evaluate an experiment as to whether or not the results were good
Student changes all possible causative variables in an effort to get desired result rather than using a control-of-variables approach.
What is the relationship between two variables?
Understand that two variables may or may not have an influence on each other

en-us: Kuhn, Amsel, and McLoughlin worked with content neutral propositions (what foods might contribute to getting sick) to look at control of variables, but students rated some of them as influential, some as having no influence.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that two variables may be positively correlated (directly related)

en-us: Kuhn et al.: Some students were shown that when children ate a specific food (orange juice), they would get sick.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that two variables may be negatively correlated (inversely related)

en-us: As distance from a light increases, brightness (light intensity) decreases.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that two variables may not be related

en-us: Sometimes the children got sick when they drank juice
Sometimes they were healthy when they drank juice (in the Kuhn et al research).

competencyText.en-us: Determine if a variable is positively correlated with the outcome
Determine if a variable is negatively correlated with the outcome
Determine if a variable is not correlated with the outcome
Amount of data needed for evidence
Understand that more than one piece of data is needed to draw a conclusion
Evaluate whether there is enough evidence to justify calling data evidence
Identify patterns in large sets of data
Batch data into meaningful blocks
Reorganize data to assist in analyzing trends

en-us: This could involve batching, graphing, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Find the median of a set of data using counting in or other technique
Determine or calculate the range of a set of data
Identify the mode (or bi-modes) of a given set of data
Determine how the value of one variable changes as the value of another variable changes in a simple data presentation (chart, table, graph)
Estimate by interpolation a value based on a simple graph or table
Estimate by extrapolation a value based on a simple graph or table
Create an x-y scatter plot from measurements taken in an investigation
Calculate the mean of a given set of data
Contrast the mean, median, and mode as measures of central tendency
Identify quartile points or other equipartitions to find measures of central tendency
Explain how range data might be more important in lab or engineering settings

en-us: Since failure of equipment can occur at extreme conditions, these might be more important for engineering or safety concerns.

competencyText.en-us: Identify a line of best fit for a scatter plot
Draw a line of best fit for a scatter plot
Identify the y-intercept for a line of best fit
Determine if the dependent and independent variables appear to be positively or negatively correlated (if correlated at all) by examining the line of best fit
Determine if the dependent and independent variables appear to be positively or negatively correlated (if correlated at all) by using statistics or statistical software

en-us: Some real-time data collection devices can easily print equations of best fit and r-squared values for data.

competencyText.en-us: Examine and evaluate anomalous data
Understand that there is variability in data, so one sample is not sufficient
Understand that an outlier is a data point that is very dissimilar from the other data
Explain the effect that an outlier has on the mean value of a set
Explain that an outlier has a smaller effect on the mean of a large set of data
Justify orally or in writing the selection of mean, median, mode, or inner-quartile (or other inner-equal partition) as an appropriate measure of central tendency for a given set of experimental data
Understand that all measurements of continuous data are approximations
Understand that error bars (whiskers) show the possible range of values associated with a measurement
Draw the error whiskers on a measurement to show the range of possible values the measurement represents
Understand that two piece of data with over-lapping error whiskers are the same, given the measurement device available
Use math or computer analysis to determine if variation in data is likely to be a result of errors in data collection, instrumentation, or actual variations in the data
Identify that two variables are not correlated
Understand that some variables do not have an impact on the outcome of an investigation or phenomenon
Determine whether or not two variables covary consistently
Understand that correlation does not insure causality
Understand that two or more independent variables can have an effect on the dependent variable
Understand that two or more variables may have an effect on an outcome

en-us: Temperature, volume, and number of gas particles all have an effect on gas pressure.

competencyText.en-us: Identify two variables that both make a difference on the outcome
Understand that if two variables both make a difference on an outcome, they may or may not be equally important
Understand that statistics or statistics software can be used to determine the relative importance of two variables
Some variables make a difference on the outcome only if another loading variable has a necessary value.
Understand that some variables only have an effect on the outcome at certain levels

en-us: When selecting students for National Honor Society, the teacher ratings only matter if the GPA is above the necessary value (e.g., 3.60).

competencyText.en-us: Determine if one variable acted as a threshold variable for a second variable in an investigation
Develop an explanation that could explain why a variable may act as a threshold for another variable
Understand that a variable may act as a threshold for one effect but not for others

en-us: Although frequency of light does have a threshold effect on the current in the photoelectric effect, it has no such effect on light intensity or reflection.

competencyText.en-us: Learning progression of knowledge and skills related to designing, performing, and analyzing scientific investigations

competencyLabel.en-us: Develop and Test Scientific Questions LP

competencyText.en-us: Learning progression on developing scientific questions and investigations to explore phenomena
Scientific questions
Ask a question
Understand that there are different types of questions
Understand that a scientific question can be answered by evidence from an investigation

en-us: How much light is needed for a bean plant to grow?" is a scientific question. "Do you like bean plants?" is not a scientific question."

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a scientific question should be interesting and important to investigate
Understand that you may need knowledge about the topic before you can ask a scientific question

en-us: Information gathered in an explore activity as part of the 5E learning cycle could be the starting knowledge required.

competencyText.en-us: Ask a scientific question
Ask a scientific question that can be investigated by the student
Understand that the purpose of an investigation is to test a hypothesis
Understand that a hypothesis is an informed prediction that can be tested
Make a hypothesis that answers a scientific question

en-us: Ideally, a hypothesis should lead to a causal explanation model with sufficient testing and not just I think that Energizer batteries will last longer than Eveready.""

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the purpose of an investigation is to test a hypothesis
Identify the hypothesis in an investigation
Identify the purpose of an investigation
Perform an investigation, given instructions, that tests a hypothesis
Design an investigation to observe or describe phenomena that address the scientific question
Design an investigation to observe or describe phenomena that address the scientific question posed

en-us: What is the life cycle of a caterpillar?

competencyText.en-us: Determine what data needs to be collected to test the hypothesis
Collect data needed to test the hypothesis

en-us: This may be qualitative or quantitative data, depending on the investigation.

competencyText.en-us: Analyze the data (leads to their LP map)
Determine if the results of the investigation confirm or do not confirm the hypotheses
Design an investigation with alternative possible outcomes
Make a hypothesis as a testable if...then statement

en-us: If the temperature of the fish tank is raised to 30 degrees Celsius, then seaweed will grow faster.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that an independent variable is changed by the investigator

en-us: In the example above, the IV is the temperature of the fish tank.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a dependent variable is measured to show the effect of the investigation

en-us: The DV here would be the growth of seaweed.

competencyText.en-us: Identify the independent variable in an investigation
Identify the dependent variable in an investigation
Understand that how a variable (IV or DV) is measured influences what conclusions can be made about the hypothesis
Determine how to measure an independent variable (tools, units, number of measurements)

en-us: The temperature of the fish tank will be measured with a temperature probe that records data every hour to the nearest degree Celsius.

competencyText.en-us: Determine how to measure a dependent variable (tools, units, number of measurements)

en-us: The growth of seaweed will be measured by height of the seaweed plants in cm.

competencyText.en-us: Design an investigation that could have outcomes that confirm or not confirm the hypothesis
Understand that experiments should be replicated and that the outcomes will have a range of values
Understand that a test or investigation should be done more than once to verify results
Understand that when a test or investigation is repeated, all aspects of the test should be as close to the same as possible
Understand that measurements in an investigation will not be exactly the same value
Understand that some of the differences between the measurements in an investigation come from normal variation in outcomes

en-us: When growing plants with identical amounts of light and water, some plants will grow taller than others because of natural variation in the plants.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some of the differences between the measurements in an investigation come from the limitations of the measurement tools

en-us: A graduated cylinder with markings for every 1 mL can only measure with an estimate to the tenths place, which will be +/- .1 mL. A digital balance may be +/- 2 grams. Using a beaker to measure volume may give an error of +/- 10.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a measurement can be made one decimal place past the smallest graduated line on a measuring device

en-us: A ruler marked to cm can be measured to the nearest .1 cm with an understanding of an error of +/- .1 cm.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some of the differences between the measurements in an investigation come from student errors; However, these can be minimized by using the proper equipment correctly
Understand that because measurements in an investigation will exhibit a range of values, they must be analyzed mathematically
Understand that the more times an investigation is replicated with similar results, the more confidence you can have in the relationships (if any) between the variables
Explain that an investigation with more trials is more trustworthy (likely to be valid) than an investigation with fewer trials
Determine if a second investigation replicated the first by determining if they both had the same independent and dependent variables
Design an investigation to replicate an investigation
Perform an investigation that replicates an investigation
Compare and contrast the results of the replicated experiment and the original experiment to determine if the same conclusion is justified by the evidence
Understand and apply a control-of-variables approach
Understand that alternate variables should be kept constant from one trial to another in an investigation
Understand the difference between a control group and a control (controlled variable)
Identify a control group in an experiment

en-us: This could be from a written description of the experiment or from reading the directions for the investigation.

competencyText.en-us: Identify a control (controlled variable) in an experiment

en-us: This could be from a written description of the experiment or from reading the directions for the investigation.

competencyText.en-us: Identify a potential variable that needs to be controlled
Determine how to control a possible confounding variable
Identify two or more potential variables that need to be controlled
Design an investigation that controls possible confounding variables while changing the independent variable
Perform an investigation that controls possible confounding variables while changing the independent variable
Perform a series of investigations that test possible variables one at a time

en-us: First run an experiment to see the effect of changing volume on the pressure of a gas at constant T. Then conduct an investigation in which volume is held constant but temperature is varied to see its effect on P.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a fair test changes only one variable while keeping other potential variables constant

en-us: This shows up in early grades in ACARA standards.

competencyText.en-us: Predict a possible effect of not controlling a potential variable
Design a series of investigations that test possible variables one at a time
Understand a direct relation between two variables

en-us: As one variable increases, the second variable also increases.

competencyText.en-us: Understand inverse relations between variables

en-us: As one variable increases, the second variable decreases.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there might not be enough evidence to determine if two variables covary
Understand that variables may or may not have a correlation
Identify whether or not two variables covary
Understand that correlation does not automatically identify causality
Design and analyze investigations that consider multiple variables and their interactions
Understand that two or more variables may have an effect on an outcome

en-us: Temperature, volume, and number of gas particles all have an effect on gas pressure.

competencyText.en-us: Identify two variables that both make a difference on the outcome
Understand that if two variables both make a difference on an outcome, they may or may not be equally important
Understand that statistics or statistics software can be used to determine the relative importance of two variables
Understand that in complex systems (like living things) it may be impossible to control all possible confounding variables

en-us: In doing medical research, you cannot control every aspect of the subjects' lives ... what they eat, where they live, what they do for a living, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that control groups are used in research to try to counteract the variables outside the control of the investigator
Understand that some variables only have an effect on the outcome at certain levels

en-us: Studying increases grades up to a point, and then you reach the point of diminishing returns.

competencyText.en-us: Identify whether or not an investigation was designed to see if one of the variables acts as a threshold, allowing the other variable to have an effect only within a certain range
Design an investigation to determine if one variable acts as a threshold for a second variable on the outcome
Perform an investigation to determine if one variable acts as a threshold for a second variable on the outcome
Determine if one variable acts as a threshold variable for a second variable in an investigation
Develop an explanation that could explain why a variable may act as a threshold for another variable
Understand that a variable may act as a threshold for one effect but not for others

en-us: Although frequency of light does have a threshold effect on the current in the photoelectric effect, it has no such effect on light intensity or reflection.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that multiple variables may all have effects on an outcome in investigation
Develop an investigation to evaluate portions of multivariable models
Understand that some systems are so complex that it may not be possible to understand the effects of all potential variables as they interact with current technology

competencyLabel.en-us: Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Results LP

competencyText.en-us: Learning progressions on the practice of using empirical evidence and other available information to predict and explain what happens in natural and engineering processes by linking evidence with reasoning to form claims or hypotheses
Learning progression on making and evaluating of scientific claims, evidence, and reasoning
Narrative accounts and explanations
Make observations about an event from information gathered using the senses or simple equipment

en-us: Simple equipment would include thermometers, rulers, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Make an inference about an event from information gathered using the senses or simple equipment
Descriptions of events are considered to be explanations
Understand the differences between observation and inference
Understand that inferences are logical conclusions drawn from information and observations
Make an inference from information in a reading passage
Understand the difference between an observation and an inference
Determine if a given statement is an observation or an inference
Engage in a discussion about whether a statement is an observation or inference
Understand that science is a field that uses experiments to predict and explain what happens not only in the classroom but also the world (universe) at large
Understand that one fundamental assumption of science is that scientific processes obey the same rules (laws) in all places and at all times
Understand that some science investigations rely on examining existing evidence to create theoretical models rather than manipulating variables in a controlled experiment
Make a claim (conclusion) and support it with evidence in a scientific argument
Understand that a claim is an inference or conclusion that has been made
Understand that scientific arguments address debatable claims (falsifiable claims)
Identify a claim or inference
Understand that evidence is information used to support a claim
Understand that data from an investigation becomes evidence when it is used to support a claim
Determine if a given claim has been given evidence to support
Identify a piece of evidence in a scientific argument
Make a scientific claim

en-us: Scientific claims should be falsifiable.

competencyText.en-us: Make a scientific claim and support it with evidence
Engage in a discussion using evidence to support claims
Ask for evidence to be added to support a claim in a discussion

en-us: Asking for clarification and evidence requires some team building, modeling

competencyText.en-us: Claims and support with appropriate evidence
Understand that information may not be relevant to a claim or conclusion
Understand that some claims are based on feelings and prior understanding rather than current findings and logic
Identify whether a given piece of evidence is relevant to the claim
Identify the reasoning that links evidence to a conclusion or claim
Explain the reasoning that links the evidence to the conclusion in a scientific statement in a logical way
Understand that a model or explanatory theory can be evaluated using specific criteria

en-us: Sister Gertrude's research shows that this can begin at a very young age with scaffolding and then move to be more independent over time. Kathleen Metz's work has shown some similar things.

competencyText.en-us: Make a claim, justified with evidence, and give valid reasoning (scaffolding)
Understand that reasoning is the logical link between the evidence and claim in a scientific argument
Identify the reasoning that links evidence to a conclusion or claim in a scientific argument
Identify the claim, reasoning, and evidence for a scientific argument
Evaluate a scientific argument for intelligibility

en-us: Can others understand the explanation?

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a scientific argument for plausibility

en-us: Consistency with the evidence

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a scientific argument for extra assumptions needed for it to be true

en-us: non ad hocness" is the term Samarapungavan (1992) and Posner et al (1982) used"

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a scientific argument for consistency with other available and accepted scientific theories and knowledge
Ask for a speaker to supply reasoning to link evidence and claim in a scientific argument or discussion
Provide reasoning to link evidence and claim in a scientific argument or discussion when prompted by peer or teacher
Provide two or more pieces of evidence for justification when prompted
Make a written claim justified with evidence and reasoning with scaffolding

en-us: Examples of scaffolding would include having specific text boxes labeled Claim, Evidence Piece 1, Evidence Piece 2, and Reasonong. (Songer and Gotwals, 2012
Gotwals, Songer, and Bullard, 2009)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that more than one claim may be supported by evidence by using different reasoning or emphasis on different aspects of the data
Explain, orally or in writing, that there may be more than one plausible explanation/model for a given set of experimental data
Understand that science is a social process that involves consensus building based on published evidence

en-us: There may not be enough evidence to build consensus.

competencyText.en-us: Claim, evidence, and valid reasoning (without scaffolding)
Make a claim justified with evidence and reasoning that clearly links the evidence to the claim without scaffolding
Make a claim justified with two or more pieces of evidence and reasoning that clearly links the evidence to the claim without scaffolding
Make a claim that addresses the hypothesis of an investigation using clearly stated evidence and reasoning either orally or in writing
Evaluate a claim based on the quality of evidence and reasoning
Understand that empirical evidence is considered more acceptable (persuasive) than anecdotal evidence in science
Explain why empirical evidence is considered to be more acceptable than anecdotal evidence in science
Understand that a larger data set is generally considered to be better than a small data set
Understand that issues in experimental design and control may lead to reasonable doubt about the validity of relationships between variables
Understand that a sample should be similar to the larger group it represents
Understand that if a sample is not representative of the larger group that it represents, conclusions may not be transferable from the small sample to the larger group

en-us: The telephone poll of the 1948 election, which was only able to ask people who could afford telephones who they voted for, predicted that Dewey would beat Truman.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a random sample of a larger group could be representative of the larger group if the sample size is large enough

en-us: A sample should be more than one or two individuals.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that statistics and statistical software can be used to tell if a sample is similar to the large group
Evaluate whether or not a sample appears to be representative
Evaluate whether there seems to be enough data to warrant a conclusion

en-us: Students need to learn that multiple pieces of data are necessary to validate that a trend is occurring.

competencyText.en-us: Participate in a written or oral scientific argument about a topic of a science investigation
Understand that, in other disciplines, other forms of evidence are acceptable in a debate

en-us: Appeal to authority, narrative reports
Appeal to moral reasoning or principles, consensus, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Engage in a scientific debate using only appropriate scientific argumentation
Assess the amount of legitimate doubt to attach to a claim

en-us: This may require more formal operations and need to move to upper MS.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if more data as evidence is needed to justify a claim
Compare and contrast two scientific claims based on the evidence and reasoning and then develop a test to determine which claim is more likely
Determine the differences between two scientific arguments or explanations for a phenomenon
Determine what independent variable could be manipulated that might be able to distinguish which explanation could be correct
Understand that scientists generally consider the simplest explanation that is plausible and consistent with the evidence to be more likely correct
Design an investigation that could demonstrate that one scientific argument was not consistent with the data

en-us: An investigation that could demonstrate the falsifiability of one of the currently plausible explanations

competencyText.en-us: Perform an investigation that could demonstrate that one scientific argument was not consistent with the data
Evaluate the results of an investigation that could demonstrate that one scientific argument was not consistent with the data

en-us: The conclusion may still be that they are both consistent with data
Neither is consistent
Only A
or only B are consistent. It may also be that the test revealed nothing new.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that it may be impossible to determine which of two plausible explanations is more likely to be correct given time, technology, and physical limitations

en-us: Limitations of budget, time, and equipment may be easily understood. Limitations such as Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle may be more difficult for all but the oldest students to understand.

competencyText.en-us: Understand and explain, in oral or written form, that which scientific research is or is not pursued is influenced by nonscientific (political and social) factors like funding, economic impact, and status of the issue

en-us: Understand that science and science funding do not occur in a 'vacuum.' Some research is not funded because those making funding decisions do not want to receive scientific information that might contradict their point of (socio-political) view.

competencyText.en-us: Learning progression on using physical, representational, and conceptual models to make explanations and predictions
Models represent but are not identical to real objects and processes.
Distinguish between a model and the real object
Draw a picture to represent or model an observed event or situation
Use a model to represent an object by changing its scale, either larger or smaller, to a manageable size

en-us: A tabletop model of Earth, the Sun, and the Moon
Maps, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Using physical or representational models
Understand that some models represent the original as a physical copy of the original

en-us: Model of elbow research in which learners quickly moved from direct physical analogy to a model of how it moved and worked

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a model may not represent all parts of the original
Understand that a model may highlight some parts of the original for emphasis or analysis
Determine what parts of the original are not represented or emphasized in a model
Understand that a model is an analogy to a real system

en-us: Atoms as a planetary system (Bohr model) with electrons in near circular orbits around the nucleus

competencyText.en-us: Models as explanatory mechanisms for predicting and explaining relations between variables
Understand that models are a form of explanation
Understand that models are tools for making and revising analogies between scientists' ideas and the real world
Select which aspects of a natural system to emphasize in a model to test or examine a hypothesis
Emergent systems
Understand that the system as a whole may not behave the same way as the individual particles that make up the system
Models as tools to make explanations and predictions
Understand that models can be used to make predictions about what will happen

en-us: Models can be used to make testable predictions (hypotheses).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that models can be used to explain what has happened in the past

en-us: Models can be used to explain past events such as plate tectonics, evolution, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that models can be used to explain and represent cause and effect relationships
Make a prediction of what will happen in an experiment using a model
Explain events that occurred using a model
Design an investigation to test the prediction of a model
Evaluate the limitations, assumptions, and simplifications of a model for explaining and predicting through data analysis and testing
Understand that a model or explanatory theory can be evaluated using specific criteria
Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for intelligibility

en-us: Can others understand the explanation?

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for plausibility

en-us: Consistency with the evidence

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for conceptual coherence

en-us: It is internally consistent with no contradictory statements

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for fruitfulness

en-us: Does the model help to accomplish things or lead to new investigations?

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for extra assumptions needed for it to be true

en-us: non ad hocness" is the term Samarapungavan (1992) and Posner et al (1982) used"

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate a model or explanatory theory for consistency with other available and accepted scientific theories and knowledge
Evaluate the predictive power of a proposed model

en-us: Does the model predict some, most, or all possible events?

competencyText.en-us: Identify simplifications and assumptions used in a model
Evaluate likely reasons for the failure of a model to make accurate predictions of a phenomenon
Defend orally or in writing how experimental findings support a given explanatory model or theory
Evaluate whether new experimental findings support/refute/neither a model or explanatory theory
Design an investigation to test the prediction of a model
Make and use conceptual models, including parts that cannot be seen
Create a model that incorporates one cause as an explanation or prediction for an event
Create a conceptual model to explain observable experimental results with underlying conceptual mechanisms
Use a conceptual model to predict and explain observable results

en-us: As temperature increases, gas molecules will move faster, which will cause them to hit the container walls more often and harder, which will increase observed pressure if the volume is held constant.

competencyText.en-us: Use a mathematical model to predict and explain observable results

en-us: Halley's comet returns every 76 years, and it last appeared in 1986. When will it appear again?

competencyText.en-us: Understand that data can be generated to both generate and substantiate claims
Create a mathematical model that can accurately predict observable results

en-us: This could include interpolating, extrapolating, equation matching for data using a computer.

competencyText.en-us: Create a model that incorporates two or more causes that contribute to predictions or explanations for an event
Test and revise models
Understand that models are based on available evidence
Understand that as new evidence becomes available, a model should be reevaluated for plausibility, consistency with other theories, etc.
Reevaluate a model or explanatory theory for plausibility
Reevaluate a model or explanatory theory for fruitfulness
Reevaluate a model or explanatory theory for consistency with other available and accepted scientific theories and knowledge
Propose a revision or clarification to a model using new data as evidence for the changes
Propose a revision to a model when new data/evidence does not match the predictions of the model
Design an investigation to test the revisions of a model
Communicate using claim, evidence, and reasoning if and how a model was revised
Learning progression on applying design criteria to solve problems and build objects
Defining the problem
Define the problem only the engineer point of view, not considering the client or science
Consider only the client point of view or goals in defining the problem without concern for the engineering design or science views of the problem space
Able to define the goals of both the client (task) and engineer but does not consider relevant math or science topics
Define goals in terms of client and engineer while considering relevant math or science topics
Break down problem into smaller components/ parts/routines that can be tested separately
Consider the point of view of final user in addition to the client and engineer (own) point of view
Balance the goals of final user, client, and engineer
Consider the precision and accuracy needs and limitations of the problem and solution
Designing and testing prototypes
Change multiple (all) variables the student thinks may be causative looking for maximum results (Schauble's engineering model)
Apply a situation-specific design scheme. Apply HOTAT (Tshirgi, 1980) method, only on positive results. Apply a VOTAT (CoV) approach to negative results.

en-us: Hold constant one possible causative variable, while changing all others. Determine if it gives good result that the constant entity is the cause.

competencyText.en-us: Apply a VOTAT (Tschirgi) or CoV approach in which the design changes only one potential variable at a time regardless of whether the outcome of previous test was positive or negative
Consider which variables are likely to be causative and then test only those (e.g., stop testing variables that have been shown to have no effect)
Design and test components of the prototype before trying to incorporate all parts together (e.g., Wright brothers' wing tests)
Build and test complete prototype using components tested independently
Compare results of integrated components to how they worked as separate entities to determine if there are advantages or disadvantages when the components work together
Modeling the design process
Make claims based only on overall performance of prototype or model without considering components
Apply causal reasoning for a component without sufficient evidence to make the claim
Apply causal reasoning that is supported appropriately with data but does not clearly link claim and evidence with reasoning
Apply appropriate causal reasoning that is supported by data that links claim and evidence with data-based reasoning given scaffolds
Evaluate and revise a model based on data from testing design. Reiterate process
Apply causal reasoning that is supported appropriately with data that links claim and evidence with reasoning based on both testing data and math/science content given scaffolds
Apply causal reasoning that is supported appropriately with data and links claim and evidence with data based reasoning without scaffolds
Understanding and using constraints
No constraints or limitations are considered when solving problem.
Consider only one constraint of several when using a design process.

en-us: Example would be 'cost only.' If the situation is building a bridge, students consider only whether they have enough money to buy necessary parts.

competencyText.en-us: Consider constraints based on both science concepts and other quantitative criteria such as cost or time needed to complete task
Understand that when dealing with constraints, there are tradeoffs that must be made (e.g., cannot build the strongest possible bridge and meet the constraint of the budget)

en-us: For a bridge building project, the strongest possible bridge cannot be made given the constraint of cost
however, a bridge that meets the requirements of holding the required weight within the cost constraint could be constructed.

competencyText.en-us: Can apply a given rubric to evaluate the tradeoffs necessary based on the constraints of a design problem
Understand that socioscientific constraints involve issues such as ethics, values, etc. as well as quantifiable constraints for which there may not be universally accepted claims or decisions
Apply scientific argument using claim, evidence, and reasoning to design problems that involve socioscientific issues to justify and/or analyze a position on a design challenge
Communicating the design process progression
Understand the design challenge and restate the goal
Accurately record findings that can be analyzed
Display and interpret data in a way that communicates the results of the analysis of a test or prototype
Relate design problem to a big idea" content knowledge piece"
Explain design choices with claim and evidence
Explain design choices with claim, evidence, and reasoning with scaffolds
Explain design choices with claim, evidence, and reasoning (with scaffolds) in a way that is consistent to the audience (client, engineer, final user)
Science disciplinary content progressions covered in K-12 education
Topics in chemistry and physics that involve the properties and interactions of matter and energy
The study of interactions between energy and matter
The study of motion

Learning progression on analyzing motion using kinematics equations to calculate initial, final, and average velocity, position, displacement, distance, and acceleration in both one and two dimensional systems
Can use D=RT relationship
Explanation of velocity as rate of change of distance or position
Calculations using embedded average velocity formula
Explanation that acceleration is the rate of change for velocity
Calculate using vf=vi + a*t
Calculate using d=vit + .5*a*t^2
Can calculate using vf^2 = vi^2 + 2ad
Derivation of relationships either algebraically or graphically
Learning progression on describing motion in both vector and scalar forms using qualitative descriptions, graph analysis, and measurements
Motion described in everyday language
Snapshot view
Relationships with velocity, time, and displacement
Acceleration as the rate of change of velocity (Dynamic view)
Effect on speed when v and a are in the same direction
Effect on speed when v and a are in different directions
Explanations involving zero velocity while accelerating
The study of the motion and equilibrium of systems under the action of forces
Learning progression on understanding and applying Newton's Laws to systems with both balanced (1st Law) and unbalanced (2nd Law) forces
Description of the use of forces
Believe that an object that is not moving has no forces acting on it
Aristotelian or Impetus model (alternate conceptions)
Constant force implies constant velocity (alternate conception)
Unbalanced force rule
Forces can be either contact or distance acting
Force interaction pairs
Implications of no net force
Using Newton's second law
Directionality of a and F
Forces towards a center cause circular orbits
Learning progression on understanding and applying concepts momentum, the quantity of motion, and its conservation to explain and predict what occurs in a system
Basic Understanding of momentum
Understanding momentum in the same direction
Understand momentum in opposite directions
Understanding momentum in two dimensions
Understand momentum in three dimensions
Topics related to law of universal gravitation, Kepler's laws, orbital mechanics, stellar formation, and cosmology
Understanding, explaining, and predicting the properties and transformations of energy as well as its conservation
Learning progression on explaining energy and its transformation,conservation, and degradation
Forms and sources of energy
Transformation and transfer
Degradation
Conservation of energy
Energy devaluation

Understanding, describing, and predicting the properties and behavior of waves in which a physical medium oscillates as longitudinal or transverse waves in response to energy such as water waves, seismic waves, and sound waves

en-us: Water waves, earthquake waves (s and p), sound waves

competencyText.en-us: Learning progression on harmonic motion and waves including simple harmonic motion and mechanical waves.
Relations between heat and mechanical energy or work, and the conversion of one into the other
Learning progression on thermodynamics topics such as heat, work, entropy, and energy conservation.
Understanding how static and moving electric charges interact with each other and magnetic fields to explain, predict, and calculate the results of the interactions
Learning progression on understanding, describing, and predicting the effects of electrical charges moving through closed conducting loops
Components of a circuit
Sink model of circuits
Clashing current model of circuits
Unidirectional current model
Ohmic model of circuits
AC and DC circuits
Field model of circuits
Learning progression on electrostatics foucsing on forces, fields, electric potential (voltage), and electrical potential energy.
Types of electric charges
Interactions between types of charges
Electric fields
Voltage and electric potential energy between static charges
Fields as causal mechanism
Learning progression on magnetism focusing on magnetic forces, magnetic fields, and interactions between electricity and magnetism
Magnetic poles
Interactions between magnetic poles
Domains and magnetic fields
Relationships between electricity and magnetism using hand rules
Field model of electromagnetic induction using Lenz's Law

Understanding, describing, and predicting the properties and behavior of waves in which electric and magnetic fields oscillate, which produce the spectrum of light, both visible and invisible to humans
Learning progression on optics including components of light and geometric optics.
Topics related to fluids, aerodynamics, solid-state physics, and states of matter
A collection of topics including relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, and particle physics
The study of matter, its properties and interactions, and the constituent particles that make up matter
Topics related to the structure and properties of matter as well as how matter interacts in (physical) changes
States of Matter LP
Different states of matter with different characteristics
Understand that solid is different from liquid
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that solid objects are all hard
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all liquids are lighter than solids
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that matter can be felt by the skin
(MISCONCEPTION) Belive that gases do not have mass
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that gases are not matter

en-us: Because they do not believe gases do not have mass, many students believe that gases are no longer matterBerkheimer et al 1990

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that some forms of energy (like heat and light) are matter because you can feel them
Understand that gas is a state of matter

en-us: Students may still believe misconceptions about mass but they will have at least a rote understanding that gas is one state of matterBerkheimer et al 1990

competencyText.en-us: Understand that liquids are different than gases
Understand that gases are different from solids
Understand that solids have a specific shape
Understand that liquids can be poured

en-us: Smith, Wiser, Anderson, and Krajcik, 2011

competencyText.en-us: Understand that liquids change shape to match the container they are placed in
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that the amount of liquid changes when it is poured from one container to another

en-us: This is a Piagetian conservation task that few children at this stage will conserve volume

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that gases do not have a shape because they are not matter
Different states of matter are made of different stuff (Misconception stepping stone)

en-us: "The use of different terms for the different states of matter for water can serve to strengthen this misconception that ice, water, and steam are actually made of different stuff"

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that matter is continuous with no small particles

en-us: Use picture from Chiu and Wu Chiu & Wu(2013)

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that solids are made of solid materials

en-us: https://www.chemedx.org/JCEDLib/QBank/collection/CQandChP/CQs/ConceptsInventory/Concepts_Inventory.html

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that liquids are made of liquid materials
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that gases are made of gas material
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that ice (solid water) is made of different material than liquid water
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that steam(gaseous water) is made of of different material than liquid water
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that changes in state are chemical changes that produce new substances

en-us: Many students believe that boiling water decomposes it into Hydrogen gas and oxygen gas as shown in the Chemical Concept Inventory (Item 6)

competencyText.en-us: Substances can change from one state to another in processes than can be named

en-us: At this level,frequently occurring in upper elementary school or middle school,  students have frequently memorized the names of transitions but generally lack a good understanding of the process. Frequently, misconceptions concerning conservation of matter and chemical changes during transitions persist.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are three normal states of matter
Understand that the solid state of matter is generally found at relatively low temperatures
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that low temperatures for determining if something is a solid or not are negative or feel cold
Understand that the liquid state of matter can be formed from the solid state of matter
Understand that the process of changing from a solid state to a liquid state is called melting
Understand that the change from solid to liquid state occurs at a temperature called the melting point
Understand that a liquid can be changed to a solid at low temperatures
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that the low temperatures that a liquid changes to a solid always feel cold
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all liquids change to solids at 0 degrees Celsius

en-us: Because water is used so frequently as the example of a substance changing state, many students will believe that all substances behave the same as water.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that changing from a liquid to solid state is called freezing
Understand that the change from liquid to solid occurs at a temperature called the freezing point
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that melting point of a substance is higher than the freezing point because liquids occur at higher temperatures
Understand that the gas state of matter is generally found at high temperatures
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that the high temperatures that a liquid changes to a gas always feel hot
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all liquids change to gases at 100 degrees Celsius
Understand that changing from a liquid to gas state is called boiling

en-us: Few students will use the term vaporization, which will generally be added in high school.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that specifically for water boiling involves changing liquid water into gaseous hydrogen and oxygen

en-us: Since water is viewed as a liquid that was made from two gaseous elements, many students believe that turning water into a gas actually  breaks it into its original gaseous element components.  For substances that they are not as certain of their composition, like acetone or ethanol, students are less likely to decompose the substance into its components, possibly because they do not know what they are or possibly because if the substance contains Carbon, students believe that it would be a solid.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the change from liquid to gas state occurs at a temperature called the boiling point
Understand that the process of changing from a gas state to a liquid state is called condensation
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that water that forms on the outside of a cold glass on a hot day traveled through the glass rather than condensed from water vapor in the air
Understand that there is a process that changes a solid directly to a gas state called sublimation

en-us: This is generally only memorized or learned that this is what dry ice (solid carbon dioxide does)

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe dry ice is the only substance sublimes

en-us: Since dry ice is usually the only example that is given for sublimation, some students believe that it is the only substance capable of sublimation

competencyText.en-us: Identify the change in state for a substance based on a description of the changes the substance undergoes
Identify the change in state, if any,  based on beginning and ending temperature and the melting and boiling point of a substance
Describe the changes in the state of matter of a subtance as it is heated or cooled over a range of temperatures given the melting and freezing point
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that when a liquid boils mass decreases because gases have little or no mass
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that when a liquid freezes the mass increases because solids are heavier than liquids
Substances obey conservation laws when undergoing a change in state
Understand that matter has mass in all three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas
Understand that a substance does not undergo a chemical change when a phase change occurs
Understand that when a substance undergoes a phase change no substances are created or destroyed
Understand that when a substance undergoes a phase change no substances are changed into new substances
Understand that when a substance freezes there is no change in mass in a closed system
Understand that when a substance boils there is no change in mass in a closed system
Understand that changes in state are reversible because no mass is gained or lost in a phase change
Predict the mass after a phase change given the mass before the change for a closed system
Understand that in an open system (container) that when a substance boils some of the gas may float away
Understand that evaporation occurs when a liquid changes to a gas at a temperature below its boiling point
Understand that when a liquid evaporates from an open container the mass in the container decreases because some of the substance from the liquid is now in the air
Predict the mass after a phase change for an open system
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that when a gas is involved in a chemical reaction like photosynthesis or cellular respiration it has no mass
Determine if a system was open or closed during a change in state based on the beginnning and ending masses of the contents of the system
Substances are made of tiny particles (transition to KMT LP)

en-us:
This is a stepping stone usually reached in upper middle school or high school in which a particulate model of matter replaces a continuous model of matter (Smith, Wiser, Anderson, & Krajcik, 2011) Research on how students treat these particles as molecules that are different or as all identical pieces of matter are mixed (Berkheimer et al, 1990). 

At this point, moving to the KMT Learning Progression will be the path for many students. The remaining stepping stones and anchor levels are based on a progression that focuses on how students have learned states of matter and transitions as summarized by Chiu and Wu (2013)

competencyText.en-us: The state of matter is dependent on the organization and space between the particles (Transition to KMT LP)

en-us: At this level, usually first seen in upper middle school and more common in high school, students are able to give the definitions of states of matter based on the amounts of organization, movement of particles, and relative amount of space between the particles. They are usually lacking in a causal mechanism that explains why as particles become compressed that they change from gas to liquid to solid states of matter. (Chiu & Wu, 2013)

competencyText.en-us: The causal mechanism for changes in state is the strength of electrical attractions between particles (transition to KMT LP)

en-us: This level is usually limited to high school students. They are able to link electrical interactions at the sub-microscopic scale with their effects at the macro scale.

competencyText.en-us: Dynamic equilibrium model (transition to KMT LP)

en-us: This level is characterized by understanding that transfers in energy are related to changes in state. Additionally, there is an understanding that at the boiling point, freezing point, etc. there is a dynamic equilibrium with particles switching between the states and that the transfer of energy into or out of the substance is necessary to drive the syestem from equilibrium towards a final state in which only one state of matter is likely to be present.

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to atomic and subatomic chemistry, such as theories about atomic structure, quantum mechanics, and components of the atom

Learning progression on matter beginning with a continuous model of matter, moving through a stepping stone particle model. Upper anchor is a conceptual understanding of Schrodinger's sublevels of the atom.
Particle model
Understand that matter is made of tiny particles that are in constant motion
Understand that the tiny particles can be modelled as solid balls
Understand that the tiny particles have mass
Understand that the tiny particles take up space
Understand that the tiny particles are matter because they fit the criteria of having mass and volume
Understand that temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles
Understand that the particles move faster at higher temperature
Understand that the type of motion of the particles is related to the state of matter
Understand that most of the particle movement in solids is vibrating in place
Understand that the particles in liquids move (translational) from one place to another in clumps within the volume of the liquid
Understand that the particles in gases move (translational) in straight lines until they collide with another particle or the wall of the container
Compare and contrast the movement of particles in the 3 standard states of matter
Understand that energy must be added or removed to allow the substance to change state
Understand that changing from a solid to a liquid state is called melting and requires the addition of energy
Understand that changing from a liquid to a solid state is called freezing and requires the removal of energy
Understand that a substance melts or freezes at the same temperature; It is the direction of the flow of energy that determines which process occurs
Determine whether a substance will melt or freeze (if either) given information about the direction that energy is flowing, the temperature, and the melting point of the substance
Understand that changing from a liquid to a gas state is called vaporization and requires the addition of energy
Understand that changing from a gas to a liquid state is called condensation and requires the removal of energy
Understand that a substance vaporizes and condenses at the same temperature: it is the direction of the flow of energy that determines which process occurs
Determine whether a substance will vaporize or condense (if either) given information about the direction that energy is flowing, the temperature, and the boiling point of the substance
Understand that changing from a solid to a gas state is called sublimation and requires the addition of energy
Understand that changing from a gas to a solid state is called deposition and requires the removal of energy
Stability
Understand that phenomena occur so that the final result has the most stability (and the lowest energy)
Understand that particles can be positively charged, negatively charged, or neutral
Understand that particles in a material can attract or repel each other based on electrical charges
Understand that two positively charged particles will exert a force pushing the particles apart from each other as will two negatively charged particles

en-us: Two balloons that are both charged negatively will repel each other. Bits of paper that are positively charged will also repel each other.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a positively charged particle and a negatively charged particle will exert a force that brings the particles closer together
Understand that if particles get very close to each other in a solid, they may begin to repel
Understand that there will be a distance that will have the most stability in which attractive and repulsive forces counteract
Explain the counteracting forces of attraction and repulsion between particles in a substance
Compounds and elements
Understand that the particles in a substance can be either elements or compounds
Understand that an element contains only one kind of atom
Understand that a compound contains two or more kinds of atoms that are held together electrically
Understand that elements follow certain rules when they combine to form compounds
Understand that matter is not created or destroyed when elements combine to form compounds
Understand that in a closed system the total mass of the starting materials will equal the total mass of the ending materials in a chemical reaction
Understand that in an open system it may appear that matter (mass) was destroyed, but in reality it was not measured because matter was able to flow either in or out of system
Determine if an investigation involves an open or closed system
Determine if an investigation is likely to appear to obey the Law of Conservation of Matter
Understand that when elements combine they always combine in simple whole-number ratios of mass
Understand that if two elements can combine in more than one way, all the compounds will have simple mass ratios of the elements involved
Determine if two lab results appear to obey the Law of Definite Proportions
Understand that elements have properties that can be used to identify them
Predictability and the periodic table
Understand that the properties of elements follow predictable patterns
Understand that elements can be classified by their properties
Understand that the atoms of an element are identical to each other but different from the atoms of all other elements

en-us: Dalton's postulates

competencyText.en-us: Understand that metal elements usually have physical properties that include malleability, ductility, high luster, and good conductivity of electricity and heat
Understand that nonmetal elements usually have common physical properties such as brittleness, low luster, and insulation (poor conductivity) of heat and electricity
Understand that metalloid (semimetallic ) elements have a mixture of physical properties but generally are considered semiconductors of electricity
Understand that metal elements usually have chemical properties that include losing electrons easily to form positive particles in reactions
Understand that nonmetal elements usually have common chemical properties that include gaining electrons easily to form negative particles in reactions
Understand that many elements tend to have the same charges in all of their compounds

en-us: In compounds, Calcium has a valence (charge) of +2. However, copper sometimes has a charge of +1 and other times has a charge of +2.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the elements could be grouped together by their chemical and physical properties into groups (families) of elements that share common characteristics
Understand that the properties of elements repeat in regular intervals

en-us: Elements that are highly reactive with water and form basic solutions after they react with water occur every 8, 18, or 32 elements.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the periodic table arranges the elements by their chemical and physical properties
Understand that the properties of elements can be predicted by their position on the periodic table
Predict the properties of an element by using data about other elements in the same family/group

en-us: Mendeleev predicted the properties of undiscovered elements (like ekasilicon/germanium) extremely accurately.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the location on the periodic table can be used to predict whether or not two elements will likely react
Understand that the formula of a binary compound of elements can be predicted from their location on the periodic table
Predict the formula of a compound given two representative elements that include a metal and a nonmetal
Underlying structure as the cause of the predictability
Understand that an underlying structure is necessary to explain the predictability of elemental properties
Understand that the atom is made of smaller particles
Understand that experiments have been done that have given evidence to the existence of particles smaller than individual atoms
Understand that the first particle to be discovered had a very small mass and a negative charge
Understand that the first particle to be discovered could be ejected from the atom by applying an external energy source, whether it was thermal, electrical, or electromagnetic energy
Understand that the negative particle was called the electron
Understand that the second particle to be discovered had a positive charge and a relatively large mass compared to the electron
Understand that the positive particle was called the proton
Understand that the last particle to be discovered had a neutral charge and a mass comparable to that of the proton
Understand that the neutral particle was called the neutron
Compare and contrast the properties of protons, neutrons, and electrons
Understand that, in a stable atom, the number of protons and electrons is equal
Understand that if the number of protons does not equal the number of electrons, the particle will have an electrical charge and be called an ion
Understand that the identity of an atom is determined by the number of protons
Understand that the atomic mass of an atom is equal to the total number of protons and neutrons in the atom
Understand that two atoms of the same element may have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons
Calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons in an atom or ion given the atomic symbol, atomic mass, and electrical charge
Determine the atomic symbol and electrical charge given three of the following: atomic mass, number of protons, number of electrons, and number of neutrons
Determine if two atoms are isotopes of the same element given data about protons, neutrons, and electrons
Models of the atom
Understand that several models of the atom have been developed based on the experimental evidence available at the time
Understand that a scientific model is evaluated by several factors: plausibility, intelligibility, conceptual coherence, fruitfulness, and/or ad hoc-ness""
Understand that the first models of the atom pictured them as a solid particles
Understand that an experiment using a cathode ray tube demonstrated that a small negative particle could be ejected from the atom
Understand that Thomsen theorized a (Plum Pudding) model of the atom that included discrete negative particles (electrons) that moved in a diffuse positive ly charged cloud

en-us: The model had negatively charged particles (electrons) as analogous to the bits of plums found in the pudding. The positively charged cloud was analogous to the custard of the pudding and had a charge equal but opposite the total of the electrons.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Thomsen's model explained the results of the cathode ray experiment

en-us: Most alpha particles (positive particles) pass straight through foil. Some are deflected. Some bounce nearly straight back.

competencyText.en-us: Draw or explain the plum pudding model of the atom

en-us: Most alpha particles (positive particles) pass straight through foil. Some are deflected. Some bounce nearly straight back

competencyText.en-us: Understand the results of Rutherford's gold foil experiment

en-us: Most of the atom is empty (why most pass straight through)
There must be a small concentrated 'nucleus' of positive charge that deflected or completely repelled the positively charged alpha particle.

competencyText.en-us: Understand the conclusions Rutherford drew from his gold foil experiment and the evidence for those conclusions
Understand the planetary model that Rutherford used to explain his experimental findings
Draw or explain Rutherford's planetary model of the atom
