Compare and contrast the Rutherford model of the atom with the Thomsen model of the atom
Understand that light has wave properties such as frequency and wavelength
Understand that the wavelength and frequency of light are inversely related

en-us: Could be presented as c=(lambda)*f
c=(lambda)(nu)
c=l*f

competencyText.en-us: Calculate the wavelength or frequency of light given the other value

en-us: E=h*f

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the energy of a photon of light is proportional to its frequency

en-us: E=h*f

competencyText.en-us: Calculate the energy, wavelength, and frequency given the value of one of the three variables
Understand that when atoms are exposed to energy (heat, light, electricity) they emit only specific frequencies of light
Understand that when atoms are exposed to light, they only absorb specific frequencies of light
Understand that the lines of light in an emission spectrum exactly correspond to the dark lines in an absorption spectrum
Understand that the emission/absorption lines of an element are unique and can be used to identify the presence of an element in a sample
Understand that each line in an absorption or emission spectrum corresponds to a specific amount of energy
Understand that since only a few specific lines are present in the spectrum of a particular element, only specific energy configurations are possible

en-us: The analogy is often stairs: A student can jump from the first step to third step on a flight of stairs, but she cannot be on step 2.5 hovering in midair. She will end up in a stable location on a specific step.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Bohr theorized a model that allowed for electrons to only be in specific energy locations (rings) around the atom
Understand that the Bohr model used the lines of the spectrum of hydrogen as its basis
Understand that the Bohr model of the atom (solar system model) had the nucleus in the center with electrons located in specific rings/levels around the nucleus

en-us: The levels hold 2-8-8-18-18-32-32 electrons in the Bohr model.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in the Bohr model the different levels can hold different numbers of electrons

en-us: Na has 11 electrons, which would have 2 in level 1
8 in level 2
And 1 in level 3.

competencyText.en-us: Assign the correct number of electrons to each level in the Bohr model of the atom
Understand that the outermost level that contains electrons can be used to determine properties of the element
Understand that the number of valence electrons in the Bohr model of an atom can be used to determine to which column on the periodic table the element belongs
Understand that the number of levels of electrons in the Bohr model of the atom can be used to determine to which row (period) on the periodic table the element belongs
Sketch the Bohr model of the atom for any element up to atomic number 56
Understand that the Bohr model of the atom was developed using single electron atoms and ions and does not work to completely explain the experimental spectra of atoms with multiple electrons
Understand that light has some particle properties
Understand that light is said to have two natures, both particle and wave
Understand that wave properties of light include refraction and diffraction
Understand that particle properties of light include the photoelectric effect
Understand that deBroglie's hypothesis is that matter, like light, can have both particle and wave characteristics

en-us: Based on the double slit experiment for electrons: when electrons are shot through a single slit, they behave as particles and produce a single line pattern. However, when they are shot through a double slit, they produce an interference pattern.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that electrons can undergo diffraction
Understand that if electrons can be diffracted, then they must have some wave properties
Understand the deBroglie hypothesis that, like light, all matter has both wave and particle properties
Understand that the waves associated for electrons (and other matter) are probability waves
Understand that Schrodinger's model of the atom explains the atom in terms of orbitals that are defined by where electrons are likely to be found in a probabilistic way

en-us: An orbital in Schrodinger's model is usually defined as the region an electron is found 90% of the time.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Schrodinger's model of the atom found that Bohr's levels could be subdivided into sublevels and orbitals

en-us: So level 1 has 1 sublevel (subshell) called the s. Level 2 has 's' and 'p,' etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the number of sublevels available, but not necessarily used, is equal to the energy level of the atom
Understand that each type of subshell is made of orbitals

en-us: s has 1, p has 3, d has 5, f has 7, g has 9, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that each type of subshell has a specific number of orbitals available
Understand that each orbital can hold up to 2 electrons

en-us: s can hold 2, p can hold 6, d 10, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that each sublevel can hold a specific maximum number of electrons

en-us: http://images.tutorcircle.com/cms/images/44/energy-level-diagram-and-aufbau-principle.png

competencyText.en-us: Understand that electrons will enter the lowest energy orbital available first

en-us: Iron (At

competencyText.en-us: Write out the electron configuration for atoms using the aufbau principle
Understand that when electrons fill into a subshell, one electron is placed in each orbital before any orbital adds a second electron
Understand that the second electron in an orbital must spin in the opposite direction of the first electron to obey the Pauli Exclusion Principle
Draw electron configurations using orbital (line or box) notation
Mathematical models of the atom
Understand that a specific amount of energy are associated with the location of an electron in the atom
Understand that the Rydberg equation is one mathematical model of the energy of electrons in an atom

en-us: E=RH/n2

competencyText.en-us: Understand that, like all models, there are limitations and assumptions to the Rydberg mathematical model
Understand that energy must be added to move an electron from a lower level (n-value) to a higher level
Understand that energy must be released to move an electron from a higher level (n-value) to a lower level
Understand that amount of energy (absolute value) is a function of the initial and final levels
Calculate the amount of energy involved in a given electron transition by using the Rydberg equation
Calculate at what energy level an electron will be located given the amount of energy added or removed from the electron by using the Rydberg equation
Calculate the wavelength and frequency of light that corresponds to an electron transition using the Rydberg equation
Understand the differences between fluorescence and phosphorescence
Topics related to trends, organization, and development of the periodic table
Periodic Table and Periodicity LP
Descriptions of elements
Understand that elements can be classified by their properties
Understand that the atoms of an element are identical to each other but different from the atoms of all other elements

en-us: Dalton's postulates

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the stair case" drawn on the periodic table can be used to classify elements"
Understand that elements to the right and above the stair case are generally called non-metals

en-us: Oxygen, carbon, neon

competencyText.en-us: Understand that elements to the left and below the stair case are generally called metals

en-us: hydrogen, lithium, copper, and iron

competencyText.en-us: Believe that all non-metals are gases and all metals are solids
Understand that elements that are adjacent to the stair case are generally called metalloids

en-us: silicon, arsenic, and gallium

competencyText.en-us: Understand that metal elements usually have physical properties that include malleability, ductility, high luster, and good conductivity of electricity and heat
Understand that nonmetal elements usually have common physical properties such as brittleness, low luster, and insulation (poor conductivity) of heat and electricity
Understand that metalloid (semimetallic ) elements have a mixture of physical properties but generally are considered semiconductors of electricity
Understand that metal elements usually have chemical properties that include losing electrons easily to form positive particles in reactions
Understand that nonmetal elements usually have common chemical properties that include gaining electrons easily to form negative particles in reactions
Understand that many elements tend to have the same charges in all of their compounds

en-us: In compounds, Calcium has a valence (charge) of +2. However, copper sometimes has a charge of +1 and other times has a charge of +2.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some metals (transition metals) have more than one common charge

en-us: Copper is commonly either +1 or +2 in compounds
Iron is usually either +2 or +3 in compounds

competencyText.en-us: Periodicity and families
Understand that the properties of elements repeat in regular intervals

en-us: Elements that are highly reactive with water and form basic solutions after they react with water occur every 8, 18, or 32 elements.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the periodic table arranges the elements by their chemical and physical properties
Understand that the Mendeleev arranged elements in his periodic table by their chemical properties and not atomic mass
Understand that Mendeleev left empty spaces for elements, in known families, that had not yet been discovered

en-us: Mendeleev left a blank location and predicted that there would be an element that he called eka-silicon that would behave like silicon and lead with a mass between the two of them

competencyText.en-us: Believe that the modern table is identical to Mendeleev's table with all new elements in groups that he included
Understand that the properties of elements can be predicted by their position on the periodic table
Predict the properties of an element by using data about other elements in the same family/group

en-us: Mendeleev predicted the properties of undiscovered elements (like ekasilicon/germanium) extremely accurately.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the location on the periodic table can be used to predict whether or not two elements will likely react

en-us: Two metals will not generally react. A metal and a non-metal will frequently react (particularly if given activation energy)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the formula of a binary compound of elements can be predicted from their locations on the periodic table
Predict the formula of a compound given two representative elements that include a metal and a nonmetal
Understand that the elements could be grouped together by their chemical and physical properties into groups (families) of elements that share common characteristics in vertical columns
Understand that column is called the alkali metals and generally have a charge of +1 in compounds
Understand that column 2 are called the alkaline earth metals and generally have a charge of +2 in compounds
Understand that columns 3-12 are called the transition metals and may have a variety of different charges in compounds
Understand that Column 13 generally have a charge of +3 in compounds
Understand that Column 14 generally have a charge of eith +4 or -4 in compounds

en-us: Carbon and silicon (above the steps) generally are -4 and the elemnets below the steps are generally positive (although tin and lead both have a common charge of +2 as well)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Column 16 are called the chalcogens and generally have a charge of -2 in compounds

en-us: Arsenic and antimony may behave as metals, but are not generally used in HS chemistry lab due to safety concerns

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Column 15 generally have a charge of -3 in compounds
Understand that column 17 are called halogens and generally have a charge of -1 in binary compounds
Understand that column is called the Noble gases and are generally chemically inert at normal classroom conditions

en-us: Helium's lack of reactivity is why blimps are now filled with He rather than Hydogen like early dirigibles.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the Periodic Law and Mendeleev's table do not supply an explanatory cause, only an observation of trends

en-us: This is similar to Newton's gravitational law that explained the movement of objects without an explanatory cause (general relativity or gravitons)

competencyText.en-us: Periodic trends and causes
Understand that the cause of the periodic law is the arrangement of electrons into shells and subshells
Understand that the location of an element on the periodic table is related to its number and location of valence electrons
Understand that the maximum number of electrons that a given sub-shell can hold is 2,6,10, and 14 for s,p,d, and f subshells, respectively.

en-us: The s-block is 2 wide
p is 6 wide
d is 10 wide
f is 14 wide
'g' if ever needed due to synthesis of superheavy elements will be 18 blocks wide

competencyText.en-us: Understand that columns 1 and 2 represent the s-block in which atoms valence electrons are in the s-subshell at ground state

en-us: H is 1s1
Li is 2s1, Ca is 4s2

competencyText.en-us: Understand that columns 13 through 18 represent the p-block in which atoms valence electrons are in the p-subshell at ground state
Understand that columns 3 through 12 represent the d-block in which atoms valence electrons are generally in the d-subshell at ground state
Understand that the lanthanide and actinide series at the bottom of the periodic table represent the f-block in which atoms have valence electrons generally in the f-subshell at ground state
Predict the location of the outermost electron in a ground state atom based on its location on the periodic table
Understand that there are exceptions to the rules about valence electrons
Understand that most exceptions occur for elements that should be Ns^2 and (N-1)d^4 or Ns^2 and (N-1)d^9, but are actually Ns^1 (N-1)d^5 or d^10

en-us: Chromium and Copper are good examples

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the cause of the of the d^4 and d^9 exception is that the energy level of the next d level in the aufbau principle rules is actually lower in energy than reversing the spin of the second s-subshell electron
Believe that a half-filled shell has extra stability""
Predict the location of the outermost electron in a ground state atom based on its location on the periodic table for elements that do not obey the aufbau principle in columns 6 and 11
Understand that the common charge of a family in binary compounds is a result of either adding electrons (negative charge) or removing electrons (positive charge)
Understand that the number of electrons that are added or removed is related to having a valence shell with 0 or 8 electrons (rule of octets)
Understand that H and He obey the rule of duets
Understand that the rule of octets is a result of having a full s-subshell and p-subshell in the outer valence shell
Explaining periodic trends
Understand that the greater the number of levels (shells) in the atom, the greater the distance between the nucleus and the valence electrons
Understand that the lower on the periodic table in a family an lement is, the larger it is
Predict the relative sizes of elements in a family/group based on location on the periodic table
Understand that core electrons provide shielding which effectively cancels out some protons in the nucleus

en-us: In Silicon (element 14) there are 10 core electrons which effectively shield approximately 10 of the protons. This leaves 4 protons that will be effectively exerting attractive forces on the four valence electrons

competencyText.en-us: Understand that every non-shielded proton in the nucleus exerts force on every valence electron
Believe that each proton attracts one and only one electron
Understand that the number of protons exerting force on valence electrons is proportional to the total electrical (coulombic)force on the the electrons
Understand that in a given row on the periodic table, smaller radius elements are found to the right and larger radius elements are found to the left
Believe that elements get larger in size moving left to right in a row because they are generally heavier
Predict the relative sizes of elements in a row based on the amount of coulombic forces (main group elements only)

Understand that combining the shell cause and the shielding cause leads to the conclusion that the smallest atoms (by radius) are at the top right of the periodic table and the largest are at the bottom left
Understand that additional shells generally causes a greater change in radius than shiielding effects
Predict the relative sizes of two elements based on their location on the eriodic table
Understand that ionization energy is a measure of how easy it is to remove (ionize) the outermost electron in an atom
Understand that the stronger the attractive force between the nucleus and outermost electron, the more difficult it will be to remove that electron
Understand that electrical forces follow an inverse-square law for distance, so larger atoms have a smaller electrical (coulombic) force holding the outermost electron

en-us: Francium, the largest atom on the periodic table, has a very small coulombic force on its outermost electron. Helium, the smallest atom, has a very large coulombic attraction with its outermost electron.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are exceptions to the size predictions for ionization energy based on quantum mechanics

Understand that column 13 generally have lower ionization energies than column 2 because they are losing a p-subshell electron which is in a higher energy state than the s-subshell electrons of column 2

Understand that column 16 generally have lower ionization energies than the corresponding column 15 elements because they are losing an electron with a reverse spin which makes it a higher energy (and therefore easier to remove) electron
Predict the relative ionization energies of two elements based on their locations on the periodic table
Explain why one element has a lower ionization energy tan another using coulombic and/or quantum mechanics principles
Understand that removing an electron results in an atom with a positive charge because it will have more protons than electrons
Understand that having a net positive charge will increase the force the nucleus exerts on the outermost electron
Understand that the ionization will therefore increase as the charge increases
Understand that the more valence electrons already removed, the larger the increase in ionization energy
Understand that the shell effect will cause a much larger increase when removing a core electron than the effect of removing another valence electron
Understand that the electron removed before the largest multiplicative ince=rease in ionization represents the last valence electron of the atom

en-us: An atom has IE1 = 25
IE5 = 1000. The largest multiplicative increase was at IE4, so the 3rd electron was the last valence electron and the atom belongs in column 13

competencyText.en-us: Predict the number of valence electrons in an atom given a sequence of ionization energies
Predict the chemical family of an leement based on a seires of ionization energies
Understand that a measure of an atoms ability to gain electrons is electronegativity

en-us: EN is generally measured using a relative scale developed by Linus Pauling with F having a value of 4.0

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Noble gases are generally considered to have an electronegativity of zero

en-us: Since noble gases have a full octete, there is no need to add additional electrons

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the larger the electronegativity of an atom, the more likely it is to add electrons
Understand that the electronegativty is related to the electrical (coulombic) forces that the nucleus exerts on valence electrons
Understand that since the amount of force is related to the size of the atom, that electronegativity is also related to the size of the atom
Understand that since smaller atoms exert a larger force on the valence electrons, they are more able to add additional electrons
Understand that smaller atoms have larger electronegativity
Understand that electronegativity is large in the top right (near Fluroine) and low in the bottom left (near Francium) of the periodic table
Predict the relative electronegativities of two atoms
Understand that electron affinity measures the change in energy when an additional electron is added to its valence shell

en-us: These are generally negative for non-metals and positive for metals (or noble gases)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that since electron affinity is another way to measure the same process as electronegativity that both measurements have similar trends with similar causes
Predict the relative electron affinties of two atoms
Explain the differences in the relative electronegativity or electron affinity for two atoms based on coulombic forces and size
Understand that adding an electron will cause the atom to have a negative charge which will make it increase in relative size
Predict the relative sizes of two atoms or ions
Predict whetehr or not a bond is likely to form between two atoms given a table of electon affinities and ionization ernergies
Understand that electron affinity and ionization can be added together to predict whether or not a bond may form between two atoms

en-us: If the total is negative, the formation of a bond is favored from a Hess' Law standpoint for example between chlorine and lithium

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to the kinetic molecular theory (KMT) and Gas Laws
A learning progression for kinetic molecular theory
Continuous model of matter
Understand that matter has mass and takes up space
Determine if something is matter or is not matter
Matter can be broken down to smaller pieces.
Understand that a piece of matter can be broken down into smaller pieces
Understand that the smaller pieces that can be found when breaking down an object were already present in the original object
Matter has mass and volume even when it cannot be observed directly by the senses.
Understand that objects can have weight too small to be felt by the sense of touch
Understand that objects can be too small to be seen with normal vision
Understand that some things that are too light to feel by touch can be weighed using very sensitive balances/scales
Understand that some things that are too small to be seen with normal vision can be seen using microscopes
Understand that matter can be described as having three normal states of matter
Understand that solids have specific traits

en-us: Definite shape and volume

competencyText.en-us: Understand that liquids have specific traits

en-us: Definite volume, shape conforms to containers

competencyText.en-us: Understand that gases have specific traits

en-us: Volume and shape conform to container

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a substance can change from one state of matter to another
Understand that the changes in the state of matter are caused by adding energy (heat) to or from a substance
Matter is made of very small particles with spaces between.
Understand that matter is made of very small particles
Understand that there are spaces between the particles
Understand that the amount of space between particles varies by state of matter
Understand that the attractions between particles are directly related to how close the particles are to each other

en-us: The closer the particles, the stronger the attraction is.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that solids have many relatively strong attractions between the particles
Understand that liquids have some moderately strong attractions between the particles
Understand that gases have no attractions between the particles
Understand that the energy needed to change from one state of matter to another is related to the strength of attractions that are being formed or broken
Determine if the strength of attractions is increasing or decreasing for a given phase change
The particles in matter are constantly moving.
Understand that particles in matter are always moving
Understand that temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles in an object
Understand that although temperature is the average kinetic energy of the particles in an object, some particles will have more KE and move faster and some particles will have less KE and move slower
Understand that for a given object as temperature increases the average speed of the molecules increases
Understand that how the particles in an object move is determined by the state of matter

en-us: Solids: the particles vibrate in place
Liquids: The particles tend to move in large clumps (translation)
Gases move in translational motion between collisions

competencyText.en-us: Understand that, when heated through a phase change, the particles in an object change how they move
Understand that as a substance changes state from solid, liquid, or gas, the particles remain the same size

en-us: There is no change in the particles themselves as the phase changes occur. It is the relative spacing and attractive forces between the particles that change.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the distance between the particles increases during a phase change from solid to liquid, solid to gas, or liquid to gas
Understand that the distance between the particles decreases during a phase change from gas to liquid, gas to solid, or liquid to solid
Kinetic molecular theory
Understand that the particles in a gas act like tiny balls that fly around at high speeds
Understand that the volume, pressure, temperature, and number of particles in a gas are related to each other in predictable ways that follow some basic principles
Understand that pressure in a gas is caused by the force of the particles striking the walls of the container
Understand that if particles strike the walls of the container more often, then the pressure will increase
Understand that if the particles strike the walls of the container at a higher speed, then the pressure will increase
Understand that kinetic energy is equal to .5*m*v2
Understand that at the same temperature (same KE), the heavier particle will have a lower average speed
Understand that all particles in a gas behave the same way even if they are different kinds of particles

en-us: Whether a balloon is filled with CO2, He, N2, or any other type of molecule/atom, the principles of KMT apply equally.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that, in a gas, there are no attractions or repulsions between particles
Understand that the particles in a gas fly in straight lines between collisions with other particles or the wall of the container
Understand that when the particles in a gas collide, the collisions are elastic

en-us: Elastic collisions involve no loss of KE to other forms of energy such as heat or sound, but KE is transferred from one particle to the other.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the volume of a gas is a measure of the space that the particles move in because the particles are so small that the volume of the particles is negligible

en-us: The finite volume of the particles is so small compared to the volume that they move in that under most conditions (ideal gas law) it can be ignored.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the distance between the walls of the container will have an inverse relationship to the number of collisions between the particles and the walls

en-us: As the walls of a container get closer together (the volume decreases), the distance needed to travel decreases
This decreases the time needed to travel between walls, and the number of collisions increase.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if volume increases while temperature is held constant for a sealed container, the pressure will decrease
Predict the change in pressure caused by a change in volume or a component of volume (length, width, or height) of the container
Predict the change in volume caused by a change in pressure
Explain the changes in volume and pressure when one variable is changed using a particle model and the KMT, assuming temperature and number of particles are held constant
Understand that as temperature increases in a gas, the molecules will move faster on average between collisions

Understand that if gas particles move faster between collisions, then it will take less time, on average, for a particle to travel from one container wall to another container wall, so more collisions occur and an increase in pressure
Understand that if the number of collisions increases when the temperature increases, the pressure will increase
Understand that if the temperature decreases, the particles will slow down, resulting in fewer collisions and therefore a lower pressure
Predict the change in pressure caused by a change in temperature
Predict the change in temperature caused by a change in pressure

en-us: When using a can of compressed air to clean a computer/keyboard, as the pressure inside the can drops, the can gets cold (as P decreases, the T decreases).

competencyText.en-us: Explain the changes in temperature and pressure when one variable is changed using a particle model and the KMT, assuming that volume and number of particles are held constant
Understand that as temperature increases in a gas, the molecules will move at higher speeds, which will result in a larger volume required for the gas to move

en-us: Assumes that pressure and number of particles is held constant

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if gas particles slow down because of a decrease in temperature, they will require less space to move and volume will decrease

en-us: A balloon taken outside on a cold day will deflate as the particles slow down. If the balloon is then taken back inside and allowed to warm up, the balloon will increase in volume.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the change in volume caused by a change in temperature
Predict the change in temperature caused by a change in volume
Understand that since temperature and volume are directly related, the graph of T vs. V can be used to predict the value of absolute zero, when all motion would stop
Understand that since gases liquefy before they reach absolute zero, the intercept of the graph is found by extending the graph line beyond the liquefaction towards the origin
Understand that all gases create lines that intersect at the same point, which is absolute zero (0 K)

en-us: http://wiki.chemprime.chemeddl.org/images/f/ff/Thermodynamic_Temperature.jpg

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if more particles are placed in a container, then the particles will need more space to move in

en-us: Assumes pressure and temperature are held constant

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if there are more particles in a container, they will collide with the walls of the container more often, thus pushing the walls outward until the collisions on the inside equal the collisions on the outside
Understand that, at the same temperature and pressure, equal volumes of gas will always contain the same number of particles, regardless of type of particle

en-us: This is Avogadro's Law.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the change in volume caused by a change in the number of gas particles in a container

en-us: Number of particles will be measured in moles.

competencyText.en-us: Explain the changes in volume and number of particles, when one variable is changed using a particle model and the KMT, assuming that temperature and pressure are held constant
Predict the changes in pressure, volume, temperature, or number of particles when one variable is manipulated and the other two variables are held constant
Explain the changes in pressure, volume, temperature, or number of particles when one variable is manipulated and the other two variables are held constant, using a particle model and the KMT
Mathematics of the KMT
Understand that the relation for P & V can be expressed as the equation P1V1 = P2V2

en-us: This is known as Boyle's law and produces a hyperbolic graph of P vs. V when moles and temperature are held constant.

competencyText.en-us: Apply Boyle's law to solve for pressure or volume
Understand that the relation for pressure and temperature can be expressed as the equation

en-us: This is known as Charles' Law and produces a linear graph of V vs. T when moles and pressure are held constant.

competencyText.en-us: Apply Gay-Lussac's law to solve for temperature or pressure

en-us: Assumes volume and number of particles constant

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the relation for temperature and volume can be expressed as the equation
Apply Charles's Law to solve for temperature or volume
Understand that Avogadro's law can be expressed as the equation
Apply Avogadro's Law to solve for volume or number of particles
Understand that if only the number of particles is held constant, the Combined Gas Law can be used
Apply the Combined Gas Law to solve for pressure, volume, or temperature when a gas changes conditions
Understand that gases obey the Ideal Gas Law, PV=nRT

en-us: R=0.0821 L*atm/(mol K) in SI units

competencyText.en-us: Apply the Ideal Gas Law to solve for temperature, volume, pressure, or amount of particles
Limitations of the KMT
Understand that the assumptions of the KMT are not true for all conditions
Understand that, at relatively low temperatures, the particles move slowly enough that they can experience attractions or repulsions
Understand that relatively low temperature would refer to a temperature close to the boiling point of the gas in question
Understand that, for air, the only major component at a temperature relatively low compared to its boiling point at room temperature is water vapor

en-us: N2, CO2, Ar, He, O2, etc. all behave ideally at room temperature.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the particles at high pressures are packed so closely that there will be attractions between the particles in the gas
Understand that at low temperature and high pressure, the substance may begin to act like a liquid and liquefy
Understand that at low temperature and high pressures, the volume of the particles may become noticeable as the substance exhibits more liquid behaviors

en-us: Under these conditions, the real gas law (Van Der Waal equation) may be used.

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to crystal structure, bonding, and molecular geometry
Leaning progression on understanding and modeling through drawing electron dot structures

en-us: How atoms share or transfer electrons to increase stability as well as the impact that these have on the properties of the substance such as molecular shape, boiling point, and solubility
Balancing
Classifying
Predicting chemical reactions

competencyText.en-us: Building Blocks
Understand that matter is made of small particles that cannot be seen
Understand that there is empty space between the particles
Understand that the particles may be molecules
Understand that molecules are made of two or more atoms combined together
Understand that the atoms that make up molecules are made of smaller parts

en-us: Protons, neutrons, and electrons

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the electrons are arranged around the atom in specific, predictable ways
Understand that the Bohr model predicts how many electrons will be located in each level

en-us: Level 1 has 2 electrons, Levels 2 & 3 have 8 electrons, Levels 4 & 5 have 18 electrons

competencyText.en-us: Predict how many electrons are in each level of a given atom using the Bohr model
Understand that the electrons in the outermost level are able to interact with other atoms
Understand that electrons in interior levels are not usually able to interact with other atoms
Understand that the units digit of the column number (1-18) on the periodical table is equal to the number of valence electrons for main group elements

en-us: Main group, transition metal, inner-transition metal, actinides, lanthanides

competencyText.en-us: Stable configurations
Understand that matter naturally arranges to the lowest energy and most stable configuration

en-us: A ball rolls down a hill because it has less potential energy at bottom of hill (transfers energy to environment as heat and sound)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that electrons in the outermost shell arrange themselves as far away from each other as possible to conform with quantum theory
Understand that some arrangements of valence electrons are more stable than others

en-us: Having 8 valence electrons (octet) for most atoms, a pair of electrons (duet) for hydrogen and helium

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the high amount of energy required to remove an electron from a noble gas is evidence that a full outer shell is more stable
Predict whether an atom is more likely to add electrons, remove electrons, or maintain the current number of electrons to maximize stability

en-us: Rule of octets and duets

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms that tend to gain electrons to increase stability are nonmetals
Understand that atoms that tend to lose electrons to increase stability are metals
Bonding principles
Understand that atoms can transfer or share electrons to form bonds
Understand that bonds that form increase the stability of the atoms involved
Understand that if one atom transfers one or more electrons to a different atom, then an ionic bond occurred
Understand that if one atom shares one or more electrons with another atom, then a covalent bond occurred
Understand that electronegativity is a measure of how likely an atom is to add electrons

en-us: Pauling Electronegativity table

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the difference between the electronegativities of two atoms in a bond is used to predict the type of bond between the atoms

en-us: One example of a classification system is that if the electronegativity difference between the atoms is less than 1.6, the bond is considered covalent. While atoms with a difference greater than 1.6 are considered to form ionic bonds.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the type of bond between two atoms given a table of electronegativities
Understand that the type of bond between two atoms may determine many of the observable properties of the compound

en-us: Ionic compounds have very high melting points and conduct electricity in molten or dissolved form but not in solid form.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that two metal atoms may form a metallic bond which is not predicted strictly using differences in electronegativity
Understand that substances that have metallic bond have characteristic properties that can be used to identify the substance

en-us: Metallically bonded solids conduct both electricity and heat. They are malleable and ductile.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the type of bonding involved in a substance based on characteristic properties such as conductivity, malleability, etc.
Understand that atoms with 3 or fewer valence electrons are likely to lose electrons and form ionic bonds with high electronegativity atoms to increase stability
Understand that atoms with 5 or more valence electrons will usually add enough electrons to get to 8 valence electrons
Understand that atoms with 4 valence electrons could either gain or lose 4 electrons to achieve a stable configuration which obeys the octet rule

Understand that the number of electrons that an atom needs to gain or lose to achieve a stable configuration (octet) explains patterns in common oxidation states (charges) of atoms on the periodic table

en-us: Column 1 = +1
col 2=+2
col 14 is +/- 4
col 15 is -3
And col 18 are generally chemically inert

competencyText.en-us: Predict the oxidation number (charge) of an atom based on its location on the periodic table
Lewis dot structures
Understand that Lewis dot structures are simplified models of electron locations in atoms or molecules

en-us: Lewis dots and electron dots are synonymous.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the dots in Lewis dot structures represent valence electrons
Understand that one electron dot is drawn on each side of the elements symbol before doubling up because of Hund's rule
Understand that no more than 2 electron dots should be drawn on any given side of the atomic symbol because of the Pauli exclusion principle
Understand that the Lewis dot structure of a covalent bond will show 2 electron dots between the two atoms for a single bond
Understand that, in ionic structures, arrows are drawn to model the transfer of electrons from the metallic atom to the nonmetallic atom
Understand that after the arrows have been drawn in ionic structures, the charge (oxidation number) should be written next to the atom involved

en-us: Metals end with a positive charge equal to the number of electrons transferred out. Nonmetals will have a negative charge with the same absolute value as the number of arrows going into the atom symbol.

competencyText.en-us: Draw the Lewis dot structure of binary ionic compounds showing arrows and final charges

en-us: Best to start with compounds that have one of the elements as a single atom (like MgCl2, Na2S, MgO) and then work up to more complicated structures like Al2O3.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that although difference in electronegativity is generally used to determine the type of bond, atoms with 3 or fewer valence electrons are often drawn as ionic in Lewis dot structures for convenience

en-us: This is mainly a problem with boron, since other elements with 3 or fewer valence electrons all have EN that are less than 2.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms may form a single covalent bond with one pair of electrons shared between them

en-us: F-F, the bonds in CCl4

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms may form a double covalent bond with 2 pairs of electrons shared between them

en-us: O=O, the bonds in CO2 or SiS2

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms can form a triple bond covalent bond with 3 pairs of electrons shared between them

en-us: N=N or the CN bond in H-C=N

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms CANNOT form quadruple covalent bonds because of both electrostatic and structural limitations
Understand that one way to determine how main group atoms will bond is to look at how many electrons each atom involved needs to gain to get to a stable configuration

en-us: H has one VE and needs 1 more to become stable (rule of duets), so it will generally form one bond. Oxygen has 6, needs 2 to get to a stable octet, so it will generally form 2 bonds.

competencyText.en-us: Draw the Lewis dot structure of binary compounds of main group nonmetals that involve only single bonds

en-us: H2S, CCl4, PCl3

competencyText.en-us: Draw the Lewis dot structure of binary compounds of main group nonmetals that involve double bonds

en-us: O2, SO, CS2, SiS2

competencyText.en-us: Draw the Lewis dot structures of binary compounds of main group nonmetals that involve triple bonds

en-us: N2, NP, AsP

competencyText.en-us: Identify the central atom, the number of ligands, and the number of lone (nonbonding) pairs of electrons on the central atom
Write the AXE notation for a Lewis dot structure of a molecule

en-us: X refers to the number of ligands. E refers to the number of lone electron pairs on the central atom.

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate whether a given Lewis dot structure for a molecule with 3 or more different kinds of atoms is plausible given the rule of octets

en-us: CHCl3. This could even be applied to organic molecules that are larger.

competencyText.en-us: Lewis dot structures of polyatomic ions
Understand that for polyatomic cations, the central atom loses electrons to equal the net charge of the ion

en-us: NH4 +1, the N atom loses 1 electron so that it only has 4 valence electrons rather than 5.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that for polyatomic anions, the central atom (usually written first) gains electrons to equal the net charge

en-us: OH -1, the oxygen atom gains an electron so that it has 7 valence electrons rather than the normal 6.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that after adjusting the number of electrons on the central atom, the Lewis dot structure of the polyatomic ion will still tend to obey the octet rules
Understand that a coordinate covalent bond occurs when the ligand donates no electron to the bond when the central atom already has 8 valence electrons

en-us: This is commonly referred to as a 'mooch' bond, using the vernacular of a student who benefits but does not contribute to the group.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the most common ligand to form coordinate covalent bonds is oxygen

en-us: This simplification when applied to main group bonding is appropriate for introductory chemistry.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the ligand arranges its six electrons in other orbitals and presents an empty orbital to a lone pair on the central atom to form the bond

en-us: Although this seems to violate Hund's rule, it does explain the properties of the bonds (and the overall geometry later).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that additional coordinate covalently bonded ligands (usually oxygen) can be added until the number and kind of atoms in the Lewis dot structure match the formula of the molecule or ion

en-us: In ClO-1 (hypochlorite ion), only one oxygen forms a coordinate covalent bond, but in ClO3-1, chlorate ion, there are 3 coordinated covalent bond oxygen to match the formula.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if there are additional oxygen atoms in the formula after forming bonds that account for the octet of the central and ligands,, they will likely form coordinate covalent bonds

en-us: CO3-2, carbonate ion would be an example. The first oxygen would form a double bond with the carbon atom (with 6 electrons because of the ionic charge). The remaining two oxygen atoms would form Co-ordinate covalent bonds.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when all lone pairs on the central atom have been used in the Lewis dot structure, no more coordinate covalent bonds can form

en-us: This explains why CO3-2 exists but CO4-2 does not
Also, why the halogenated oxyanions can have 4 oxygen ligands as in perchlorate, periodate, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Draw the Lewis dot structure for a polyatomic ion that does not require coordinate covalent bonds
Draw the Lewis dot structure for a polyatomic ion that does require coordinate covalent bonds
Draw the Lewis dot structure for a molecule that requires coordinate covalent bonds

en-us: SO2, SO3

competencyText.en-us: Assign the AXE notation for the Lewis dot structure of a polyatomic ion
Bonds not as simple as first presented
Understand that electrons are in constant motion
Understand that scientific explanations must match empirical (laboratory) findings
Understand that the energy in a bond is correlated to the strength of the bond
Understand that bonds that are more exothermic to form (or endothermic to break) are stronger
Understand that bonds formed from an s-orbital should be different than those formed by a p-orbital because they have different shapes and energy
Understand that elements like carbon have one s-orbital and 3 p-orbitals in their valence shell available for bonding
Understand that in a molecule like CH4, given atomic theory, 3 bonds should be the same because they came from p-orbitals, and the other bond should be different because it came from an s-orbital
Understand that in the lab, all four bonds in a CH4 molecule have equal bond energy and therefore equal strength
Understand that this evidence contradicts using atomic theory for bonding
Understand that an alternative hypothesis is necessary to explain the bond energy findings
Understand that a hybridization theory suggests that the atomic orbitals of the bonded are mixed (hybridized) to create equivalent bonding orbitals
Understand that the hybrid orbitals would have a shape and size based on a combination of the orbitals
Understand that the number of bonding zones and therefore the number of required equivalent orbitals can be found by adding X and E from the AXE notation
Predict the number of bonding zones given the AXE notation of an atom in a Lewis dot structure
Predict the number of bonding zones given the formula of an ion or molecule that obeys the octet rule

en-us: Or duet rule

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if there is only one bonding zone (BZ), then the atom would use an unhybridized s-orbital
Understand that if BZ=2, then the atom will use a pair of sp-hybrid orbitals
Understand that if BZ=3, then the atom will use a trio of sp2-hybrid orbitals
Understand that if BZ=4, then the atom will use a quartet of sp3-hybrid orbitals
Predict the hybridization of an atom given the AXE notation of the atom in a Lewis dot structure
Predict the hybridization of an atom given the formula of an ion or molecule that obeys the octet rule
Understand that the first bond formed between two atoms is called a sigma bond
Understand that sigma bonds involve end-over-end overlap of the hybrid orbitals of the atoms involved in the bond
Understand that the second and third bonds formed between two atoms are called pi bonds
Understand that pi bonds involve side-by-side overlap of unhybridized orbitals
Given a Lewis dot structure of a molecule or polyatomic ion, determine the number of sigma and pi bonds in the structure
Understand that the strength of a single bond, a double bond, and a triple bond should be different
Understand that a single bond between two atoms is weaker than a double bond between two atoms

en-us: The triple bond cannot cause one of the atoms to violate the octet rule.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a double bond between two atoms is weaker than a triple bond between atoms

en-us: The double bond cannot cause one of the atoms to violate the octet rule.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in a molecule or ion that contains both double bonds and single bonds between the atoms, the double bond should be stronger (more energy) than the single bond.
Understand that, in the lab, the bond energy for both bonds in molecules that have a double-bonded oxygen and a single-bonded oxygen (coordinate covalent bond) are the same energy and strength

en-us: Ex. SO2, SO3, NO2-1

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the bond energy data does not match the theory for these molecules and ions that involve double-bonded and coordinate covalent-bonded oxygen ligands
Understand that an alternative explanation is needed to explain the data for these molecules and ions that involve double-bonded and coordinate covalent-bonded oxygen ligands
Understand that resonance theory explains that the double bond moves from ligand to ligand

Understand that some of the time the first ligand has the double bond, and some of the time the second ligand has the double bond, and some of the time the third ligand, if present, has the double bond
Draw all possible resonance structures for a molecule or ion that includes ligand with a double bond and one or more ligands with coordinate covalent bonds
Understand that bond energy for each of the ligands will be the same and have a value that is stronger than the single bond but weaker than the double bond
Understand that the bond order can be calculated by (total number of bonds between central atom and its ligand)/(number of ligands attached to central atom)

en-us: Using local central atom for a complicated Lewis dot structure

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the higher the bond order, the stronger (higher energy) and shorter the bond
Predict the bond order given a Lewis dot structure
Predict the bond order of a molecule or ion that obeys the octet rule

en-us: Or duet rule

competencyText.en-us: Predict the relative strength and length of bonds of two or more molecules given the Lewis dot structure
Predict the relative strength and length of bonds for a molecule or ion that obeys the octet rule

en-us: Or duet rule

competencyText.en-us: Octet rule has exceptions (optional level)
Understand that many rules have exceptions

en-us: I before E except after C""

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when rules have exceptions, there are often rules for the exceptions

en-us: Except after C or when sounding long A as in neighbor or weigh""

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are molecules and ions that appear to violate the octet rule
Understand that an sp3 hybrid only allows for 8 total electrons around the central atom
Understand that the next available lowest-energy orbital would be a d-orbital in the same shell as the valence electrons
Understand that the central atom must be in row 3 or lower on the periodic table to have available d-orbitals to exceed the octet rule

en-us: Phosphorous and sulfur (row 3) can violate the octet rule but oxygen and nitrogen (row 2) cannot.

competencyText.en-us: Determine whether or not an atom could exceed the octet rule based on its location on the periodic table

en-us: Limit to p-block elements

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the ligand should be halogen forming a single bond with the central atom
Understand that the ligands will first bond with single electrons, then split a lone pair by having two ligands attach, one to each electron.

en-us: SF4: sulfur has 6 valence electrons arranged around the atom in 2 pairs and 2 single electrons. First the single electrons form bonds, then the other two flourine atoms bond to both electrons in the same pair. This leaves an AX4E1 arrangement.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if a single electron is left over, the Lewis dot structure will not represent a stable molecule or ion

en-us: SF4 exists, as does SF6, but SF5 is not stable and does not exist as a stable molecule.

competencyText.en-us: Draw a Lewis dot structure for a molecule that exceeds the octet rule
Determine the AXE notation for a molecule or ion that exceeds the octet rule
Understand that if BZ=5, then the hybridization is sp3d
Understand that if BZ=6, then the hybridization is sp3d2
Determine the hybridization for a molecule or ion that exceeds the octet rule
VSEPR Model of Shapes
Understand that valence electron pairs have negative charge and therefore repel each other
Understand that the smaller the distance between pairs of electrons, the greater the repulsion between the pairs

en-us: Understanding Coulomb's law as an inverse square law may help in this understanding.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the natural tendency is to minimize energy (repulsions) and to maximize stability

en-us: This is an application of Gibbs Free Energy and perhaps can be addressed as such or as the natural state of the universe.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a specific arrangement will minimize the repulsions if all the electron pairs (ligands) are as far apart as possible
Understand that if all the ligands are identical, they should repel equally
Understand that ligands will arrange themselves such that they are as far away from each other as possible in 3-dimensional space
Understand that if BZ=2, the furthest arrangement would be a linear at a 180 degree angle

en-us: CO2 (AX2E0)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if BZ=3, then the most stable shape will be a trigonal planar arrangement at 120 degrees apart in a plane

en-us: BF3, SO3

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if BZ=4, then the most stable shape will be a 3-D tetrahedron with the ligands at the corner and the central atom at the center of the tetrahedron (109.5 degrees)

en-us: CH4, SiCl4

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if BZ=5, then the most stable configuration is trigonal bipyramid with 3 ligands on the equator (120 degrees) and two ligands at the poles so that there are fewer 90 degree interactions

en-us: PF5, PCl5

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if BZ=6, then the most stable shape is an octahedron with the ligands at the corners and the central atom in the center

en-us: SF6

competencyText.en-us: Determine the shape of a molecule or ion that does not contain lone pairs

en-us: (AXE notation with E=0)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Gillespie shapes based on VSEPR match the lab findings of crystals
Understand that Gillespie shapes (VSEPR Theory) is plausible, consistent with other science theories, testable, and does not require adhoc assumptions
Understand that lone pairs on the central atom act as a more concentrated charge and are more repulsive than bonding pairs of electrons
Understand that since LP are more repulsive than bonding pairs, they distort the actual shape of the molecule
Understand that a complete list of shapes can be generated based on distortions of the original stable Gillespie shapes for molecules and ions with BZ from 2 to 6

en-us: An example can be found here http://tinyurl.com/ln6lyz5

competencyText.en-us: Use a table of Gillespie shapes to identify the actual shape of a molecule or ion and the general shape of its bonding zones given its AXE notation
Use a table of Gillespie shapes to identify the actual shape of a molecule or ion and the general shape of its bonding zones given its Lewis dot structure

Use a table of Gillespie shapes to identify the actual shape of a molecule or ion and the general shape of its bonding zones given its formula by first drawing its Lewis dot structure and determining its AXE notation
Polarity of molecules and ions
Understand that if a substance is polar, it has positive and negative ends as a whole
Understand that something is nonpolar if it has no discernible charged ends as a whole
Understand that if a substance is polar, it will usually dissolve in polar solvents

en-us: Like dissolves like""

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if a substance is nonpolar, it will usually dissolve in nonpolar solvents

en-us: Like dissolves like""

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if a substance is nonpolar, it will not dissolve in a polar solvent
Understand that if a substance is polar, it will not dissolve in a nonpolar solvent
Understand that water is considered the universal polar solvent
Understand that polyatomic ions are treated as polar and generally dissolve in water
Understand that for molecular substances with covalent bonds, the overall polarity is determined by the shape of the molecule
Understand that if molecule is symmetrical, the polarity of individual bonds will be canceled by geometry and the molecule as a whole will be nonpolar

en-us: Carbon dioxide is a good example. Although the individual C=O bonds show polarity (the oxygen is far more electronegative), the 180-degree arrangement cancels out the forces.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the molecule is asymmetrical, the polarity of the bonds will not be canceled through geometry and the molecule is polar

en-us: Water with ligands at approximately 105 degrees is polar.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all Gillespie shapes with no lone pairs ( E=0) will be nonpolar because they are always symmetrical
Understand that most Gillespie shapes with lone pairs (E greater than zero) are not symmetrical and are therefore polar but geometry dictates

en-us: AX2E3 linear and AX4E2 square planar are both nonpolar.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the ligands are not identical, then the geometry may not cancel out the polarity of the bonds

en-us: Example: CH4 is nonpolar but CH3Cl is slightly polar, CH2Cl2 is more polar.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if a given molecule is polar or nonpolar given its AXE notation and a chart of Gillespie shapes
Determine if a given molecule is polar or nonpolar given its Lewis dot structure (to determine AXE notation) and a chart of Gillespie shapes
Determine if a given molecule is polar or nonpolar given its name or formula and a chart of Gillespie shapes so that its Lewis dot structure and AXE notation can be determined and applied
Determine if a given molecule is likely soluble in water by determining if it is polar or nonpolar
Determine if a given molecule is likely to dissolve in a common nonpolar solvent (like carbon tetrachloride or hexane) by determining if it is polar or nonpolar
The study of how substances interact to form new substances: Chemical reactions obey the laws of conservation of matter, energy, and electric charge.

Learning progression for chemical reactions from an initial state of identifying parts of a reaction towards an upper anchor of describing the relative amounts of product and reactant as a function of thermodynamic phenomena.
Chemical reactions rearrange matter to form new substances
Understand that matter can be classified as mixtures or substances
Understand that substances can be identified by specific properties that are not dependent on the amount of substance

en-us: Density, melting point, boiling point

competencyText.en-us: Understand that mixtures can have different properties as a result of different relative amounts of the substances involved

en-us: A 20% alcohol solution does not begin to boil at the same temperature as a 75% alcohol solution.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if two materials could be made of the same substance by comparing intensive properties

en-us: Compare the melting points and color of two materials
If they are the same, then they could be made of the same material. If these properties differ, they could not be the same pure substance.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the properties of a substance are different after a change, it changed into a new substance
Understand that the starting materials in a chemical reaction are called reactants
Understand that the ending materials in a chemical reaction are called products
Understand that reactant substances are changed into new substances called products in a chemical reaction (chemical change)
Identify the reactants and/or products in a chemical reaction
Understand that matter is conserved in a chemical change

en-us: Total mass of reactants equals the total mass of products.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that atoms are conserved in a chemical reaction

en-us: The same number of each kind of atom must be present on both sides of a chemical equation.

competencyText.en-us: Balance a chemical reaction by applying the Law of Conservation of Matter
Determine if a chemical reaction occurred by determining if new substances formed
Chemical reactions rearrange matter so that the products are more stable under current conditions.
Understand that compounds form when bonds are formed between two atoms
Understand that forming bonds increases the stability of the atoms involved
Understand that bonds between different kinds of atoms can have different strengths
Understand that the stronger the bonds are in a compound, the more stable that compound will be
Understand that reactions (or any other change) occur when the products (final state) are more stable than the reactants (beginning state) at current conditions

en-us: At room temp, liquid water is more stable than solid water (ice), so it is inevitable (although not instantaneous) that the change of melting would occur.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some reactions, while theoretically possible, do not occur because the products are not stable at current conditions
Understand that many chemical reactions can be reversed by changing the conditions so that the original reactants are more stable at the new conditions than the products were
Predict whether or not a chemical reaction will take place given the relative stabilities of the reactants and products
Chemical reactions can be predicted and explained
Understand that reactants can be classified as elements or compounds
Classify reactants as either an element or a compound
Understand that compounds can be classified as organic (carbon based) or inorganic (lacking carbon)

en-us: Methane (CH4) is organic
Sodium chloride (NaCl) is inorganic.

competencyText.en-us: Classify a compound as organic or inorganic

en-us: Limit the exceptions to the starting-with-C rule to CO and CO2 as inorganic.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that reactions of inorganic substances can be classified into several categories
Understand that when two or more reactants combine to form one product, it is classified as a synthesis reaction

en-us: Magnesium + oxygen yields magnesium oxide

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a reaction of two elements, one metallic and one nonmetallic, to yield a compound can be classified as a synthesis reaction and a single ionic compound product can be predicted

en-us: Magnesium + oxygen yields magnesium oxide

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when one reactant breaks down into two or more products, it can be classified as a decomposition reaction
Understand that many decomposition reactions break compounds completely into elements

en-us: Electrolysis of water

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some decomposition reactions break compounds into smaller compounds

en-us: Heating a carbonate to yield a metal oxide and CO2
As in heating baking powder (Na2CO3) to produce Na2O and CO2 in baking

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a reaction of a compound and an element to form a different compound and a different element is a single replacement reaction

en-us: Mg + 2 HCl --> H2 (gas) + MgCl2

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in a single replacement reaction, the free-standing element will replace the element that is most similar to itself

en-us: Mg is a metal so it replaces the metallic hydrogen atom.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a reaction between two inorganic compounds will result in a double replacement reaction, which forms two different compounds

en-us: Sodium chloride plus silver nitrate will yield sodium nitrate and silver chloride.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are other ways to classify reactions: redox, acid-base, precipitation, etc.
Understand that in a combustion reaction, an organic compounds reacts with oxygen to produce CO2 and water as products
Identify a reaction, given its reactants and products, as single replacement (SR), double replacement (DR), synthesis (S), decomposition (D), or combustion (C
Identify the type of reaction given only the reactants
Predict the products of an SR, DR, C, D, or S reaction given only its reactants
How much new substance forms relative to the amount of starting substance is based on the relative stability of the new and old substances and the temperature and pressure of the system.
Understand that reactions do not yield the entire product theoretically possible
Understand that many reactions have competing reactions that make products that are not intended

en-us: Combustion reactions often produce CO (carbon monoxide) in addition to the water and CO2 predicted in combustion because of the incomplete combustion of the organic materials

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the relative stability of the reactants and products influences the degree (percentage) that reactants are converted to products
Understand that experimental conditions (temperature and pressure) influence the percentage of reactants that are converted to products
Understand that these byproducts or contaminants are sometimes considered pollutants

en-us: When burning gasoline, there are several of these that are produced, including NO2, CO, SO2, SO3

competencyText.en-us: Understand that by changing the conditions, the relative amounts of product to reactant can be changed
Speeds of reaction are determined not only by relative stability but also by factors related to the collision of particles.
Understand that molecules or atoms must collide for a chemical reaction to take place
Understand that when the two particles collide, they may bounce off each other or may react
Understand that for a reaction to take place during a particle collision, the particles must be properly aligned

en-us: If the positive end of each particle collides, the electrical repulsion will drive them away from each other. If the positive end of one particle approaches the negative end of the other particle, a bond (reaction) may occur

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in addition to the proper alignment, the particles must have enough energy to start the reaction by overcoming the stability of the bonds in the reactants

en-us: O2 in the air collides with paper. However, only above 451 degrees Fahrenheit will the combustion reaction start.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the energy of the particles is less than the activation energy, the reaction will not occur
Understand that temperature is the average kinetic energy of the molecules
Understand that the fastest moving molecules have the most kinetic energy
Understand that although all the particles do not have enough energy to overcome the activation energy, some may, and those could react if they collide with the correct alignment
Understand that the more effective collisions (correctly aligned with enough energy to overcome the energy of activation) that occur, the faster the reaction will occur
Understand that conditions that lead to more collisions are likely to increase the rate of reaction
Understand that lowering the activation energy will increase the number of effective collisions
Understand that catalysts speed up a reaction by lowering the activation energy

Understand that some reactions, while theoretically inevitable because of the stability of the products relative to the reactants, do not occur at noticeable rates because the activation energy is higher than the available energy
Understand that some biological reactions occur only at noticeable rates in the presence of an organic catalyst (enzyme)
Predict whether a change in temperature will increase or decrease the rate of a chemical reaction
Understand that when reactant particles (atoms or molecules) collide with either contaminants or product particles, the desired reaction cannot take place

Understand that as the concentration of reactant particles drops, the speed of the reaction will decrease because the probability of colliding with the correct particle with the correct alignment and energy decreases

en-us: So as a reaction occurs, the concentration of reactants decreases and the concentration of products increases. Some collisions now involve reactants and products (which do not cause the reaction) so the rate of reaction slows.

competencyText.en-us: Predict whether a change in the concentration of a substance is likely to increase or decrease the rate of reaction
Understand that the shelf life of a product (food, medicine, etc.) is based on the rates of reactions that reduce its effectiveness or yield contaminants (spoilage)
Explain how refrigeration could extend the time that a product could be safely used (shelf life)

en-us: Food in a refrigerator has lower average KE, so the decompositions reactions slow down.

competencyText.en-us: Topics that apply the conservation laws to chemical reactions such as balancing equations and stoichiometry
Topics related to solutions such as pH, electrical conductivity, measurements of concentrations, and colligative properties

Learning progression on understanding that substances and mixtures of substances have different properties that can be used to predict and explain how and why they interact with other substances and mixtures or energy
Topics related to entropy, enthalpy, and calorimetry
The chemistry of carbon-containing compounds
Topics related to rates of reactions, LeChatelier's principle, and Keq
Topics related to Earth , the solar system, and outer space, including origin and continuing processes
A collection of topics in Earth and Space sciences

competencyLabel.en-us: Rocks, Minerals, and the Rock Cycle

competencyText.en-us: Understanding, explaining, and predicting how material is recycled as it changes from one form of rock (sedimentary, igneous, or metamorphic) to another form, and the processes and energy involved in those transitions
Learning progression on rock types and the rock cycle
Understand that minerals are naturally occurring substances that can form rocks
Understand that minerals have specific properties like color, hardness, cleavage, streaking, and luster
Identify a mineral using a key and a list of its properties
Identify a mineral using a key and appropriate equipment (streak plate, hardness reference materials, etc.)
Understand that a rock is a naturally occurring solid that contains one or more minerals
Understand that there are 3 general types of rock, based on how they were formed
Understand that sedimentary rocks usually form from the accumulation and consolidation of sediments

en-us: Shale, sandstone, limestone

competencyText.en-us: Understand that metamorphic rocks form when other rocks are subjected to extreme heat and/or pressure

en-us: Schist, marble, quartzite

competencyText.en-us: Understand that igneous rocks form from the solidification of molten rock

en-us: Granite, basalt, obsidian

competencyText.en-us: Understand that properties of a rock such as grain size and composition can be used to determine the origin of a rock

Understand that if two rocks are identical in structure, makeup, and fossil content, they were probably formed at the same time, in nearby areas, and with similar processes, even if the rocks are not near each other today
Predict the change in a rock if it undergoes a specified change by applying the rock cycle
Predict a single path that will change a rock to another location on the rock cycle
Predict two or more paths that will change a rock to another location on the rock cycle
Understand that the rock cycle shows how rocks can be transformed into other types of rocks
Understand that in the rock cycle, matter is not created or destroyed; It simply changes form
Understand that energy is required to move along a change process in the rock cycle

en-us: Solar energy causes wind, which leads to erosion. Convection currents in the mantle caused by radioactive decay can lead to burial, melting, and metamorphosis.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that large-grain igneous rocks usually formed by magma cooling slowly below ground, forming large crystals
Understand that small-grain igneous rocks usually formed by lava cooling rapidly above ground, forming small crystals

en-us: Basalt, andesite, pumice

competencyText.en-us: Understand that weathering occurs because of chemical interactions (acid, oxidation, etc.)

en-us: Acid rain reacting with limestone to produce CO2 and dissolving the calcium ions

competencyText.en-us: Identify the origin (intrusive or extrusive) of an igneous rock by grain size
Understand that the breakdown of rock into smaller pieces is called weathering
Understand that the weathering that occurs because of physical interactions (friction, scraping, wind, water, etc.) is called mechanical weathering
Understand that erosion is the movement of sediment away from the original rock
Create a plan, using evidence, to reduce the effects of erosion by wind and water

en-us: Wave barriers, using plants for soil conservation

competencyText.en-us: Understand that energy from the Sun, gravity, and geologic processes (tectonic) drive the rock cycle

Understanding and explaining the large time frames necessary for geologic processes both in terms of relative time and absolute time, which serve as evidence for other phenomena in Earth and space science
Learning Progression for Geologic Time that moves students to understand that geologic and astronomical processes occur over extremely long time frames
Understand that Earth is very old
Understand that Earth is very old (4.5 billion years)
Relate familiar timespans and events to the age of Earth
Understand that Earth has not always looked like it does now
Understand that Earth has not always looked like it does now

en-us: Continents used to be in a supercontinent (Pangaea).

competencyText.en-us: Justify that Earth has not always looked the way it does now with evidence

en-us: Similar terrestrial plant and animal fossils on continents that are no longer connected
Tropical fossils in Antarctica

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Earth can change slowly through processes of erosion, sea floor spreading, and mountain building
Understand that Earth can change slowly through processes of erosion, sea floor spreading, and mountain building

en-us: Streams gradually erode banks and deposit deltas.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Earth can change quickly due to catastrophic events like tsunamis, floods, hurricanes, and asteroid impacts

en-us: Flooding can strip away large layers of rock in a few days.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the universe is very old
Understand that the universe is very old (13.8 BY)
Justify that the universe is very old using evidence

en-us: Red shift of galaxies, space probes, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to planetary geology, soil, biogeochemical cycles, weathering, and erosion
Understanding the effects of water in the various systems of Earth (biosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, etc.) and the ways that water moves throughout those systems

Understanding how the structure of Earth's layers, and specifically the motion of its crustal plates, can be used as a causal mechanism to predict and explain geologic events such as mountain building, earthquakes, and volcanoes
Learning progression for understanding plate tectonics
Understand that Earth consists of four concentric layers: crust, mantle, outer core, and inner core
Compare and contrast the 4 layers of Earth
Draw and label the 4 layers of Earth
Explain the evidence for Earth's layers

en-us: Shadow zones for EQ waves indicate that there is a liquid layer below the mantle.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that Earth's crust is made of several crustal plates
Understand that Earth's crust is made of several crustal plates

en-us: North American plate, Indian plate, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Explain the evidence for the presence of crustal plates
Understand that crustal plates are divided into two general types: oceanic plates and continental plates, which have different characteristics such as density, type of rock, age, and formation
Explain that oceanic plates are generally dense, young, igneous basaltic rock formed at mid-ocean ridge volcanoes
Explain that continental plates are generally lower in density, contain a mixture of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rock, and vary in age
Understand that the tectonic plates are moving
Explain the evidence and reasoning (the scientific argument) in favor of plate tectonic theory
Understand that plate tectonic theory changed as scientists gathered new evidence and refuted previous theories

en-us: Kelvin's miscalculation of Earth
Magnetic striping. A good source of materials for this can be found here https://www.storybehindthescience.org/geology.html

competencyText.en-us: Explain the evidence and reasoning (the scientific argument) in favor of plate tectonic theory

en-us: Continental fit, similar rocks in continents that do not touch, identical plant fossils (glossopteris), identical animal fossils (Lystrosaurus), mid-ocean ridges, magnetic striping, location of earthquakes, and volcanoes

competencyText.en-us: Understand that tectonic plates can move in one of three ways relative to each other: collision (convergent), separation (divergent), or parallel (transform fault)
