Interpret a map showing the location of crustal plates and their motion to determine the type of plate boundary present
Understand that subduction occurs at a converging plate boundary when gravity pulls the higher density plate, usually oceanic, downward below the lower density plate, usually continental

en-us: The Juan de Fuca plate is subducted under the North American plate along the Northwest coast.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that folding and uplift (mountain building) occurs at a converging plate boundary when two plates of similar density, usually both continental, collide

en-us: The Himalayas are the result of the Indian Plate colliding with the Eurasian plate.

competencyText.en-us: Predict whether a converging plate will be more likely to be a subduction zone or a mountain building zone given information about the two plates involved

en-us: The relative densities of the plates (which is analogous to crustal type) determine what will happen.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in subduction zones some rock is melted to form magma as it is heated due to friction and contact with high temperature parts of the mantle
Understand that in a subduction zone some rock will undergo metamorphosis as a result of the pressure and/or heat
Understand that if the magma formed in a subduction is of lower density than the surrounding rock, it will rise to the surface
Understand that if the magma formed in a subduction is of lower density than the surrounding rock, it will rise to the surface
Understand that if the magma cools and solidifies before it reaches the surface, it will form an intrusive igneous rock with large-grain crystals

en-us: Granite sills, dikes, and batholiths

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the magma reaches the surface, it is called lava; When it cools and solidifies, it forms extrusive igneous rocks that usually have small-grain crystals

en-us: Lava flows, pyroclastic ash

competencyText.en-us: Explain that volcanoes are usually found in certain areas because of plate tectonics

en-us: Ring of fire, mid-Atlantic ridge

competencyText.en-us: Understand that divergent plate boundaries occur when plates move away from each other
Understand that divergent plate boundaries occur when plates move away from each other

en-us: Mid-ocean ridges and rift valleys

competencyText.en-us: Understand that new rock is formed at a rift zone that pushes the plates away from each other at a slow but measurable speed

en-us: Mid-ocean ridges and rift valleys

competencyText.en-us: Justify with evidence the scientific reasoning that the rock closest to the divergent plate boundary is the youngest

en-us: Radioactive dating
Magnetic striping

competencyText.en-us: Understand that transform plate boundaries occur when one plate is sliding past another but encounters friction
Understand that transform plate boundaries occur when one plate is sliding past another but encounters friction

en-us: San Andreas fault is caused by the strike/slip movement of the Pacific plate and the North American plate

competencyText.en-us: Understand that energy builds up at a transform plate boundary due to friction and other forces and is eventually released in an earthquake
Understand that earthquakes at transform plate boundaries can have an impact on human life
Understand that Pangaea was a supercontinent that existed millions of years ago
Understand that Pangaea formed in incremental pieces over a long period of time
Explain, using evidence and scientific reasoning, the formation and breakup of Pangaea

en-us: Fossils, identical rock formations, radioactive dating, location of earthquakes and volcanoes, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that rifting caused Pangaea to break first into 2 supercontinents

en-us: Laurasia and Gondwaland separated.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the supercontinents continued to separate to form the current crustal plates as more rifting occurred
Explain and justify why other supercontinents have formed in the past and will form again in the future
Explain the sources of energy and how they are transformed in the Earth system as plate tectonics occurs
Understand how a convection current (cell) moves
Understand that the heat sources for convection in the mantle are the core and radioactive decay
Understand that buildings made at plate boundaries (areas of current tectonic activity) have different engineering concerns than buildings near the center of a crustal plate
Understand how tsunamis and earthquakes are related.
Explain the consequences of earthquakes on land
Predict what areas should be more concerned with earthquake and tsunami preparedness
Explain the effect that tsunamis can have on both land and sea

en-us: Japanese tsunami 2011, Sumatra 2004
Waves and energy topics

competencyText.en-us: Understand how buildings can be designed and built to better withstand earthquakes and tsunamis
Evaluate the relative risk of several areas for earthquakes and tsunamis

en-us: http://www.ehso.com/ehshome/disastersearthquakerisk.htm

competencyText.en-us: Explain that although most earthquakes occur along current plate boundaries, there are potentially dangerous faults that lie in mid-continental areas; Explain how this information was obtained and how it could inform decisions in society

Explain that although most earthquakes occur along current plate boundaries, there are potentially dangerous faults that lie in mid-continental areas; Explain how this information was obtained and how it could inform decisions in society

en-us: New Madrid fault

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some faults lie within the middle areas of plates where previous tectonic activity occurred

en-us: New Madrid fault

competencyText.en-us: Explain that some of these earthquakes away from plate boundaries have occurred in historical times so that eyewitness accounts are available

en-us: http://www.ceri.memphis.edu/compendium/eyewitness/index.html

competencyText.en-us: Predict the possible results in the biosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere of a proposed tectonic event such as a supercontinent forming or breaking apart
Explain that as two continents separated by a body of water collide, the sea will be removed

en-us: Destruction of the Tethys Sea

competencyText.en-us: Predict that if continental plates rift apart, a new sea will form

en-us: Start of the Atlantic Ocean

competencyText.en-us: Predict that the addition or removal of a sea from an ecosystem will cause substantial changes in the wind and ocean currents
Predict that changing ocean and wind currents could cause changes in weather patterns, including global cooling (ice ages and glaciation) or global warming (sea-level rising and shrinking ice caps)
Understand that a changing environment caused by tectonic changes could be a contributory cause for a mass extinction

en-us: Permian mass extinction

competencyText.en-us: Topics related to the study of the impact of human activity on Earth, including pollution, hazards, remediation, and mitigation
Topics related to the location, types, and uses of natural resources
Topics related to oceans, such as sea floor topography, currents, chemistry
Topics related to atmospheric structure and conditions as well as weather and climate, including planets other than Earth
Learning progression on understanding how local atmospheric conditions can be described and predicted
Observation and measurement of local weather
Observe local weather conditions

en-us: Sunny, cloudy, rainy, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Record local weather conditions over time
Make a chart using data about the weather

en-us: Bar graph of sunny, cloudy, and rainy days

competencyText.en-us: Use appropriate tools to make quantitative measurements of local weather

en-us: Thermometer, wind vane, rain gauge, barometer

competencyText.en-us: Understand that weather is a local (regional) combination of sunlight, wind, snow, rain, and temperature
Collect or research data about typical weather by extended time periods (months, seasons, or years)

en-us: Rainfall, temperature, snowfall, wind direction

competencyText.en-us: Make a graph or table showing average weather conditions for an area
Local weather can be predicted
Understand that weather can be predicted (forecast)
Understand why predicting weather is important

en-us: Prepare for storms, floods
Know when to plant crops

competencyText.en-us: Use a weather prediction to prepare for severe weather

en-us: Go to tornado shelter location

competencyText.en-us: Understand that air pressure can be measured
Understand that areas can have high air pressure or low air pressure relative to normal air pressure
Understand that air moves from high-pressure areas to low-pressure areas
Predict weather based on air pressure
Understand that the collision of high-pressure areas (air masses) with low-pressure areas (air masses) can cause sudden changes in weather
Weather predictions are probabilistic models
Understand that weather forecasts are predictions based on mathematic models of scientific understandings

en-us: A two day forecast is more accurate than a 2 month forecast

competencyText.en-us: Understand that predictions of weather give probabilities of weather events, not certainties

en-us: El Ni?o, La Ni?a

competencyText.en-us: Understand that short-term weather forecasts are usually more accurate than long-term forecasts

en-us: A 2-day forecast is more accurate than a 2-month forecast.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that long-term forecasts need to use data and patterns from large areas that extend beyond the local area
Learning progression on understanding how long-term, large-scale weather patterns occur and explain how these have changed due to both human and natural causes
Climates are large scale in both time and area
Understand that climates describe long-time trends in weather

en-us: Climate describes trends over many years, not only a few months.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that climates describe large areas of Earth's surface
Understand that climates can be classified by a variety of factors, such as amount of rainfall, average temperature, etc.

en-us: Desert defined by average rainfall less than 250mm, but temperature can be high (Sahara), cold (Gobi), or mild (Atacama)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that climate results from the interplay of latitude, altitude, and geography

en-us: Two areas at the same latitude and opposite sides of a mountain chain (leeward and windward) will have different climates.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that unequal heating of Earth is one cause for patterns of water and air circulation

en-us: Jet stream for air circulation, Gulf stream current for water

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the rotation of Earth is one cause for patterns of water and air circulation
Understand that the combination of water- and air-circulation patterns determine regional climates
Climates have changed over the last 100 years.
Understand that weather and climate data have been recorded for over 100 years
Understand that weather and climate data can be deduced from a variety of older sources like ice core samples, corals, etc.
Analyze data for average monthly temperature, rainfall, ice flows, glaciation, etc. to identify trends and patterns

en-us: Look at pictures of summer ice coverage from satellite photos and notice the smaller coverage

competencyText.en-us: Understand the effect of greenhouse gases

en-us: Greenhouse gases such as CO2, ozone, etc. absorb IR light and prevent the re-radiation of energy from Earth back into space.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that CO2 is the most prevalent greenhouse gas
Understand that CO2 levels in the atmosphere have increased greatly since the industrial revolution
Understand the predictions for increased global temperature as a result of the increase in greenhouse gases
Predict the effects on sea level based on changes in global temperature
Understand that climate change will not only increase global temperature but also lead to an increase in severe weather

en-us: Polar vortex fluctuations, increased rate of high category hurricanes, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the effects on ecosystem caused by climate change

en-us: Change in polar ice floes impact polar bears, loss of habitat to sea level rising, etc., loss in biodiversity

competencyText.en-us: Predict the effects on human societies caused by climate change

en-us: Rise in sea level could flood many cities (New Orleans, NY, Tokyo, etc.)
Changes in amount and timing of precipitation can affect amount and quality of freshwater available

competencyText.en-us: The primary cause of climate change is human activity, based on research findings of many studies
The primary source of CO2 and other greenhouse gases is burning fossil fuels
Understand that global production of CO2 from burning fossil fuels is much larger than the environment's ability to absorb (sequester) CO2 through photosynthesis and other processes
Understand that deforestation is another cause of the increase in CO2, because it decreases the ability to absorb (sequester) CO2
Understand that human activity can change these trends
Understand that there are benefits, costs, and risks to action or inaction relative to global carbon emissions
Create a plan and justify with data for how to reduce the CO2 emissions

en-us: Wedge activity

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate the costs and risks of a plan to reduce CO2 emissions
Evaluate mathematically the flow and collection of CO2 gases and energy in a global ecosystem, given data on flows and sinks
Use scientific argumentation from evidence with reasoning to evaluate the benefits and risks of a plan to address climate change and present it in written, oral, or technological (presentation) form
Understanding the properties, origins, and interactions of the components of our solar system and other solar systems
LP about the Solar System
Patterns in motion of Earth, the Moon, and Sun can be observed
Understand that the Sun does not rise and set at the same time every day

en-us: Students enter school knowing that sunset is later in the summer (can be accessed with questions about summer time or bedtime in the summer)

competencyText.en-us: Record the time for sunrise and sunset for an extended period of time

en-us: This could be done daily for several weeks
A few times per week for several months, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the Moon does not appear the same every night
Draw a picture of how the Moon appears
Compare drawings or pictures of the Moon made on different days
Understand that the Moon does not rise and set at the same time every day
Record the time for moonrise and moonset for an extended period of time

en-us: Record these every day for a month

competencyText.en-us: Understand that these patterns have been observed since ancient times
Understand that certain stars or constellations appear at the same time of year each year

en-us: Orion is visible best in winter in the US.

competencyText.en-us: There are large distances between objects in the solar system
Understand that faraway objects appear smaller
Understand that light sources that are faraway appear dimmer

en-us: A flashlight that shines on a board or wall will appear dimmer as it is moved farther back from the wall.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the Sun is the largest object in the solar system
Understand that the Sun is the most massive object in the solar system
Understand that the brightness of a star (like the Sun) is a result of both its distance and the amount of light it produces
Understand that the brightness of other objects (like the Moon, planets, and comets) is a result of both distance and the amount of light from the Sun that they reflect

en-us: The Moon is very bright. Venus looks very bright sometimes.

competencyText.en-us: Patterns in motion in the solar system and constellations can be used to explain and predict events
Understand that there are observable patterns in the solar system and constellations
Understand that the patterns in constellations and the solar system have been known since ancient times

en-us: The Egyptians could predict the Nile floods by the appearance of certain stars.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the phases of the Moon can be identified and predicted

en-us: Understand that Earth, the Moon, and the Sun are not exactly in the same plane (explains why there is not an eclipse every month)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the location of planets can be predicted based on prior observations

en-us: Ancients could predict the location of the morning/evening star (Venus)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the changing of the seasons can be predicted by observing constellations
Understand that different stars and constellations are visible in the northern and southern hemispheres
Understand that people in history thought that the stars, planets, Moon, and Sun revolved around Earth

en-us: Ancient myths and stories (possible literature interplay)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the planets all move around the Sun in the same direction (CCW)
Understand that scientists can predict the future location of planets so that space probes can be sent to investigate them

en-us: Galileo, Cassini, Viking, Voyager

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the rotation of Earth on its axis causes day and night
Understand that patterns in high and low tide can be predicted
Understand that the predictions based on astronomical observation led to decisions affecting agriculture and commerce, such as when to plant crops
Understand that events that were not predicted (like comets and supernovas) could be frightening to ancient people

en-us: Comets were seen as harbingers of doom and used as a justification to overthrow rulers.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the seasons can be predicted based on the tilt of Earth's axis relative to the Sun

en-us: Many students have a misconception that summer occurs when Earth is closest to the Sun.

competencyText.en-us: Predict what season is occurring based on a picture or diagram of the Sun and a planet's axis
Understand that solar and lunar eclipses can be predicted
Understand that a solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes directly between the Sun and Earth causing a shadow that appears to block out the Sun
Understand that a lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth passes directly between the Sun and the Moon, causing a shadow that appears to block out the Moon
Solar system is held together by gravity
Understand that gravity is a force that draws two things together
Understand that gravity gets weaker the farther apart two objects are
Understand that the force of gravity is proportional to the masses of the two objects

en-us: Again, conceptual basis
Since the Sun is massive, it is able to exert much more gravitational force at the same distance from a second object than a planet would.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that gravity can be used to explain the cause of the patterns in the solar system and constellations

en-us: Newton's explanation for Boyle's question about the orbits of planets, which was explained in The Mechanical Universe and Cosmos (2013).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the gravitational forces exerted by both the Sun and the Moon cause tides
Predict the relative height (high or low) of the tide based on the location of the Moon relative to a point on Earth
Understand that the relative positions of the Sun and Moon to Earth can either strengthen or weaken the tidal (gravitational force)

en-us: If the Sun and Moon are aligned (new and full Moon), the tides are higher.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the relative height of the tide based on the positions of the Sun and Moon relative to Earth
Origin of the solar system can be explained
Understand that scientists apply scientific reasoning and theories to explain the formation of the solar system
Understand that the solar system formed from a cloud (nebula) of gas and dust approximately 5 billion years ago
Understand that the parts of the solar system formed at the same time
Understand that both gravity (collapsing inward) and pressure (pushing outward) contributed to what happened to the cloud
Understand that the cloud was disturbed by an external force that started it rotating

en-us: A nearby supernova blast is the most likely cause.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the interplay of the velocity and gravity caused the cloud to collapse from a spherical shape to a disk shape

en-us: Gravitational potential energy was converted into kinetic energy (and vice versa).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that gravity pulled most of the matter toward the center, which would eventually become the Sun
Understand that material combined as it smashed together to form larger pieces
Understand that as the pieces increased in size, they exerted a larger gravitational pull

Explain using evidence and reasoning the validity of the nebular accretion theory
Understand that when the Sun became a star undergoing nuclear fusion, many light elements were driven from the inner parts of the solar system

Centripetal forces caused by gravity explain the motions in the solar system

Understand that if a force acts perpendicular to a velocity, it causes circular motion

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the speed of planets can be predicted using Kepler's laws

When a planet is closer to the Sun, it moves at a greater speed than when it is farther away, so that equal areas are swept out in equal times.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that fluctuations in Earth's orbit are a contributory cause to long term cyclical changes in weather such as ice ages and other gradual climate changes

competencyText.en-us: Traits passed from parents to offspring
Some traits of individuals are passed from parent to offspring. These are called heritable or inherited traits. Other traits are learned or non-inherited and are not passed on to offspring.
Identify a trait that was inherited from a parent by an offspring

en-us: A pea plant with green peas has offspring that produce green peas.

competencyText.en-us: Identify a trai that will not be inherited by offspring.

en-us: A pea plant that has its naturally green peas painted purple will not have offspring that have purple peas, the peas will be green

competencyText.en-us: Compare and contrast acquired from inherited traits
(MISCONCEPTION) A learned trait can be passed onto offspring
(MISCONCEPTION) Transformational misconception - offspring are better adapted than their parents
Traits can have a variety of effects: positive, negative, or neutral

Some traits are helpful (advantageous); some traits are harmful (disadvantageous); some neither help nor hurt (neutral). The helpfulness of a trait is related to environmental factors such as climate, food sources, and predators.
Identify a trait as helpful given information about survival of offspring

en-us: White fur for a rabbit or hare in the winter in a climate with snow.

competencyText.en-us: Identify a trait as harmful given information about survival of offspring

Evolution as a result of random and non-random processes

Evolution is the result of two separate sets of processes: 1) the non-random processes like the natural selection of traits by differential deproduction and (2) the random processes like the generation of new traits and genetic drift
Contrast the random generation of new traits with the process of natural selection

Predict the genotype and phenotypes of individuals using a pedigree analysis for blood type

Causes of changes in genotypes
Understand that gametes are produced during meiosis
Understand that DNA must be copied during meiosis to pass along genetic material
Understand that during meiosis some genetic material is moved from one homologous chromosome to another, which causes the random assortment in classical genetics
Understand that if two genes are close together on a chromosome, they will be linked and will not obey the law of independent assortment
Understand that because of meiosis and crossing over, the probability of any two gametes being identical is negligible
Understand that if the DNA is miscopied during meiosis, a new allele may arise if the change causes a change in the production of a coded protein

en-us: Links to the molecular genetics progression

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the miscopied DNA prevents the formation of a critical protein, the embryo may not be viable
Understand that if the miscopied DNA produces a similar protein to the original gene, the effect may or may not be noticeable
Understand that if the chromosomes do not separate correctly during meiosis, the embryo will not have a normal number of chromosomes

Understand that although most human embryos that do not have 46 chromosomes are not viable, some of these errors lead to significant genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, Klinefelter syndrome
Genetics can be used to show the closeness of relationships.
Understand that organisms that have similar DNA are likely to have a recent ancestor
Understand that mitochondrial DNA is passed primarily along maternal lines because ova have many mitochondria and sperm rarely contribute mitochondria to the zygote
Understand that evolutionary phylogeny can be interpreted using genetic similarity

Learning progression that genes in DNA contain information that code for proteins that perform the functions of the organism. Although all body cells contain a complete genetic code, only certain genes are activated in a given cell.

en-us: The upper anchor of this LP is that students will understand the three models structure of the information: genetic model, meiotic model, and molecular model. This model was proposed by Stewart, Cartier, and Passmore (2005) and is relied upon in many ways by other LP related to the topic ((Duncan et al, 2009
Elmesky et al, 2013

Rodeman et al, 2006). Todd (2013) used a modified form of the Duncan et al (2009) LP with HS students to show that looking across levels (gene, protein, cell and trait levels had an impact). As Dreyfus and Jungwirth (1989) suggest, students will create ad hoc explanations for phenomena that are taught as processes that occur without a causal mechanism. So, it is important to tie the causal mechanism of proteins as the expression of genes at the molecular and trait level or students will create explanations as part of the normal sense making activities that occur when an explanation does not conform to prior understanding (Posner et al, 1988).  The primary focus here is on multicellular eukaryotes that engage in sexual reproduction so that the meiotic model is relevant and fewer exceptions (circular plasmid DNA) need to be addressed. Properties of prokaryotes and the peculiarities of their DNA can be handled in other units and progressions.

competencyText.en-us: Living things use chemicals
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that chemicals are bad or dangerous

en-us: Many students believe that chemicals are bad or dangerous

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are many kinds of chemicals
Understand that some chemicals are helpful and some are harmful
Understand that living things use different kinds of chemicals
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that water is not a chemical
Understand that water is a chemical
Understand that water is the most common chemical in all living things
Understand that living things use other chemicals
Understand that living things use carbohydrates

en-us: Many students will have some knowledge about "carbs" from a dietary sense.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that carbohydrates (carbs) are bad

en-us: Some students will have internalized messaging about excess carbs in diets in a way that they believe that carbohydrates are bad for you

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the primary use of carbohydrates in living things is for energy
Understand that living things use proteins
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that protein is good

en-us: Some students will have internalized messaging about protein in diets that proteins are good and that fats and carbs are bad

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a primary use of proteins in living things is as building blocks

en-us: Using an analogy of a Lego may allow students to understand that proteins are made of smaller units or blocks that can be taken apart and put back together in different ways to make new things. Eventually, students will learn that proteins are responsible for doing the work of the cell, but at this stage, the goal is understanding that they are put together with smaller blocks to build things. The curriculum will spiral back to the function of proteins later.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that living things use fats (lipids)

en-us: The term lipid can be ignored at the elementary school level. Relating it to the dietary term (fat) may allow for better anchoring to prior knowledge.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that fats are bad or that some fats are good and others are bad

en-us: Some students will have internalized messaging about specific fats as good or bad. Again, this view of value is based on messaging in popular media and ads about dietary concerns.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that fats (lipids) are used by living things in many ways including energy storage.

en-us: Since students at this age will not have learned about cells and cellular membranes, the use of lipids for membranes will be added when they learn about cells at a later age

competencyText.en-us: Understand that chemicals can be classified into different groups
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that organic chemicals pertain to only certain kinds of food

en-us: Students may be confused because terms in used in food labeling (e.g., organic) may have very little to do with actual scientific terminology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that living things also use inorganic chemicals that do not contain carbon

en-us: The obvious one for most kids in ES will be oxygen which they know they need to breathe.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some chemicals are called organic because they contain carbon and usually occur in living things

en-us: The emphasis here is that organic chemicals are related to living things. The idea that some food are organic and others are not is an unintended consequence of the food labeling industry

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the inorganic compounds that living things use are sometimes called minerals or salts

en-us: Students may be familiar with minerals from food labels. They may know they need iron, sodium, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Genes are transmitters of information

en-us: In elementary grades, students will learn that genes carry and transmit information. Many misconceptions will abound but the central tenet of this stepping stone is that genes contain information. At this level, how that information works in either a mechanistic or simplistic way is probably beyond most students. The primary model addressed here is the genetic model of inheritance (Stewart et al, 2005). The target is not Mendelian genetics but rather an explanation as to why offspring are similar to but not identical to parents.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that animals have genes but plants do not
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that genetically modified produce (food) has genes but normal produce (food) does not
Understand that all living things have genes (or genetic material)

en-us: At this grade level, the idea of gene as a portion of a DNA molecule is not accessible. So, genetic information may be preferred. However, using two long words instead of "gene" may be problematic to poor readers, ELL, and other students.  Using "gene" in this way with a plan to use a recursive lesson to correct the simplification may be the best approach from a PCK perspective.

competencyText.en-us: Identify whether or not something has genes
Understand that things that were once living had genes
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that genes can be extracted from all fossils

en-us: Some students will believe that all fossils will contain genes.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that genes are particles that travel through the body

en-us: (Venville and Treagust (1998)

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that genes are small components of a trait found in cells

en-us: For example, eyes contain a gene that holds eye color pigment that it releases

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that one gene determines all the traits of an organism

en-us: Duncan & Reiser (2007)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that genes contain information or plans for an organism

en-us: The goal here is that students think of genes as plans for building. There is a possibility of returning to the Lego analogy that genes are like instruction booklets for how to build the blocks to make a specific organism, just like the directions for a Lego kit might allow for the parts to be made into a car, a plane, or a boat.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that most of the genes for two of the same species are the same

en-us: Students should understand that the basic plans from genes are the same for a given species or even for similar organisms.  Advanced students in middle school might even relate to "Your inner fish" by Schubin that some genes (plans) like one, two, many blobs for instance are common across species.  The main point is that most of the plans in genes for two members of the same species are the same that is why people usually have 2 legs, 2 arms, 1 mouth, etc.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that every individual has completely different genes with no similarities

en-us: Many students believe that each person has completely different genetic material with no similarities. This may stem from news and popular culture ideas that DNA testing shows that everyone is different.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that genes pass information from one generation to the next
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that an organism gets more genetic information from the same sex parent
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that more genetic material comes from the parent that is most similar to the child

en-us: Many students believe that they get more genes from the parent that they "take after."

competencyText.en-us: Understand that organisms get equal amounts of genetic material from each parent

en-us: This is limited to organisms that use sexual reproduction. The mechanism that causes this (meiosis) will be explored later in the learning progression. The focus here is on the genetic model.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe genes battle or fight to determine what an organism looks like

en-us: Some students will have internalized a view of dominant and recessive terms as being a battle in which dominant genes "win" a fight.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some genes lead to easily observable traits

en-us: Examples of easily observable genetic traits would be rolling tongues, widows peak, detached earlobes, hair or eye color

competencyText.en-us: Understand that people can alter the appearance of some traits that are genetically determined through the use of cosmetics or cosmetic devices

en-us: People can dye their hair or wear colored contacts.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that scientists (like Mendel) understood that information was passed from parent to offspring before they understood how the process worked

en-us: The key here is to let students understand that they are unraveling this big idea in the same way that scientists did, in pieces over time. Students need to understand that understanding the causal process took many years to develop.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that farmers and other people have used an understanding that genes are passed from parent to offspring to select for specific traits in plants and animals that were desirable for use

en-us: Farmers might use the biggest and strongest stallion to get horses that were more likely to be bigger and stronger for farm work. Others might use horses that were fast to try to breed horses that were fast.  They might use pollen or seeds from plants that grew the most fruit or a specific color, etc. Dog breeds would be another example.

competencyText.en-us: DNA as the carrier of genetic information

en-us: The shift is back to molecular level information from the focus at the organism level in Level 2 of this LP. Students have some misconceptions about DNA many of which are related to the terminology used (such as macromolecule). In MS grades, students will learn what DNA is and that it carries the genetic information in a chemical code. An analogy can be made to computer codes or ciphers in which digits or letters serve as code for something else.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is one chemical found in cells
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that DNA is only present in sex cells (sperm and egg)
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that plants do not contain DNA

en-us: Gribble & Donovan (2004)

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe DNA is an indicator of individuality

en-us: Venville et al (2004)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA is made of several smaller components
Understand that DNA is a macromolecule made up of multiple repeating parts
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that DNA can be seen with the naked eye because it is a macromolecule

en-us: The term macromolecule implies macroscopic to students, so they think that they should be able to see it

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that if you cannot see DNA, then it is not present
Understand that the parts of DNA include a sugar (deoxyribose), a phosphate, and nitrogenous bases
Understand that a phosphate, sugar, and base together make a functional unit of DNA

en-us: The term nucleotide can be introduced at higher grades. The importance of DNA as having a basic structure with variation is more important than the terminology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are four different nitrogenous bases that are present in DNA
Understand that the bases in DNA are adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine and are often abbreviated as A, T, G, and C

en-us: Although there are rare exceptions to these simple rules, they are well beyond the scope of this level of the LP and normally not addressed at all in K-12 biology education.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that sequences of sugar, phosphate and base (nucleotides)  are connected together and link to form a chain
Understand that two chains of these sequences together form a double helix or spiral that is what is called DNA
Understand that the two strands complement each other because the base pairs only fit together in certain ways that will allow the helix to form
(MISCONCEPTION ) Believe that the two strands of DNA are identical to each other
Understand that adenine on one strand always pairs with thymine on the matching strand

en-us: One mnemonic is to remember that the bases at the ends of the alphabet go together. These pairs are held together by 2 hydrogen bonds, although memorizing that is not as important as understanding that these occur as pairs

competencyText.en-us: Understand that cytosine on one strand always pairs with guanine on the matching strand

en-us: One mnemonic is to remember that the letters in the middle of the alphabet go together. These pairs form 3 hydrogen bonds. Again, this factoid is less important than the big idea that certain pairs always occur together so that DNA can maintain its double helix shape.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the appropriate base pair on the matching strand of a DNA molecule
Understand that the bases in matching strands of DNA are held together by "weak hydrogen bonds"

en-us: For most students learning this in MS, the concept of different kinds of bonds (ionic and covalent) has not been taught. Intramolecular forces such as hydrogen bonds and dipoles have also not been taught, so the use of "hydrogen bonds" becomes little more than a mental widget to explain how it works. There are some hands on manipulatives and lab activities that illustrate the fit by showing the A & T with double prongs and the C & G with triple prongs or similar differences in shapes to help students visualize that the pairs are based on some geometric aspect, this is a good precursor to the idea that shape will determine functionality of proteins. The details of H-bonds are less important than the idea that geometry at the molecular level leads to stability. This echoes Lavoie (1989) who found that students memorize terms but do not understand the concepts behind them in biology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA is the primary part of chromosomes
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that old cells have less DNA than new cells

en-us: Lewis, Leach, and Wood-Robinson (2000)

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all cells of a given type have identical DNA even if they come from different people

en-us: Lewis, Leach, and Wood-Robinson (2000). Many students believe that all skin cells or cheek cells have the same DNA (skin DNA or cheek DNA) that are different from other tissue DNA but identical across people

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that DNA is only present in certain organs like the brain or heart

en-us: Some students believe that DNA is only present in the brain. This may be the result of learning cellular organelles and learning that the nucleus is the "brain" of the cell that tells it what to do.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA is present in all cells
Understand that cells in a given organism, except for sex cells (gametes), have the same number of identical chromosomes

en-us: Although some cells, for example mature red blood cells, lack DNA this can be addressed later in the progression when specialization is addressed. The key point here is to get students to understand that cells have identical genetic codes. Gametes may not have been studied in biology class at this point but students may be familiar with them from human development or health classes.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that since all cells have the same chromosomes, the cells all have the same genetic information or code
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all chromosomes look the same
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that chromosomes look like the double helix diagrams because they are made of DNA
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that chromosomes are visible in all cells at all times
Understand that chromosomes are only visible with a microscope at certain times or stages in a given cell

en-us: Pictures of karyotypes may be interesting to show

competencyText.en-us: Understand that different chromosomes in an organism might appear to have different shapes

en-us: Karyotype photos. Most bacteria have circular plasmid DNA. This is likely to be covered in a unit detailing the differences between prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all organisms have the same number of chromosomes

en-us: Humans have 46, corn has 20 chromosomes, fruit flies have 8 chromosomes

competencyText.en-us: Understand that for a species all normal individuals will have the same number of chromosomes but that number may be different for a different species

en-us: Morse code, ASCII, HTML could all be used as examples or even cyphers.  Even numbers show a code in that "12" does not mean the exact same thing as 1 and 2 separately.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a code can be used to communicate information in one form that can be translated into another form
Understand that DNA and chromosomes are the code for genetic information from previous levels of the learning progression
Understand that a given chromosome has code for part of the genetic information for an organism
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that a cell only has the genetic information that pertains to that cell
Understand that set of all chromosomes in a cell contains the entire code for the genetic information for the organism
DNA replication in mitosis passes the genetic code from cell to cell within an organism

en-us: At this point the progression moves forward to how is the genetic code passed from cell to cell within an individual. In MS grades, students will learn that as part of the cell cycle that cells each get copies of the genetic information found in DNA and that usually the code is copied correctly. The level will end with the idea that if the code is not copied correctly, the plan may lead to problems in the daughter cells, which will lead to the next level of the progression which returns to the role of proteins. Although the small grain progression contains a large amount of detail, the overwhelming focus should be on the Big Idea that the cell cycle and mitosis occur so that two identical (or nearly identical) cells are formed from one cell that each have exact copies of the same DNA encoded plan. The detail is added for students who might revisit this topic in high school in biology or advanced biology classes.  But the key point remains, this is how the code is maintained within an organism from cell to cell. Later, when meiosis is covered, students will see how the code is passed from one generation to the next (from one organism to another).

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that cells do not change or go through a development cycle

en-us: Students view cells as static because they have seen many pictures of a "typical" plant cell or animal cell that all look the same.

competencyText.en-us: Understand  that a cell goes through different periods of development
Understand that the periods of development for a cell is called the cell cycle
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that the cell spends most of its time in the mitotic and cell division parts of the cell cycle

en-us: Students often believe that mitosis takes up most of the cell cycle because so much more time is spent on teaching that part of the cycle rather than the growth phases that actually dominate the time of the cell cycle.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a cell is in growth and synthesis stages (interphase) for the majority of the cell cycle

en-us: Although this is not strictly true for early embryonic development, for most cells this is the case.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the first phase of the cell cycle is the G1 (Growth) stage

en-us: Ignoring the G0 or resting phase.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that G1 stage begins after cytokinesis
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that the number of organelles in a cell is fixed and very small

en-us: Students internalize the standard picture of a cell with its organelles to think that there are always a small, fixed  number of organelles in a given cells

competencyText.en-us: Understand that during G1 the cell is metabolically active, increases in size, and increases the number of organelles.

en-us: Some research has mitochondrial replication tied to G2. Students need to understand that as the cell gets larger, it will need more organelles to do the work of the cell.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the volume to surface area ratio for a cell falls out of a certain range, the cell will not be able to function normally

en-us: A great lab to demonstrate this is using pieces of potato cut to different sizes (.5 cm cube, 1 cm cube, 2 cm cube) that are submerged in a colored solution that can penetrate the potato partially like potassium permanganate.  Students can then understand that the process of diffusion is not instantaneous and that if the cell becomes too large, chemical nutrients will not be able to diffuse from end of a cell to the other end of the cell in a timely manner.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that feedback loops related to resources and triggers from other cells determine if the cell proceeds to the next stage (S phase) or will arrest in growth stage

en-us: It is important for students to understand the big picture of feedback loops. If there are not enough resources readily available for 2 cells, the cell will not advance in the cycle towards replication.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that S (synthesis) phase primarily involves the synthesis (copying) of DNA
Understand that S phase should produce two exact copies of a chromosome with its DNA information code

en-us: In this progression, the idea of passing along exact copies of the information code is important. It will lead to questions about what happens when the code (plan) is not coped correctly. At this stage the DNA is loosely packed so it is technically called chromatin.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that an enzyme causes the double helix to unwind leaving strands with only one set of nitrogenous bases

en-us: The enzyme is helicase, but the important thing to note for the progression is the role of enzymes along the way. This will tie back to proteins in the next level of the progression. The exact details of 5'-3' replication are beyond the level of detail that most students to be prepared for college biology. The extreme detail here is not as important as understanding the big picture that enzyme proteins work in specific ways. The idea of the importance of specific shapes (lock and key analogy) may be fruitful here as it will help when protein synthesis is stressed in the next level.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a different enzyme attaches complementary nucleotide to the single strand so that an exact copy of the original is made

en-us: The enzyme is DNA polymerase, but again the importance is that it is an enzyme.

competencyText.en-us: Predict what nucleotide base must be added to the strand to re-create an exact copy of the original DNA molecule
Understand that this process is occurring for both strands at the same time
Understand that cells have proteins that check for damage and repair the DNA

en-us: Again the role of proteins is used as a pre-cursor to later in the progression

competencyText.en-us: Understand that even with these proteins and complementary base pairs, a few errors might occur each time the DNA strand is copied

en-us: Estimates for error rates for advanced eukaryotes (like humans) range from about 1 in 1 million (10^-6) to 1 in 1 billion (10^-9). (Kunkel, 2004
Pray, 2008)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the DNA is not copied correctly the new cell might not have the correct code (plan)

en-us: Returning to the idea of DNA as a code for a plan for how the organism works

competencyText.en-us: Understand that an error in the plan might cause little or no problem or it could cause a major problem

en-us: A great example of this would be the scene from "This is Spinal Tap" in which the plan for Stine Henge is inches instead of feet.  If a safe for school instruction version of the scene is available, it would be a way to illustrate the point by reducing it to the absurd.  That could be contrasted with a GPS direction that is off by 50 feet but only one possible turn on that side of the road is near. Another example might be the difference between 1/4 teaspoon and 1/3 teaspoon of salt vs 1/4 teaspoon and 1/4 cup salt in a recipe.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA replication occurs rapidly under enzyme control to minimize errors

en-us: This is a place that evolutionary biology might be included. Organisms that had less effective enzymes that copied DNA more slowly are more likely to copy errors into the DNA code. The more errors that occur, the more likely that one or more of the errors will cause significant problems to the plan which might lead to death, sterilization, or other problems that would reduce the likelihood that the organism with less effective enzymes was able to pass along its plan (DNA) to future generations. Conversely, organisms with more effective enzymes, are less likely to have errors in copying so fewer cells should have problems. If fewer cells have problems, then it is likely that fewer tissues, fewer organs, and fewer systems will have problems. Understand that this is all based on probabilities, if there are only a few errors, but one is catastrophic, then the organism may still have significant problems including death or sterilization as mentioned before. There is a random nature to the errors in terms of their significance
however, in general fewer errors will generally lead to fewer major problems.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the copied (replicated) chromosomes have two sister chromatids
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that during S-phase the number of chromosomes in the cell doubles

en-us: Students will thing that since the DNA copied there are twice as many chromosomes. The terms chromosome, chromatin, and chromatid can be confusing and lead to errors in student understanding or explanation.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the amount of DNA is double the original amount but the number of chromosomes is still the same

en-us: Ploidy may be used as a term here, but could probably wait until meiosis is covered in later levels of the progression

competencyText.en-us: Understand that centrosome is also produced during S phase in animals

en-us: Similar microtubule structures exist in plants and fungi. Again microtubules are made of specific proteins which should be mentioned

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the G2 (growth 2) phase follows the S phase
Understand that additional organelles are produced during G2 phase
Understand that each potential daughter cell will need enough of each type of organelle to perform all necessary cellular functions
Understand that structures necessary for mitosis are also made during G2 phase

en-us: For example, the microtubule framework for aligning and moving chromosomes occurs during this phase. But again the details are less important than the idea that proteins and other structures needed for the next phase are made during this phase. The cell operates like a modern business with "just in time" delivery of supplies.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that another feedback loop (checkpoint) occurs to determine if the cell moves on the next stage
Understand that the G2 checkpoint is primarily a check for the completeness and correctness of DNA replication from S phase

en-us: Again, the emphasis is on feedback loops that are designed to prevent problematic cells that do not have the correct plans from copying and leading to potential problems for the organism

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the cell determines that the DNA is damaged, enzymes  will attempt to repair the DNA
Understand that if the DNA is damaged beyond repair, the cell may undergo apoptosis (cell death) to prevent damaged DNA being passed to future cells
Understand that problems in the detection of DNA errors or cell apoptosis are related to diseases like cancer
Understand that if the G2 checkpoint determines the DNA is correct and complete, the cell will move into the stages of mitosis

en-us: Again, there are a lot of minute details here. The key is to focus on big picture ideas: feedback loops, proteins performing functions, and exact copies of cells with the correct DNA plan without getting too bogged down in the details.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the first phase of mitosis is prophase.

en-us: Common mnemonics for this include "Pete Makes A Touchdown" and "Penny Makes A Taco". This is a description of mitosis in animal cells. Plants have slightly different features that include a preprophase.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that chromatin condenses to chromsomes that are visble with a microscope during prophase
Understand that other cellular process such as protein synthesis tend to decrease or stop during this stage
Understand that some cellular structures are dismantled (disappear) during prophase

en-us: The nucleolous and nuclear membrane are prime examples. Students may think that these structures are "destroyed" because texts often describe them as disappearning. It is important to stress again that enzymatic proteins break these structures down into components that might be reused later.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that centrosomes move along microtubule protein chains
Understand that metaphase is the next stage in mitosis
Understand that during metaphase the centromeres of chromosomes are aligned along the metaphase plate
Understand that a feedback checkpoint mechanisms determines if the sister chromatids are attached to spindle fibers

en-us: Since the next process is irreversible, the feedback loop should minimize errors in separating the sister chromatids. Again, the emphasis is that there are checks to make certain that exact copies of the DNA code (plan) is made at each step of the process.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the checkpoint criteria are met, the cell moves into anaphase
Understand that anaphase involves splitting the centromeres and the movement of sister chromatids to opposite ends of the cell.

en-us: Again, a series of enzymes trigger reactions that cause the changes. Animal cells distort to an oval shape while the ratcheting action of the spindle fibers pulls the chromosomes to opposite ends of the cell.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when the chromosomes reach opposite ends of the cell, the next phase (telophase) begins
Understand that telophase reverses the process of prophase and reforms the nuclear membrane and nucleolus from the components in the cell

en-us: This is a key point. Telophase prepares the cell to return to normal function after cytokinesis

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the chromosomes begin to unwind back into chromatin form during telophase
Understand that cytokinesis, pinching of the cellular membrane to form two new cells, occurs at the end of telophase
Understand that plants also must make a new cell wall between the two cells during this phase
Understand that following telophase the cell will return to a G1 growth stage
Understand that the result of the cell cycle should be two nearly identical cells which contain copies of the same DNA encoded plan

en-us: The small differences are likely in slightly uneven distribution of organelles and or cytoplasm. For differentiated cells, the daughter cells should be able to perform the same functions as the parent cell immediately. For undifferentiated stem cells, the number of cells increases and other triggers will cause specialization later

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if there was an error in copying that was not detected in earlier steps, then the DNA of the daughter cell and all future cells from that line will have that error (mutation)

en-us: It is important to stress that we are talking about only cells in the individual. These are daughter cells not offspring. Mutations that are passed generationally will occur later

competencyText.en-us: Protein as the key chemical in the cell

en-us: The focus here is that of all the types of chemicals in the cell, proteins perform the largest number and variety of functions. Emphasis will be placed on the idea that structure including shape determines function which will serve as a precursor to DNA translation into proteins. Eventually this will lead to a discussion of the effects of errors in the code that might result in changing the shape and therefore the functioning of the protein.  For many students just understanding that proteins perform a wide variety of functions in the cell is enough. Details are included here for advanced biology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that chemical reactions in cells require the use of enzymes which serve as catalysts or enablers to the reaction

en-us: At this point, the chemical knowledge of most student will be limited. Understanding that catalysts are chemicals that speed up or enable reactions is sufficient. This stepping stone understanding might be used by chemistry teachers in high school, to help explain and conceptualize that catalysts lower the activation energy by tapping into this biology knowledge. Knowing that decreasing the activation lowers the temperature needed to start a reaction (because more slowly moving particles can exceed the activation energy) can be used to explain why enzymes are so important. If a reaction would normally require a temperature of several hundred degrees to overcome the activation energy without a catalyst, that would mean that without an enzyme that a cell would need to be so hot that all the water would vaporize causing the cell to explode. But, with an enzymatic catalyst the reaction can occur at normal body temperatures.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that sometimes an enzyme will split one chemical into two or more smaller chemicals

en-us: Examples of this include digestion enzymes like salivary amylase and pancreatic amylase that break down starches or pepsin that breaks down proteins

competencyText.en-us: Understand that sometimes an enzyme will take two or more small chemicals and form a larger chemical

en-us: DNA polymerase studied in the previous level would be an example of this

competencyText.en-us: Understand that many enzymes work like a lock and key so that only specific shapes of chemicals can be operated on by an enzyme.

en-us: Carvone is a chemical that has two shapes with the same chemical formula. These compounds are effectively shaped like a right hand and a left hand (the term is chiral).  The left rotating one smells like spearmint while the right rotating one smells like caraway seeds (rye bread).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the part of a protein where it reacts with other substances is called the active site
Understand that the shape of the active site determines what kinds of chemicals that the protein can interact with
Understand that the structure of the protein will determine its shape which in turn will determine how and on what other chemicals it can function

en-us: This is an opportunity to revisit the lock and key analogy of enzymatic proteins

competencyText.en-us: Understand that other chemicals in the cell such as chaperone proteins and cofactors may affect the shape and therefore the functioning of the protein

en-us: Many cofactors are metallic cations (positive ions) in solution which is why they are essential minerals nutritionally. Iron in

competencyText.en-us: Understand that complex organic cofactors are also known as coenzymes

en-us: Acetyl coenzyme A is often studies as part of the Krebs cycle in cellular respiration. One model of coenzymes is that occupy or reshape the active site of a protein so that the target molecule (substrate) will fir appropriately using the lock and key metaphor

competencyText.en-us: (MISCONCEPTION) Believe that a protein contains only one kind of amino acid

en-us: Students may think that a protein contains only one kind of repeating amino acid. This may arise from two separate previously learned (and possibly misunderstood ideas). First, that polymers involve the repetition of the same monomer over and over again. Frequently, the first polymers students learn about are simple polymers like Teflon and polystyrene and are taught as if they repeat only one monomer over and over again. Consequently, students internalize that polymers are strings of the same monomer over and over again. The second may come a misunderstanding of food proteins. For example, students have heard that tryptophan in turkey makes you sleepy. So they think that turkey proteins contain only tryptophan.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that enzymes are proteins made of smaller parts, amino acids, that are combined to make larger molecules

en-us: The term polymer can be used here to describe proteins that are made of smaller units or monomers. This can be related back to DNA which is also a polymer. It is good to note here that students may struggle with the idea that a polymer can contain different monomers

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins have a primary structure caused by the specific sequence of amino acids that are used to make the protein

en-us: Peptide bonds as a term can be introduced but the chemical reaction of dehydration synthesis is not nearly as important as understanding that amino acids are attached together.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins have a secondary structure caused by hydrogen bonds (attractions) in closely located peptide chains

en-us: Alpha-helix and beta-sheets are the two main types. But for most students the key facet here is that these are attractions that occur over short distances between nearby groups of amino acids

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins have a tertiary structure that is caused by hydrophobic (water fearing nonpolar portions) and hydrophilic (water loving polar sections) that cause proteins to have specific three dimensional shapes

en-us: Many students will not have learned about bond polarity and the effects of molecular geometry. The emphasis is placed on understanding that certain parts of the molecule are more stable when the molecule achieves shapes that have some parts folded outward towards the solvent. This returns to the fundamental driving force which is that all chemicals tend to occur in the most stable configuration for current conditions. Since the cell is full of water, the molecule will arrange itself to maximize stable attractions and minimize unstable repulsions because of electrical forces at the atomic level. Students may want to employ teleological reasoning to the molecule (it wants to be stable) when they really mean that it tends to become stable. At this point in the progression, the teleological reasoning can be used as an acceptable stepping stone understanding as the idea of stability is more important than a firm understanding of the electrochemical causes at this point because the requisite chemistry knowledge is lacking.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the tertiary structure and shape plays an important role in how the protein functions

en-us: All proteins must have a primary, secondary, and tertiary structure

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins have a quaternary structure that involves the interaction of several chains or subunits

en-us: Most students will be familiar with hemoglobin the primary functioning protein in red blood cells. It has a quaternary structure that involves four sub-units working together.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the four levels of structure, including the quaternary if present, determine the overall shape and structure of the protein
Understand that the overall shape and structure of a protein determine its functioning by determining what other chemicals it can interact and react with based on the appropriate geometry
Understand that if a protein has a small error in its structure, it may still be able to perform its functions
Understand that errors in the structure of a protein may limit the effectiveness of the protein to facilitate the reactions that it normally does

en-us: One example of this would be hemoglobin that is sickle shaped instead of round

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some errors in the structure of a protein will make the protein completely ineffective to facilitate the reactions it normally does
Understand that proteins are involved in almost every chemical reaction in living things either directly or indirectly

en-us: The following KSAs give more detail to this statement. The degree to which each individual statement is important and the detail that students should know would be determined by course goals.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins are involved in metabolism
Understand that proteins cause DNA replication, repair, and transcription
Understand that there are thousands of reactions for which proteins serve as catalytic enzymes
Understand that proteins are used to communicate information from one cell to another

en-us: Cell signaling using proteins like insulin is used to transmit information to tissues far from where the chemical is produced

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins are embedded in cell and nuclear membranes which serve as receptors of information that trigger changes in the cell
Understand that some proteins in membranes serve as channels that allow certain chemicals to move in and out of cells
Understand that antibodies are proteins in the immune system
Understand that some proteins serve as structural components in cells or organelles

en-us: Actin and tubulin would be examples. Keratin, elastin, and collagen are well known as components in nails and cartilage.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins are used to cause movement

en-us: Proteins cause movement in single cells and sperm by generating force. Myosin fibers are used to contract muscles in multicellular animals.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins are used to bind and carry other chemicals within organisms

en-us: Hemoglobin as a binder of oxygen is a good example

competencyText.en-us: Explain a variety of functions that proteins perform at the cellular level
Understand that proteins perform function between cells at the tissue level
Understand that proteins perform functions at the organ level
Understand that proteins perform functions at the organ system level
Understand that proteins perform functions at the organism level
Understand that proteins are central to the survival of the organism because they perform functions from the molecular level through the organism level
Understand that protein functioning leads to all observable traits in an organism

en-us: This is a major takeaway as it will be the important precursor to level 10

competencyText.en-us: Understand that protein functioning leads to traits that are not directly observable

en-us: Also important as a precursor to level 10 of the progression

competencyText.en-us: How proteins are made

en-us: Students will learn how DNA is the instructional code for proteins and how RNA is used to convert that information into proteins. They will also learn what happens if the DNA is not translated correctly into the appropriate sequence of amino acids. This unit focuses on the central dogma that DNA codes for proteins.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins are made by sequencing amino acids in specific orders
Understand that the cell must have a set of directions to sequence amino acids together to make proteins
Understand that DNA bases are the instructional plan for making proteins
Understand that a gene is section of DNA that codes for a specific protein

en-us: There are other functions that occur in the code (regulatory functions, but they will be addressed later in the progression.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a sequence of three consecutive DNA bases is called a codon
Understand that since there are 4 bases and 3 bases in a codon, there are 64 possible codons

en-us: 4*4*4 = 64. The term permutation might be useful if the students have the math knowledge

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there are 20 amino acids used in protein synthesis

en-us: This is for humans and most other species.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that since there are 64 codons for only 20 amino acids some amino acids will have more than one codon

en-us: This can be related back to cyphers, codes, and languages from earlier in the progression. Some languages operate this way (Mayan had multiple symbols for the same syllable).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that having redundant codons allows for more than specific sequence of DNA bases to code for the same amino acid in a sequence

en-us: For example valine can be coded GTT, GTC, GTA, or GTG

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all genes begin with a start codon

en-us: ATG (methionine) is the start codon. There are initiation factors needed to activate a start codon. But this can be added in later levels of the progression.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all genes end with a stop codon

en-us: There are three stop codons.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a codon table shows the correspondence between specific codons and the amino acids or function (start or stop) that the codon represents

en-us: Sometimes the table is shown with mRNA codons rather than the original DNA codons. Here we limit the table to only DNA versions of the codons,

competencyText.en-us: Predict the sequence of amino acids based on a DNA sequence from the beginning (start codon) to the end (stop codon) using a codon table

en-us: Generally, this is limited to much smaller of codon triplets than would occur in a real protein which usually has thousands of codons.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that DNA is found in the nucleus but protein synthesis occurs outside the nucleus

en-us: The focus here is on prokaryote patterns.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the information code for proteins must get from the nucleus to the areas where proteins are made

en-us: This is important as a precursor to understanding the different roles of m-RNA which transfers information from the nucleus to the cell and t-RNA which translates the code from nitrogen bases to amino acids.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a chemical is used to send the information from the nucleus to the parts of the cell that make proteins
Understand that the chemical that takes information from DNA in the nucleus to the cell is m-RNA (messenger RNA)
Understand that  the DNA serves as a pattern for the RNA

en-us: Template strand

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a protein enzyme unzips the DNA helix

en-us: Helicase is the enzyme. But most students will not need to know the details

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a different protein enzyme creates m-RNA from the template strand

en-us: RNA polymerase reads from the 3' to the 5' end, but the details are, again, not important to most students below advanced biology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that RNA uses a slightly different set of bases than DNA
Understand that RNA uses uracil in place of thymine

en-us: Many students learn this by knowing the bases at the end of the list in alphabetical order (ACGTU) replace each other

competencyText.en-us: Understand that RNA uses the complementary codon for each base
Understand that adenine in DNA pairs with Uracil in RNA

en-us: Mnemonic is that vowels go together. This is the only pairing that is not identical to the DNA prediction in earlier levels of the progression

competencyText.en-us: Understand that thymine in DNA pairs with adenine in RNA

en-us: This is the same as predicting pairs in DNA

competencyText.en-us: Understand that cytosine in DNA pairs with guanine in RNA and vice versa

en-us: Mnemonic is that consonants go together

competencyText.en-us: Predict the mRNA sequence given a DNA sequence

en-us: Generally these are limited to short sequences to illustrate the differences and not a complete sequencing of thousands of pairs that would correspond with a protein

competencyText.en-us: Understand that mRNA then leaves the nucleus to the cytoplasm

en-us: The exact mechanism of how the m-RNA is beyond the scope of typical biology classes.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that ribosomes are cellular organelles that use mRNA to make proteins
Understand that another form of RNA is tRNA

en-us: tRNA is transfer RNA that translates the DNA code to amino acids

competencyText.en-us: Understand that tRNA has specific that correspond to mRNA bases using complementary base pairing

en-us: These are sometimes referred to as anticodons. Wobble codons and other minor details are beyond the scope of this progression. As are details about directionality (5', 3' concerns).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that one end of the tRNA is able to transport a specific amino acid that corresponds to its codon sequence from the table

en-us: This is the activation phase.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the first piece of tRNA to bind corresponds to the start codon

en-us: This is called the initiation phase.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the next available codon binds with a corresponding tRNA to add the next amino acid to the protein

en-us: This is the elongation phase. Details of the formation of the peptide bond and other reactions and proteins in the process are beyond the scope of this LP.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the process continues until a stop codon is reached

en-us: This is the termination phase. Details of the termination of the peptide chain and other reactions and proteins in the process are beyond the scope of this LP.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the mRNA is not an exact copy of the DNA, then it might result in the same amino acid or a different amino acid

en-us: Here the idea of redundancy is important. For example, alanine includes all codons that start GC. So, miscopying the third part of a codon for alanine will result in no change as to which amino acid is coded for. However, if GAT is miscoded as GAA, then aspartic acid would be replaced by glutamic acid.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the change causes a different protein to occur it is called a mutation and the result is a mutant protein

en-us: Must be careful to explain that mutation is not inherently negative

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if one or more bases is skipped between codons, the wrong sequence of amino acids will be made beginning with the location after the mistake

en-us: If one codon is skipped, then the protein will likely have a cascade of errors from that point forward. It will likely have a stop codon at the wrong location (too soon or too late) depending on the proximity of the error to the location of the correct stop codon.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the wrong sequence of amino acids is used to make a protein, it may or may not perform its functions as well
Understand that if the error in the amino acid sequence does not  have an effect on the shape of the active site of the protein it may have no noticeable effect on its functioning

en-us: The idea that a mistake can be good, bad, or neutral will be important to tie into evolutionary biology.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the error affects the shape of the active site, then the protein will probably not have the same functioning as the original protein coded for
Understand that the change in the protein's active site structure may improve its functioning.
Understand that the change in the protein's active site structure may decrease the effectiveness of its functions
Understand that the change in the protein's active site structure might make the protein ineffective for its previous function
Understand that the change in the protein's active structure might affect something that is not directly related to the original function of the protein

en-us: A good example of this would be the change in the hemoglobin protein that is commonly referred to as sickle cell. An error causes the blood to carry oxygen less effectively which reduces the effectiveness of the protein's function. However, it had a side effect that increased the resistance to malaria.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the error occurs in RNA only the protein that was synthesized will be affected
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that at the end of one gene the next gene appears immediately after the previous gene

en-us: Students may believe that DNA is like a computer code with blocks of information placed directly next to each other.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there may be large sequences of DNA between a stop codon and the next start codon in DNA
