en-us: Part of that error is information related to stability and RNA transport. Some of it is unimportant and some of it signals the start of a new gene. To combat the misconception that genes follow each other immediately, the analogy to comments or REM statements in a computer code can explain that some of the between space is informational, some is preparatory information, and some of it is just nonsense like REM statements in computer programs that Kilroy was her

competencyText.en-us: Proteins as common components and specialized components in cells

en-us: This level of the progression focuses on the what of gene expression: only a small percentage of the proteins in the DNA code are actually made by any given cell. The how and why will come in the next level of the progression. Many students will easily understand that a cell only uses resources to make the proteins it needs to do its job. The easy analogy is that students only do what is necessary and don't try to do extra work for which they don't receive credit.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins are present in most if not all cells
Understand that the proteins found commonly in nearly all types of cells correspond to functions common to all cells

en-us: Good examples would be proteins related to CR, structure of organelles, DNA replication, and transcription

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins that are not needed by a type of cell to function will not be made by that type of cell

en-us: The focus here is on a scarcity of resources model. Cells have finite energy and metabolic resources

competencyText.en-us: Understand that specialized cells may make proteins unique to their functions

en-us: Only cells in the pancreas make certain digestive enzymes for examples. There are proteins unique to neurons. Proteins that are far more common muscles.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that proteins made in one type of cell may affect other cells in the same or different tissues

en-us: Pancreatic enzymes affect digestion in the duodenum, for example.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a protein may have different functions in different cells based on what chemicals are available to react with the protein

en-us: This allows for a return to the role of things like cofactors and coenzymes. It also might be a place to explore the fact that the same protein might be able to work on different substrates (e.g., hemoglobin in red blood cells transports oxygen and carbon dioxide while in other tissues and cells it may act as an antioxidant or serve to regulate the metabolism of iron.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that most cells are specialized and can only produce cells identical to themselves
Understand that some cells can produce either identical cells or differentiate into other kinds of cells

en-us: The emphasis here is that these cells are capable making a wider variety proteins than already differentiated cells

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in mammals, like humans, there are very few stem cells in adults
How does the same DNA code in all cells lead to different kinds of cells

en-us: The focus here is on the "why" does the same DNA not produce only identical cells. The actual chemical regulators are reserved for advanced biology courses in HS or college.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that despite having the same DNA code or blueprint not all cells are the same
Understand that the functioning in a cell is determined by what proteins are present in that cell
Understand that since cells have different functioning, they must have different proteins
Understand that there must be a mechanism that controls what proteins a cell makes and uses
Understand that the cell responds to chemical signals from both inside and outside the cell to determine which proteins to make
Understand that some chemicals prevent and others cause the expression of specific genes and the corresponding proteins in a cell
Understand that some genes are controlled or regulated based on the  concentrations of certain trigger chemicals

en-us: Hormones, transmitters, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that which proteins are activated determine structure and function across multiple levels of organization: molecular, cell, tissue, organ, and organism

en-us: An example would be albinism (simplified explanation for illustration). The protein tyrosinase (molecular level) that is not produced correctly. So the cell cannot make melanin. This means that tissues that would normally have melanin appear white (if fur) or pink (if eyes) which causes the organism to be more susceptible to UV light, less able to camouflage itself, and more sensitive to bright light.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the regulation of genes in an embryo leads to cellular differentiation and the formation of tissues, organs, and systems
Understand that if there is an error in gene regulation by either overstimulation or suppression that problems (diseases) may occur

en-us: Cancer is an example in which regulation is problematic. Chemical addiction to drugs would be another.

competencyText.en-us: Meiosis and the transmission of genetic information across generations

en-us: This level of the progression will stress how the DNA code is passed from one generation to the next through gametes. One focus will be on linking meiosis to Mendelian genetics through discussion of randomization and crossing over. The other focus will be on how errors of copying DNA during meiosis do not only affect the cell line in a specific organism, they could have impact on all subsequent generations if the error is not catastrophic.

competencyText.en-us: (MSICONCEPTION) Believe that male genes are present in sperm and female genes are present in eggs

en-us: Lewis & Kattmann, 2004.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the genetic code must be transferred from parent to offspring
Understand that a mechanism is necessary to pass the genetic code from one generation to the next
Understand that offspring need to have the same number of chromosomes as the parent offspring

en-us: Since each species has a specific number of chromosomes, that number of chromosomes is maintained under normal circumstances.  Later in the progression, errors in copying will be covered as often being non-viable or having other problems. The ideas of chromosomal fusion or increasing the number of chromosomes which might eventually lead to speciation are beyond the scope of this learning progression.  Exceptions to this can be mentioned as exceptions and that it is more common in plants than animals.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in order to get the same total amount of chromosomes as the parents, the offspring will need to get only half of the DNA code from each parent

en-us: The important aspect here is that if offspring received complete copies of chromosomes from each parent, then the offspring would have double the number of chromosomes as the parent.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the first stage of meiosis is replication of the DNA

en-us: The idea here is that some parts of mitosis are the same as meiosis and other parts are different.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that meiosis will involve two sets of divisions so that the number of chromosomes in each daughter cell is half the original amount

en-us: The idea of having PMAT 1 and PMAT 2 is a key concept and that the stages follow the same order as mitosis.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that during prophase 1, chromosomes condense and the nuclear membrane is broken down
Understand that crossing over occurs during prophase 1

en-us: Details about centromere location and finer details are beyond the scope of this LP.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that crossing over involves two homologous chromosomes swapping portions of DNA
Understand that crossing over is the mechanism that causes Mendelian Law of independent assortment

en-us: This may be the a-ha moment for students that allows linking the levels of the genetic LP together. It may occur later in the progression. It is important to stress that this gives a mechanistic causal explanation at the molecular level for observations noticeable at the organism and population levels.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the law of independent assortment is not necessarily true for genes that are located near each other on a chromosome
Understand that during metaphase I homologous chromosomes move to the metaphasal plate
Understand that the homologous chromosomes line up randomly which results in the law of segregation

en-us: There is no order that maternal and paternal copies of chromosomes line up so on the 'left' there may be a mix of chromosomes that originally were part of the maternal and paternal lines

competencyText.en-us: Understand that during anaphase I homologous chromosomes move to opposite ends of the cell

Understand that during telophase I chromosomes gather at the pole of each of the cells, a new nuclear membrane forms,  and the cytoplasm divides resulting in two cells with complete sets of chromosomes
Understand that although the two cells have the same number of chromosomes as the original cell that neither cell has identical DNA for all genes to the original cell because of crossing over

en-us: This is very important to understand for the randomization factor in Mendelian genetics.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that during Meiosis II, each process is happening in two cells separately
Understand that during prophase II the nuclear membrane breaks down and new centrioles form
Understand that during metaphase II the chromosomes line up on the metaphase plate with one sister chromatid on each side
Understand that during anaphase II the sister chromatids separate and move to opposite ends of the cell
Understand that during telophase II new nuclear membranes form and cytokinesis occurs gain
Understand that once both sets of cells have finished meiosis II there will be 4 cells that each have only one of each chromosomal pair
Understand that the products of meiosis II are called gametes
Understand that errors may occur during meiosis
Understand that if the sister chromosomes do not split evenly between the two cells during anaphase I the two daughter cells will not have the same number of chromosomes as the original cell

en-us: One cell will have too many (24 pairs or 48 chromosomes) and the other will have too few (22 pairs or 44 chromosomes).

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if nondisjunction errors occur during anaphase II then the resulting cell will not have half the original number of chromosomes

en-us: One cell will have one chromosome too many and the other will have one chromosome too few. In humans this will result in 24 or 22 chromosomes, respectively instead of the normal 23.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that most zygotes formed from cells that have the wrong number of chromosomes are not viable and result in miscarriage if fertilized
Understand that the few viable versions of zygotes resulting from nondisjunction usually have significant genetic problems

en-us: Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Klinefeltner's syndrome (XXY) are two good examples of these that have significant effects on the health and development of the resulting child. There are analogous diseases in other animals or plants, but those two are the examples found in most texts.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if an error occurs during DNA replication prior to meiosis I there are several possible results
Understand that if the mistake occurs in an area that is not directly responsible for a gene or gene regulation that there is likely no effect of this change at the protein or organism level

en-us: The exception to this could be an error that creates a start codon where it did not belong. However, that error would need to be close enough to a section that signals a start codon is near to have an impact.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a single base pair may be miscopied
Understand that a point mutation may code for the same amino acid or for a different amino acid
Understand that if the same amino acid is coded then there will be no change to the protein made and the offspring will make proteins that are identical to the parent organism

en-us: Again, this is an opportunity to revisit the value of redundancy in the code. Many point errors result in no change to proteins which means that they have no effect on functioning at the molecular level or higher. This is the same idea about cell lines from mitosis

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the point mutation results in the code for a different amino acid that the protein manufactured by the offspring will not be identical to the protein made by the parent
Understand that if the error replaces an amino acid with a stop codon that the protein will not be made correctly and will differ from the protein made by the parent
Understand that if one or more bases is skipped the codons from that point onward will all be affected causing many changes in the primary structure of the protein
Understand that although meiosis has been explained as being identical, there are differences between males and females in humans

en-us: Oogenesis and spermatogenesis are not identical in mammals.  Often the emphasis is placed on humans as being relevant to students and allowing them to scaffold the knowledge here to what they have learned in human development or health classes.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in females, meiosis I occurs in utero but meiosis II does not begin to occur until after puberty
Understand that in human females the original cell will only produce 1 egg and 3 polar bodies that are not used for reproduction

en-us: Often the first polar body does not divide a second time, so in reality there are often two polar bodies and one viable egg. The key takeaway is that in mammals, only one viable egg is usually produced in comparison to the 4 sperm that are produced in males.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in human males the result is the production of 4 sperm cells
Explain the differences between meiosis and mitosis
Explain the differences between meiosis I and meiosis II
Explain the effects of crossing over
Explain the benefits of random assortment of chromosomes in meiosis
Explain the risks of crossing over

en-us: If the areas crossover in unusual ways, some genes may be damaged. SRY gene is one example. Normally, when crossing over occurs between the X and Y chromosomes normally only occurs beyond the SRY (further towards the ends than the locus of the gene on the Y-chromosome. If crossing over occurs below that gene, the result can be men with XX genotype and females with XY genotypes. This unusual instance had a large impact on the discovery of the gene in the 1980s after it was theorized in the early 20th century.

competencyText.en-us: Protein expression based on genetic information (genotype) leads to observable traits (phenotype)

en-us: The focus here is linking from the code through the protein to the observable trait. This upper anchor links together all three models inherent in the LP.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the genetic code that an organism receives from its parents corresponds to its genotype
Understand that the majority of the DNA code is nearly identical for all members of a species

en-us: Even across similar species with a recent common answer the majority of the DNA code is the same

competencyText.en-us: Understand that most genes code for proteins that are virtually identical in all members of a species

en-us: Almost all DNA is essentially the same when compared from one individual to another in a species because the basic life processes at the molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, and system level as well as their regulation are basically the same. In order to be the same, they must have the same basic code or plan.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when there are differences in the code that there are differences in the genotype
Understand that an individual normally receives one version of the gene for a protein from each parent
Understand that a gene for a particular version of a protein is analogous to the allele described by Mendelian genetics
Understand that if an organism has two different versions of the gene for a protein that several possible results can occur
(MISCONCEPTION) Believe that all recessive genes are bad and dominant genes are good
Understand that sometimes one of the genetic variations (alleles) will not produce a functional protein so only one functional version of the protein is produced
Understand that usually when one version of the protein is nonfunctional, then that version of the gene is recessive
Understand that sometimes the cell will produce two different versions of the protein that may function in different ways
Understand that sometimes the different version of the gene for a protein can perform some of the protein's functions but not all of its function
Understand that a protein that can perform some functions but not all may sometimes become a dominant negative allele

en-us: One example is the p53 gene which regulates cell growth. The functional protein works as a tetramer of 4 component proteins. In order to function correctly, all 4 proteins must be correct. If one gene version (allele) is incorrect, then the tetramer cannot function correctly and cellular growth will not have the normal regulator that stops it. (https://genetics.thetech.org/ask/ask227)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a version of the protein may perform some functions at the wrong time or with the wrong pre-cursor trigger

en-us: One example for gain of function would be abnormalities in the FGFR3 gene that regulates bone growth. The dwarfism allele of this gene causes the prevention of bone growth before it should occur. In this case, the version of the gene (allele) that would be considered negative is dominant.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that many processes in living things require multiple proteins and therefore multiple genes
Understand that how the protein or proteins relevant to a task function at the molecular and cellular level may have an impact that is visible at the organism level

en-us: One example would be hair color. There are multiple genes involved, but fundamentally if the gene that causes a larger amount of eumelanin relative to pheomelanin, the hair will appear black. If the reverse is true, a large amount of pheomelanin relative to eumelanin the hair will appear to be red.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that visible effects are called phenotype
Understand that phenotype may be influenced by both genetic and environmental factors

en-us: The pink color of flamingoes is actually a result of pigments from shrimp that they eat (environmental factors) rather than genetics. Conversely, the pinkish skin of a creature with albinism is a direct effect of the genetics. Returning to the hair example, someone with the genes for black hair can use environmental factors (hair dye) to alter the phenotype (observed hair color) but the underlying genotype will remain the same and in the absence of the environmental factor (hair dye), the original phenotype caused by the genotype will occur.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that when a particular gene is present that the result is always the same visible outcome, phenotype, regardless of the second version of the gene, that gene is called dominant
Understand that when a particular gene must be present on both versions of the gene in order for the result to always the same visible outcome, phenotype, that gene is called recessive

Understand that in many cases when an individual has two different versions of the gene for a particular protein (heterozygous) the resulting phenotype will not be identical to either homozygous version and incomplete dominance is the result.

en-us: The pink colors of four o'clock flowers is often used as the example. The two homozygous varieties are white and red respectively. However, the heterozygous variety appears to be pink.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that for some processes a mixture of dominance, codominance, and recessive patterns are possible

en-us: The most common example of this is the ABO blood typing genetics in humans. A and B are both dominant over O. However, A and B are codominant relative to each other. The genes for A and B result in the production of antigens on the surface of the blood cells that can cause an immune system response.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some of these phenotypes are not directly observable but have been discovered through indirect means

en-us: Blood types is an example of phenotypes that are not inherently visible but were determined as the result of observable patterns. For example, when people began using blood transfusions, some people would die. The discovery of the immune reaction caused by blood types led to the discovery of the underlying phenotypes which are related to the genotypes.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some phenotypes may improve the probability of surviving and having offspring

en-us: This will begin linking these ideas to evolutionary biology

competencyText.en-us: Understand that since some phenotypes are more advantageous for survival and reproduction, the genotypes that lead to these characteristics would also be advantageous
Understand that some phenotypes may decrease the probability of surviving and having offspring
Understand that since some phenotypes are disadvantageous for survival and reproduction, the genotypes that lead to these characteristics would also be disadvantageous
Understand that some genotypes are so disadvantageous that the phenotype is not even viable (trisomy of most chromosomes for example) and never occur in the population.
Understand that some phenotypes will neither increase or decrease the probability of surviving and producing offspring
Understand that over time the genotypes that lead to advantageous phenotypes will likely become more common in the population of a species
Understand that the change in gene frequency over time is the core idea of evolution
Understand that the underlying cause of the difference in phenotypes are differences in the DNA code

Understand that errors in copying DNA during meiosis lead to the different genotypes for an individual which might affect the individual's ability to survive and reproduce that over large amounts of time may eventually result in changes in the genetic frequency of the species
Explain how DNA causes effects at levels from the molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, system, organism, and finally population level.
Topics related to the characteristics of living things: anatomy, physiology, growth, and development at the individual organism level
Learning progression on understanding and explaining that living things share common characteristics that can be used to distinguish them from nonliving things
Things that move purposefully are alive.
Understand that things that move with a purpose (survival, desire, etc.) are alive
Believe that plants do not move purposefully and are therefore not alive
Understand that living things move to meet survival needs
Animals are alive.
Understand that animals are alive
Identify that animals are things that are alive
Both plants and animals are alive.
Understand that both plants and animals are alive
Identify plants as living things
Identify things that are not plants or animals as nonliving
Living things have common characteristics that nonliving things do not.
Understand that living things have the ability to grow
Understand that living things can reproduce
Understand that living things can heal or repair themselves
Understand that living things can die
Understand that there are defining characteristics of living things that can be used to classify them as living or once living
Apply a characteristic property to determine if something is living or was once living
Living things have common characteristics that are agreed upon by scientists.
Understand that science is a social process which tries to arrive at consensus
Understand that scientists have agreed that all living things have common characteristics
Understand that if something is missing one or more characteristics, it would not be considered living (alive)
Understand that all living things are capable of movement
Understand that movement in living things may be external and visible

en-us: Phototropism in plants

competencyText.en-us: Understand that movement in living things may be internal and not easily visible

en-us: Transportation of materials within and between cells

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all living things grow and develop
Understand that all living things respond to stimuli in the environment

en-us: Phototropism

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all living things are able to reproduce
Understand that all living things engage in metabolism

en-us: Chemical reactions that occur in living things that convert energy or rearrange chemicals to form new structures

competencyText.en-us: Understand that all living things needs specific chemicals (substances, nutrients) in order to survive

en-us: Water, food, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if something is living or once living by applying the common characteristics that scientists use
Living things have common characteristics and are made of one or more cells
Understand that all living things are made of one or more cells
Understand that the basic functions of life occur inside cells
Understand that organisms may have one or more cells
Identify single-cell organisms as living
Identify a cell using a microscope or picture from a microscope

competencyLabel.en-us: Structure and Function for an Organism LP

competencyText.en-us: Learning progression to understand, explain, and predict how the levels of structure in an organism (organelles, cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems) interact to perform the necessary functions of life
SFO Living things have parts
Understand that living things are made of smaller parts
Understand that the parts of living things can be identified
Identify correctly common parts of plants

en-us: Flower, stem, root, leaf, stem

competencyText.en-us: Identify correctly the common parts of mammals

en-us: Legs, head, tail, eyes, ears, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Identify the common parts of other vertebrates

en-us: Gills, fins, legs, wings, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Identify the common parts of insects or other invertebrates

en-us: Wings, thorax, pincers, etc.

competencyText.en-us: SFO The parts of living things have specific functions.
Understand that the parts of a living thing are used to perform specific functions
Understand that the shape, size, and makeup of a part of the body influence how that part is able to perform its function

en-us: The beak of a woodpecker is able to drill holes in wood well but would not be good at catching fish.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a part of an organism may serve more than one function

en-us: Mouth is used to pass air into the respiratory system and to grind food to pass it into the digestive system as well as being a way to communicate

competencyText.en-us: Identify correctly the functions of common parts of plants
Identify correctly the functions of common parts of mammals
Identify correctly the functions of common parts of insects or other invertebrates
Identify correctly the functions of common parts of other vertebrates
Understand that different organisms could use different parts to perform the same function

en-us: Gas exchange can be done by stomata (plants), spiracles (insects), gills (fish), lungs (reptiles, bird, mammal), skin (amphibians)
Locomotion can be accomplished with legs, wings, fins, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some parts, like teeth, have different forms to perform different functions
Understand that scientists can determine what foods an organism ate by examining its teeth

en-us: Animals with predominantly molars were likely to be plant eaters
Animals with large amounts of cutting teeth were likely to be carnivores

competencyText.en-us: Predict what types of food an organism ate by examining its teeth
SFO Both internal and external structures contribute to the structure and function of organisms.
Understand that some structures in living organisms are visible from the outside (external)
Understand that some structures in living organisms are not visible from the outside (internal)

en-us: Lungs, intestines, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that structures that are visible may be made of smaller parts that are not visible

en-us: Eyes are made of smaller internal parts that are not directly visible (cornea, fovea, rods, cones, etc.)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the structures, both internal and external, work together to perform necessary functions in organisms
Understand that the structures in organisms can be categorized in several levels
Understand that organ systems are groups of organs that work together to perform common functions

en-us: Early elementary children frequently know of several systems when entering school, particularly the circulatory system

competencyText.en-us: Understand that organs are made of several tissues that work together to perform a common function

en-us: Tissue as a term can be added in upper elementary.

competencyText.en-us: Identify common organs in a drawing, simulation, etc.

en-us: The list of organs that can be identified will grow as students learn about more systems.

competencyText.en-us: Identify which system a given organ belongs to
Draw multiple organs in multiple systems when given directions to draw what you think is inside yourself""
Identify the primary function of organ systems in the human body

en-us: Circulatory would be transport of materials to and from cells

competencyText.en-us: SFO Cells come in many varieties of structures, which are related to their functions.
Understand that cells are microscopic units that can be viewed with a microscope
Understand that all living things are made of one or more cells
Understand that cells must perform functions that allow the organism to survive
Understand that cells come in many different shapes and sizes
Understand that in a single-celled organism, one cell must perform all necessary functions
Understand that in a multicellular organism, a cell may specialize to perform a specific function
Understand that the shape of a cell is often related to its functions
Understand that a cell can be identified by its shape and size

en-us: Muscle cells, neurons, plant cells with chloroplasts

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the cells of bacteria (monera) are different from the cells of other organisms (prokaryotes)
Identify similarities and differences between cells viewed with a microscope or micrograph
Understand that cilia and flagella are cellular structures that aid in cellular locomotion
Understand that vesicles are closed structures that store chemicals within the cell

en-us: The similarity of the structure of vesicles and cellular membranes can be addressed in upper grades.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the cytoplasm includes all of the contents of the cell that are not located inside the nuclear membrane (if present)
SFO Chemical basis of structure and function is the protein.
Understand that cells have smaller parts that perform specific functions
Understand that the cellular membrane functions to control the flow of materials into and out of the cell
Understand that smaller parts that have their own membranes are called organelles
Understand that cells that do not contain membrane-bound organelles are called prokaryotes
Understand that prokaryotes include archaea and monera (eubacteria)
Understand that the nucleus contains chromosomes made primarily of DNA
Understand that ribosomes are organelles that are primarily involved in protein protection
Understand that the Golgi apparatus (body) is an organelle that is primarily involved in assembling and packaging proteins
Understand that the endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle that is involved with protein, lipid, and carbohydrate production and transport
Understand that rough ER contains ribosomes and is primarily a protein manufacturer
Understand that smooth ER lacks ribosomes and has a variety of functions including transport, lipid synthesis, and carbohydrate synthesis
Understand that mitochondria are organelles that are involved in converting energy to usable forms for the cell

Understand that chloroplasts are organelles in plants that contain photosynthetic material that converts light (radiant) energy to chemical energy by converting water and carbon dioxide into oxygen and glucose
Understand that lysosomes are organelles that break down and digest cellular macromolecules or byproducts
Understand that the cell wall is an organelle that provides support and structure to bacterial and plant cells
Identify the type of organelle from a list of its primary functions
Draw a cell and include the organelles present
Understand that different cells can have different numbers of each type of organelle
Understand that the relative amount of organelles in a cell is related to the function of the cell

en-us: Muscle cells have many mitochondria because they use a large amount of energy. Conversely, red blood cells have no mitochondria. Neurons have large concentrations of Golgi bodies for the processing of neurotransmitters.

competencyText.en-us: Understand the differences between plant and animal cells
Understand that not all plant cells contain chloroplasts
Compare and contrast a plant or animal cell
Understand that the operations of living things occur at the cellular level and are transferred to larger and larger structures as a result

en-us: A set of cells working together as a tissue accomplish a necessary part of the function of an organ, which is a necessary component of a system-level process, which is a necessary part of the function at the organism level.

competencyText.en-us: SFO Relationship between genetic information and proteins
Understand that some proteins operate as enzymes regulating chemical reactions in the cell
Understand that some proteins operate as structural components determining the structure and shape of the cell

en-us: Keratin, collagen, elastin

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins are responsible for movement

en-us: Actin and myosin

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins are the active chemical in immune responses

en-us: Antibodies

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins serve as messenger chemicals

en-us: Hormones, insulin, oxytocin, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins serve to activate or regulate the production of other proteins
Understand that proteins have several levels of structure
Understand that a protein is made of amino acids sequenced together with peptide bonds
Understand that the primary structure of a protein is the specific sequence of amino acids in the protein
Understand that the secondary structure is caused by local substructures

en-us: Hydrogen bonds, alpha helix, beta sheets

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the tertiary structure is the 3-dimensional structure driven by interactions with water

en-us: Hydrophobic, hydrophyllic

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some proteins have a quaternary structure of several subunits fitting together in a 3-dimensional structure

en-us: Hemoglobin

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the structure and shape of a protein will determine its function
Understand the lock and key analogy of enzyme interactions
Determine if a particular chemical will work with a particular enzyme based on a model of shape of both lock and key
Understand that only certain parts of a protein are involved in its chemical reactions

en-us: Active sites

competencyText.en-us: Understand that a change in the protein structure may cause the protein to no longer have the correct shape or alignment to operate correctly

en-us: Changes in shape lead to a change in the shape of the lock/key mechanism, or it may make the active site inaccessible.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the shape and functioning of a protein can be influenced by environmental factors

en-us: pH, temperature, presence of cofactors

competencyText.en-us: SFO Relationship between genetic information, proteins, and variation
Understand that DNA is made of sequences of nitrogenous bases attached to a chemical backbone of deoxyribose

en-us: Adenine, thymine, guanine, cytosine

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some sections of DNA code for specific proteins while other parts of the DNA molecule do not code for anything
Understand that DNA is transcribed into mRNA to make proteins
Understand that mRNA will have mirror codons of the original DNA

en-us: G in DNA becomes C in mRNA
C becomes G
T in DNA becomes A in mRNA
A in RNA becomes U (Uracil)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that sets of three RNA bases code for specific amino acids
Understand that some amino acids have more than one codon (triplet) that code for it
Understand that some specific codons code for the beginning of the manufacture of a protein

en-us: Start codon, initiation codon, methionine

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some codons are stop codons that signal the end of the protein synthesis
Determine the amino acid sequence of a small section of DNA or RNA, given a codon table
Understand that all cells have the DNA code to produce all possible proteins
Understand that only certain parts of the DNA code are activated and used in each particular cell
Understand that because DNA codes for proteins, DNA codes for structure and function
Understand that because DNA codes for structure and function, the codes for proteins lead to observable traits and traits and functions at the organism level (phenotypes)
Understand that proteins are the link between the genetic code and observable traits
Understand the relationship between genetic information, proteins, and variation
Understand that a change in the DNA sequence causes a mutation
Understand that a change in a single base could result in several different outcomes

en-us: Redundancy, missense, nonsense

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if the change of a single base results in a codon for the same amino acid, there will be no change to the protein
Understand that if the change of a single base results in a codon for a different amino acid, then the protein will be different
Understand that the change of a single amino acid may have little effect on the functioning of the protein

en-us: Amino acids with similar structures often have similar codon sequences.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that the change of a single amino acid may cause a different effect of the protein
Understand that the different sequence of amino acids may result in a different structure and function of the protein
Understand that the different structure and function of the mutated code for a protein may result in a different observable structure and function of the organism (phenotype)
Understand that if the change in sequence makes the protein more or less effective in performing its function in the given environment, it may affect the survival or reproductive rate of the organism
Understand that the deletion or insertion of a base will affect every codon from that point until a new stop codon is reached

en-us: Frameshift mutation

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if a stop codon occurs before the original protein was synthesized, it usually results in a nonfunctional protein
Understand that mutations in a somatic (body) cell may lead to problems with the functioning of the cell

en-us: Cell death, cancer

competencyText.en-us: Understand that if a mutation occurs in a germ (sex) cell then that mutation could be passed on to the offspring
Understand that if an organism inherits one normal gene and one abnormal gene, there are several possible outcomes
Understand that being heterozygous for a gene may result in smaller amounts of a particular protein being synthesized, but enough is made for the organism to still survive
Understand that being heterozygous may result in two different forms of the protein being produced
Understand that being heterozygous may result in no functional protein being produced

Understand that genetic terms like dominant and recessive can be related to whether/how protein synthesis occurs when different genetic codes (alleles) are present and affect the observable traits (phenotypes) of organisms
Learning progression on understanding that all living organisms undergo changes during their life cycle, although not all organisms undergo the exact same changes
Living things grow.
Understand that one of the characteristics of living things is that they grow
Understand that growth sometimes means getting larger
Understand that growth sometimes means changes that do not involve a change in size

en-us: Plants that do not get larger but generate flowers, fruits, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that organisms get the materials they need to grow from what they eat
Living things undergo changes during their lives.
Understand that an organism changes from its birth as it matures
Understand that both plants and animals undergo changes during their lives

en-us: Example: increases in size, ability to reproduce develops, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that although some organisms (butterflies, frogs, etc.) undergo metamorphosis, for most organisms the young and adult forms are similar in appearance

en-us: Young shark looks like adult
Babies look like small adult humans, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Identify changes in an organism as it grows from records of its appearance (drawings, pictures, measurements, etc.)
The changes in living things follow a predictable cycle.
Understand that all living things arise (are born) from a living thing of the same species
Understand that single-celled and many-celled organisms both have life cycles
Understand that all organisms grow into adult form
Understand that once adulthood is reached, organisms reproduce
Understand that all organisms eventually die
Reproduction is a critical part of the life cycle.
Understand that all living things try to reproduce
Understand that reproduction may occur in different ways
Reproduction passes genetic material from parent to offspring

en-us: This will be key to students understanding molecular genetics in its LP (Elmesky et al, 2013) A slink between macroscopic (organism) level events and submicroscopic (molecular) level events

competencyText.en-us: Understand that different types of reproduction have different advantages and disadvantages
Understand that there are generally more offspring produced than can survive
Death as part of the cycle
Understand that death is the end of the life cycle of a single organism
Understand that the death of an individual organism is not the end of a species
Understand that when an organism dies it can supply matter and energy to other organisms through a variety of processes
Life cycles that are visible at the organism level are caused by changes that occur at the cellular level.
Understand that cells undergo a cell cycle
Understand that the largest percentage of time is spent in the growth phase of the cell cycle
Understand that DNA (genetic material) is replicated during another phase
Understand that mitosis and cytokinesis are the final stages that produce two cells that should be identical
Understand that growth occurs as cells divide and then grow again, which causes tissues, organs, etc. to get larger or change as a result
Understand that the cell cycle is regulated by chemical reactions that occur both inside and outside the cell
Understand that there are several chemical feedback loops, originating either internal or external to the cell , that cause a cell to die
Understand that if there are errors that cause the cell cycle to be abnormal, these errors may cause diseases such as cancer
Topics that are used across all domains in science can be used to link the different fields of science with concepts that are important across multiple domains
Learning progression on the crosscutting concept of organizing and analyzing information to identify, test, and explain relationships
Identify and record a simple pattern
Use a pattern to classify objects
Identify patterns of similarity and difference
Identify when two variables are positively correlated
Identify when two variables are negatively correlated
Identify when no pattern exists between two variables
Identify a rate of change between two variables
Compare two or more rates of change between variables
The crosscutting concept of using explanations and models to find relationships that can be used to make predictions and explanations about the past, present, and future
Learning progression on using explanations and models to find or evaluate cause/effect relationships that are used to make predictions and explanations about events in the past, present, and future
Univariable Test for Cause and Effect
Understand that some actions, events, or objects can cause another action, event, or change
Understand that some variables do not have a cause and effect relationship

en-us: Day of the week has no causal relationship on rain.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that in order for an action or object to cause an effect, it must occur before the effect
Believe that the event that occurred later is the cause of the event that occurred first
Understand that if an object or event causes an effect, the effect should occur whenever the causal variable is present
Understand that for a variable to be causative, it must meet both criteria: (a) the cause occurs before the effect and (b) the cause must consistently lead to the effect
Understand that in order to test a potentially causative variable, all other variables should be held constant
Understand that a repeating pattern is necessary to show causality
Perform a given investigation that is a fair test for a potentially causative variable
Design a series of trials in an investigation to determine if a variable is causative by applying a COV approach
Develop a one variable hypothesis
Understand that data from a previous experiment or investigation can lead to additional experiments
Understand that a pattern in which an effect is present only after a given variable is present means that variable could be causative but may not be causative
Understand that if two events always covary, it is possible that the antecedent could be a cause of the effect
Understand that to eliminate other potential causes, experiments must be done that vary only one potentially causative variable at a time
Trying to change all the potentially causative variables at once to maximize the effect is a common mistake (engineering model")"
Hold the potentially causative variable constant and change other variables to see if any of them have effect

en-us: Hold One Thing At a Time (HOTAT)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that two trials can be used to determine if a potentially causative variable is in fact causative if the only difference between the two trials is the presence or absence of that potentially causative variable
Understand that two trials may show that a potentially causative variable is in fact causative
Determine if a test is capable of determining whether or not a specific variable is causative

en-us: Students tend to prefer to do confirming tests rather than disconfirming tests, even though the latter are more efficient.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if a test gives evidence that a potentially causative variable is in fact causative

en-us: The evidence from the investigation could be in several forms: tables, graphs, charts, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Inconclusive evidence is often used to support a preexisting theory of causation even when it is not wanted
Inconclusive evidence is often used to discount a potential causative variable if the preexisting theory of the individual is that it is not causative
Understand that the more trials that show the covariation of variables, the stronger the likelihood that the antecedent variable is causative
Apply a one variable hypothesis
Use a causative model to predict the effect of the presence or absence of a variable

en-us: It is harder for people to say that changing a noncausative variable will have no effect.

competencyText.en-us: Use a causative model to predict if the dependent variable will increase or decrease in response to the change of a known causative variable

en-us: Providing a table which states that prior findings may reduce working memory load for this task

competencyText.en-us: Use a causative model to predict that a dependent variable will not change in response to changes made to a noncausative variable

en-us: Providing a table which states prior findings may reduce working memory load for this task

competencyText.en-us: Analyze data to find the relationship between the changes in the dependent variable and the independent causative variable
Apply a mathematic relationship between the potentially causative variable and the dependent variable to predict the result of a new trial

en-us: Applying the causative relationship between mass and weight to predict that tripling the mass will triple the weight as well
Applying that weight in Newtons is approximately 10 times the mass in kilograms

competencyText.en-us: Test a multivariable hypothesis
Understand that more than one variable can be causes for an outcome (dependent) variable
Understand that multiple variables can operate at the same time in different ways
Understand that one multivariable hypothesis is that Cause A causes effects on B and C separately

en-us: Example: stress causes both increased drinking and increased blood pressure.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that one multivariable hypothesis is that Cause A causes effects on B, which then causes an effect on C
Understand that one multivariable hypothesis is that multiple variables behave in an additive manner on the effect

en-us: The more causative factors present the more the likelihood of effect happening.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some tests can serve to confirm the possibility of a causative hypothesis
Understand that some tests can serve to disprove the possibility of a causative hypothesis
Decide how to manipulate a variable to confirm a previous hypothesis

en-us: If you believe that A causes B, which in turn causes C, then making B happen should cause C to happen.

competencyText.en-us: Decide how to manipulate a variable to disconfirm a previous hypothesis

en-us: If you believe that A causes B, which in turn causes C, then making C happen should NOT cause B to happen.

competencyText.en-us: Determine if a test, when compared with prior tests, makes a proposed causal mechanism more likely to be true, less likely to be true, or does not add new information

en-us: A trial that reconfirms prior findings may add to feelings of confidence in the findings without actually adding new information.

competencyText.en-us: Understand that some variables can serve as gateway or threshold variables that limit the effect of other potentially causative variables
Perform an investigation to determine if one variable acts as a threshold variable for another

en-us: https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/photoelectric

competencyText.en-us: Determine whether or not a variable serves as a threshold variable using data from an investigation

en-us: The investigation may be simulated or hands-on
The focus is on analyzing data.

competencyText.en-us: Apply a multivariable hypothesis
Belief that only known causative variables that cause an increase in the dependent (output) variable are important in a multivariable scenario
Identify all the variables that will have an effect on the outcome dependent variable for a given trial

en-us: Some variables may have additive effects, some are linked, etc.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the effects of all causative variables separately on the outcome-dependent variable

en-us: This could be done by saying increase, decrease, no change, or by using math analysis.

competencyText.en-us: Predict the cumulative effects of all the causative variables on the outcome-dependent variable
Determine if a prediction of the combined effect of multiple variables is valid based on available data

The crosscutting concept of how interactions at levels ranging from submicroscopic (electron, atomic, and molecular), microscopic (cellular), macroscopic, and megascopic interact and cause changes in other levels
Learning progression on examining how phenomena on different scales (nano, micro, macro, and mega) interact and cause changes at other levels
The crosscutting concept that certain entities (matter, energy, momentum, and electric charge) are conserved in normal processes, which can be used to explain a wide variety of phenomena
Learning progression on understanding and applying the knowledge that in a closed system, under normal conditions, matter cannot be created or destroyed
Learning progression on understanding and applying the knowledge that in a closed system, under normal conditions, energy cannot be created or destroyed
Forms and sources of energy
Energy is associated with people (anthropocentric misconception)
Some objects have energy while others need energy (Depositry misconception)
Energy is dormant in objects but is released by a trigger (Ingredient misconception)
Overt displays are energy (Activity misconception)
Energy is a short lived product of situations (product misconception)
Energy is good for technological devices (functional misconception)
Energy is good for technological devices (functional misconceptioon)
Energy causes things to happen (Active deposit misconception)
Understand that each type of energy has a necessary defining indicator.
Understand that the indicator for kinetic energy is speed.
Understand that the indicator for light energy is the emission of light, whether visible or invisible.
Understand that the indicator for sound energy is the emission of sound.
Understand that the indicator for thermal energy is temperature.
Understand that the indicator for chemical energy is that substances seem to appear or disappear.
Understand that the indicator for elastic energy is the compression or stretching of a substace.
Understand that the indicator for gravitational energy is height.
Understand that the indicator for electrical energy is a complete circuit with a voltage source.
Identify one form of energy in a process or system.
Identify two forms of energy in a system.
Identify three or more forms of energy in a system.
Transfer and transformation of energy
Energy is a fluid that is transferred in certain processes (flow-transfer misconception)
Understand that energy can be transferred from one object to another.
Understand that there are several processes that transfer energy.
Understand that mechanical work is a process that is involved in the transfer of kinetic, elastic, or gravitational energy.
Understand that electric current is involved in the transfer of electrical energy.
Understand that heat is the transfer of thermal energy from one (high temperature) object to another (low temperature) object.
Understand that light (electromagnetic radiation) transfers light energy.
Understand that sound transfers sound energy.
Identify one type of energy transfer process occurs in a given situation.
Identify two or more types of energy transfer process occurs in a given situation.
Understand that energy can be transformed from one form to another form.
Understand that energy transfers usually involve the transformation of energy as well.
Identify one transformation of energy in a given situation.
Identify two or more transformation of energy in a single situation.
Trace the transformation of energy through a two step process.
Degradation of energy
Understand that it is difficult to transform thermal energy to other forms.
Understand that it is difficult to transform sound energy to other forms.
Understand that when energy is transformed some of the energy becomes thermal or sound energy.
Understand that once energy becomes thermal energy, it is considered dissipated or degraded.
Trace the degradation of energy in a physical system.
Trace the degradation of energy in a biological system.
Conservation of energy
Understand that the total amount of energy in a system is constant.
Understand that the total amount of energy at the beginning of a process is equal to the total amount of energy at the end of the process.
Identify whether a system as described has accounted for all the energy in its final state.
Calculate the amount of one type of a energy in a system given the amounts of all the other types of energy at the beginning and end of a process.
Understand that when energy that appears to have disappeared or been destroyed it has been transformed into thermal energy.
Devaluation of energy
Understand that entropy is a measure of the disorder or randomness of a system.
Understand that random moelcular motions are associated with entropy.
Understand that entropy increases with temperature and time (2nd Law of thermodynamics).
Systems
Learning progression on systems thinking including relationships across levels, scales, and part/whole relationships
Placeholder for Graphic Literacy
Clusters of skills used in Graphic Literacy.
Locate Information
Find or fill in information in one graphic
Identify the next or missing step in an illustrated process
Compare two or more pieces of information in a graphic
Locate information in a graphic using information found in another graphic
Trends, Patterns, and Relationships
Identify a trend, pattern, or relationship
Interpret a trend, pattern, or relationship
Compare two or more trends, patterns, or relationships
Make decisions or inferences
Make a decision or inference based on one source of information
Make a decision or inference based on multiple sources of information from one or more graphics
Justify a decision or inference based on information
Representing Data
Identify the graphic that best represents the data
Identify the most effective graphic given a defined purpose
Justify a choice of most effective graphic given a defined purpose
Cognitive Processes
Extract the Data
Read between the data
Read beyond the data
Graphic Complexity

en-us: Graphic Complexity

LOW MODERATE
HIGH MODERATE
DIFFICULT
